###### Mangrove LuxCo III S.à r.l. €425,000,000 Senior Secured Floating Rate Notes due 2029

Mangrove LuxCo III S.à r.l., incorporated as a private limited liability company (société à responsabilité limitée) under the laws of the Grand Duchy of
Luxembourg, having its registered office at 2, rue Edward Steichen, L-2540 Luxembourg, Grand Duchy of Luxembourg and registered with the Luxembourg Register of
Commerce and Companies under number B236258 (the “Issuer”), is offering (the “Offering”) €425,000,000 aggregate principal amount of Senior Secured Floating Rate
Notes due 2029 (the “Notes”). The Notes will be issued pursuant to an indenture (the “Indenture”) to be dated on or about . 2024 (the “Issue Date”).

The Notes will mature on        , 2029. The Issuer will pay interest on the Notes at a per annum rate equal to the three-month EURIBOR (with a floor of 0%)
plus %, reset quarterly. Interest on the Notes will be payable quarterly in arrears on each,, and, commencing on, 2024.

Prior to        , 2025, the Issuer may redeem, at its option, all or part of the Notes at a redemption price equal to 100% of the principal amount thereof, plus
accrued and unpaid interest and Additional Amounts (as defined herein), if any, plus the Applicable Premium (as defined herein). On or after, 2025, the Issuer
may redeem all or part of the Notes at a redemption price equal to 100% of the principal amount thereof, plus accrued and unpaid interest and Additional Amounts, if any.
Upon the occurrence of certain events constituting a Change of Control (as defined herein), the Issuer may be required to make an offer to repurchase all of the Notes at a
redemption price equal to 101% of the principal amount thereof, plus accrued and unpaid interest and Additional Amounts, if any. In the event of certain developments affecting
taxation, the Issuer may redeem all, but not less than all, of the Notes. In addition, in connection with certain tender offers for the Notes, if holders of not less than 90% in
aggregate principal amount of the outstanding Notes validly tender and do not withdraw such Notes in such tender offer and the Issuer, or any third party making such a tender
offer in lieu of the Issuer, purchases all of the Notes validly tendered and not withdrawn by such holders, the Issuer or such third party will have the right to redeem the Notes
of such series that remain outstanding in whole, but not in part, following such purchase at a price equal to the price offered to each other holder of such Notes.

The Notes will be senior obligations of the Issuer, will rank senior in right of payment to any existing and future indebtedness of the Issuer that is subordinated in
right of payment to the Notes, will be pari passu in right of payment among themselves and with all existing and future obligations of the Issuer that are not subordinated in
right of payment to the Notes, including obligations under the Super Senior Facilities Agreement (as defined herein), will be effectively senior to all existing and future
indebtedness of the Issuer that is unsecured or secured by liens junior to the liens securing the Notes to the extent of the value of the property and assets securing the Notes,
will be effectively subordinated to all existing and future indebtedness of the Issuer that is secured by property and assets that do not secure the Notes, to the extent of the value
of the property and assets securing such indebtedness, and will be structurally subordinated to all existing and future indebtedness of the subsidiaries of the Issuer that are not
Guarantors (as defined herein).

On the Issue Date, the Notes will be guaranteed (the “Initial Guarantees”) on a senior secured basis by Mangrove LuxCo IV S.à r.l., Kelvion Holding GmbH,
Kelvion Germany GmbH, Kelvion Industriebeteiligungen GmbH, Kelvion Machine Cooling Systems GmbH, Kelvion Brazed PHE GmbH, Kelvion Thermal Solutions Holding
GmbH, Kelvion Thermal Solutions Germany GmbH, Mangrove GermanCo I GmbH, Mangrove GermanCo II GmbH and Kelvion PHE GmbH (collectively, the “Initial
**Guarantors”). Within 120 days following the** Issue Date, the Notes will, subject to the Agreed Security Principles (as defined herein) be guaranteed (the “Post-Issue Date
**Guarantees” and, together with the Initial Guarantees, the “Guarantees”) on a senior secured basis by Kelvion, Inc., Kelvion Products, Inc., Kelvion Machine Cooling Sp. z**
o.o., Kelvion Sp z o.o. and Kelvion B.V. (collectively, the “Post-Issue Date **Guarantors” and, together with the Initial Guarantors, the “Guarantors”). The Guarantors will**
also guarantee the obligations under the Super Senior Facilities Agreement on a pari passu basis. On the Issue Date, the Notes will be secured, subject to certain perfection
requirements and any Permitted Collateral Liens, by security interests granted on an equal and ratable first priority basis over (i) the shares in the Initial Guarantors, (ii) certain
receivables in respect of structural intercompany loans owing to the Issuer and the Initial Guarantors and (iii) material bank accounts of the Issuer and the Initial Guarantors in
the jurisdiction of incorporation of the Issuer or the relevant Initial Guarantor, as applicable (collectively, the “Issue Date Collateral”). Within 120 days following the Issue
Date, the Notes will, subject to the Agreed Security Principles, certain perfection requirements and any Permitted Collateral Liens, be secured by (i) the shares in the Post-Issue
Date Guarantors, (ii) certain receivables in respect to structural intercompany loans owing to the Post-Issue Date Guarantors, (iii) material bank accounts of the Post-Issue Date
Guarantors in the jurisdiction of incorporation of the relevant Post-Issue Date Guarantor; and (iv) substantially all assets of Kelvion, Inc. and Kelvion Products, Inc. (collectively,
the “Post-Issue Date Collateral” and, together with the Issue Date Collateral, the “Collateral”). Under the terms of the Intercreditor Agreement (as defined herein), proceeds
received upon an enforcement or certain distressed disposals of the Collateral will be paid to the lenders under the Super Senior Facilities Agreement and certain hedging
counterparties, if any, in priority to the holders of the Notes. See “Description of Certain Financing Arrangements—Intercreditor Agreement.” The Guarantees and the security
interests over the Collateral will be subject to certain significant contractual and legal limitations or subject to certain defenses under applicable law. See “Certain Insolvency
_Law Considerations and Limitations on the Validity and Enforceability of the Guarantees and Security Interests” and “Risk Factors—Risks Related to the Notes, the Guarantees_
_and the Collateral—Corporate benefit, financial assistance laws, capital maintenance requirements and other limitations on the Guarantees and the Collateral may adversely_
_affect the validity and enforceability of the Guarantees and the Collateral.” The Guarantees and the security interests over the Collateral may be released under certain_
circumstances. See “Risk Factors—Risks Related to the Notes, the Guarantees and the Collateral—There are circumstances other than repayment or discharge of the Notes,
_under which the Collateral and the Guarantees may be released automatically, without your consent or the Trustee or the Security Agent obtaining your further consent.”_

The Notes will be in registered form in minimum denominations of €100,000 and integral multiples of €1,000 in excess thereof. The Notes will be represented on
issue by global notes, which will be delivered in book entry form through Euroclear Bank SA/NV (“Euroclear”) and Clearstream Banking S.A. (“Clearstream”) on or about
the Issue Date. Interests in each global note will be exchangeable for the relevant definitive notes only in certain limited circumstances. See “Book-Entry, Delivery and Form.”

There is currently no public market for the Notes. Application will be made to The International Stock Exchange Authority Limited (the “Authority”) for the
listing of and permission to deal in the Notes on the Official List of The International Stock Exchange (the “Exchange”). There is no assurance that the Notes will be listed on

**Non-IFRS Financial Measures**

This Offering Memorandum contains certain non-IFRS measures, including the measures are defined as follows:

    - “Adjusted Revenue” is defined as revenue for the year ended December 31, 2021 less revenue attributable
to the Medupi project, a GEA legacy project from 2008, which management considers to be of a one-off
nature and not reflective of the Group’s underlying operative performance. The Medupi project was
completed in 2021 and therefore Adjusted Revenue is presented for the year ended December 31, 2021 only.

    - “EBITDA” is defined as earnings before interest and tax (EBIT) before depreciation, amortization,
impairment losses and reversal of impairment losses on non-current assets.

    - “EBITDA Margin” is, with respect to the year ended December 31, 2021, defined as EBITDA divided by
Adjusted Revenue and, with respect to the years ended December 31, 2022 and 2023, the three months ended
March 31, 2023 and 2024 and the twelve months ended March 31, 2024, defined as EBITDA divided by
revenue.

    - “Normalized EBIT” is defined as Normalized EBITDA less depreciation, amortization, impairment losses
and reversal of impairment losses on non-current assets.

    - “Normalized EBITDA” is defined as EBITDA as adjusted for certain non-recurring effects as described in
footnote 3 in “Summary Financial and Other Information—Other Financial Data.”

    - “Normalized EBITDA Margin” is, with respect to the year ended December 31, 2021, defined as
Normalized EBITDA divided by Adjusted Revenue and, with respect to the years ended December 31, 2022
and 2023, the three months ended March 31, 2023 and 2024 and the twelve months ended March 31, 2024,
defined as Normalized EBITDA divided by revenue.

    - “Capital Expenditures” is defined as payments to acquire property, plant and equipment and intangible
assets in our consolidated statement of cash flows.

    - “Free Cash Flow” is defined as Normalized EBITDA less Capital Expenditures as described in footnote 5
in “Summary Financial and Other Information—Other Financial Data.”.

    - “Free Cash Flow **Cash Conversion” is defined as Free Cash Flow divided by Normalized EBITDA.**

    - “Trade working capital” is calculated as trade working capital w/o retention plus retention from factoring
& customers.

    - “Trade working capital w/o retention” is calculated as inventories plus trade receivables and contract assets
less accounts payables and advanced payments & contract liabilities as described in footnote 7 in “Summary
_Financial and Other Information—Other Financial Data.”_

    - “Net Debt” is defined as the sum of non-current bonds, bank loans (current and non-current) and liabilities
under finance leases (current and non-current) less unrestricted cash and cash equivalents.

The non-IFRS financial measures and related ratios contained in this Offering Memorandum should not be
considered in isolation and are not measures of our financial performance or liquidity under IFRS. They should also not be
considered as an alternative to net profit or loss for the period or any other performance measures derived in accordance
with IFRS or as an alternative to cash flow from operating, investing or financing activities or any other measure of our
liquidity derived in accordance with IFRS. Non-IFRS financial measures do not necessarily indicate whether cash flow
will be sufficient or available for cash requirements and may not be indicative of our results of operations.

In addition, certain non-IFRS financial measures, as we define them, may not be comparable to other similarly
titled measures used by other companies. We believe the non-IFRS financial measures presented in this Offering
Memorandum represent useful indicators of its financial performance when read in addition to IFRS financial measures
indicating our financial performance. You should exercise caution in comparing the non-IFRS financial measures as
reported by us to such measures, similar measures or adjusted variations thereof reported by other companies. It should be
noted that certain financial information relating to us contained in this document has not been audited and in some cases is
based on management information and estimates.

**Order Intake and Order Backlog**

In this Offering Memorandum, we present our order intake and order backlog, which relate to estimated future
revenue (“Order Intake” and “Order Backlog”) and which are defined as follows:

    - “Order Intake” refers to binding customer contracts and purchase orders concluded and received in the
respective reporting period at the respective price; and

    - “Order Backlog” refers to binding customer contracts and purchase orders concluded and the portion of the
associated transaction price for which the amount of sales has not yet been recognized in accordance with
IFRS.

We use Order Intake and Order Backlog to monitor customer orders and new business, plan production capacities
and for overall business planning and liquidity management. The value of our Order Intake and Order Backlog as of any
given date is based on confirmed purchase orders and agreed prices (which may change as a result of variable price and
cost amendment provisions). If purchase orders are cancelled by customers (including within the individual contractual
framework as a result of, among others and as varies from case to case, delays, malfunction or exercise of cancellation in
the buyers’ sole discretion rights prior to delivery of any purchased products), our ability to obtain compensation may be
limited to out-of-pocket costs expenses incurred for materials and work-in-progress or, in some cases, to contractually
agreed penalties. Other companies in our industry may calculate and report Order Intake and Order Backlog or a similar
measure using a different methodology, limiting our usefulness as a comparative measure. Our Order Intake and Order
Backlog figures included in this Offering Memorandum do not purport to represent the actual amount of revenue we will
receive and should not be considered in isolation. The amounts of our Order Intake and Order Backlog have not been
audited or reviewed and are not recognized measures and, as such, our reporting may not be comparable under IFRS or
any other generally accepted accounting principles. Therefore, you should not place undue reliance on our Order Intake
and Order Backlog figures included in this Offering Memorandum.

**Overview**

We are a leading global provider of heat exchanger solutions with more than 100 years of experience in design,
manufacturing, installation and service (source: Frost & Sullivan Report). We have built our strategic pillars on (i) High
Tech applications and solutions, in particular for Data Centers with liquid and free cooling, (ii) Green Tech applications
and solutions in various vertical markets, such as Power & Energy, HVAC, Hydrogen, Liquified Natural Gas, Carbon
Capture Storage, (iii) Conventional applications, such as in the Refrigeration, Food & Beverage, Chemicals and Oil & Gas
vertical markets, as well as (iv) Service applications across all our vertical markets and product groups. Our diversified
presence across regions and transformative industries are supported by long-term underlying megatrends, such as
digitalization, energy transition and environmental concerns in general. Based on the breath of our product portfolio,
extensive global footprint, and diverse end-markets, as well as our technology leadership position and R&D capabilities,
we believe we are well-positioned to benefit from the long-term growth trends in our vertical markets.

Since 2021, under our new management, we have been implementing a comprehensive strategic program known
as “High Five”. The High Five program is designed to build a long-term sustainable business and comprises the following
five strategic pillars: (i) Grow High Tech, (ii) Grow Green Tech, (iii) More Service, (iv) Grow APAC & Americas and (v)
More Digitalization, with greater emphasis on reducing complexity through digitalization. At the same time, we divested
unprofitable businesses, such as the Enexio in recent years. Since the beginning of 2021 and despite several external shocks,
such as the Russia-Ukraine war and the spike in energy prices and inflation caused thereby, our Order Intake, Revenue and
Normalized EBITDA have increased from €1,099.3 million, €931.7 million and €78.8 million, respectively, for the year
ended December 31, 2021 to €1,697.9 million, €1,347.9 million and €146.9 million, respectively, for the year ended
December 31, 2023. Historically, our business operations have been primarily divided into four product groups: Kelvion
Thermal Solutions (“KTS”), Refrigeration Technologies (“RT”), Plate Heat Exchangers (“PHE”) and Machine Cooling
Systems (“MCS”). We also consider our key vertical markets and geographic regions in the management of our business.

      - _KTS provides air fin coolers and cooling towers for installations with large cooling requirements as well_
as air dryers used to remove humidity from air streams. KTS focuses on providing customized solutions
and primarily serves Data Centers, Power & Energy, Oil & Gas and Chemicals vertical markets. For the
twelve months ended March 31, 2024, KTS accounted for 44.6% of our revenue.

      - _RT supplies standard and customized heat exchangers for cooling and removing heat in different_
applications using air and liquid cooling methods. The primary vertical markets are HVAC, refrigeration
applications and Data Centers. For the twelve months ended March 31, 2024, RT accounted for 20.5%
of our revenue.

      - _PHE offers a range of gasketed, brazed and welded plate heat exchangers for a variety of applications_
and vertical markets, including HVAC, Food & Beverage, Chemicals, Power & Energy and Heavy &
Light Equipment. For the twelve months ended March 31, 2024, PHE accounted for 17.9% of our
revenue.

      - _MCS supplies heat exchangers for power generation, power transmission, large engine applications_
(marine and off-highway) and Green Tech applications such as biomass, green hydrogen, or renewable
energies. The primary vertical markets are Transportation, Heavy & Light Equipment, Power & Energy
and Oil & Gas. For the twelve months ended March 31, 2024, MCS accounted for 14.3% of our revenue.

Since the beginning of 2024, the RT, MCS and PHE have been managed on a regional basis in the following
geographic regions – Americas, APAC and EMEA.

In addition, all our product groups’ activities are complemented by a comprehensive after-sales support and
services offering, reflecting our ability to support our customers with full-service packages thereby reducing their operating
costs. We provide services both for our own products as well as for third-party products, managed on a centralized and
global basis across our product groups. For the twelve months ended March 31, 2024, our service business generated
revenues of €251 million and for the year ended December 31, 2023 revenues of €259 million, an increase of 21% compared
to the year ended December 31, 2022.

1


-----

We have a large and diverse customer base, including many blue-chip customers, and have built long-standing
customer partnerships. Our customer base comprises more than 19,000 active customers (i.e., customers that have placed
an order with us in the last 24 months) and repeat orders over multiple years from more than 12,000 customers. Our
customer base is also diversified across vertical markets and geographies. For the twelve months ended March 31, 2024,
our Order Intake by strategic pillar can be broken down as follows: circa 39% in High Tech, circa 36% in Conventional
applications, circa 17% in services and circa 7% in Green Tech. During the same period, the Order Intake by geography
comprised circa 45% in EMEA, circa 42% in Americas and circa 13% in APAC.

Headquartered in Herne, Germany, we operate in 24 countries around the world, with 22 production facilities, 33
service centers and 19 engineering centers as of March 31, 2024. For the twelve months ended March 31, 2024, we
generated total revenue of €1,401 million and Normalized EBITDA of €157.2 million.

**Our Strengths**

We believe we benefit from the following competitive strengths:

**_Global market leader for mission-critical solutions to transformative industries, including Data Centers, Power &_**
**_Energy, HVAC, Carbon Capture Storage and Hydrogen_**

We are a leading global provider of heat exchanger solutions (source: Frost & Sullivan Report) serving a diverse
range of transformative industries (such as Data Centers, Power & Energy, HVAC, Carbon Capture Storage, and
Hydrogen), and vertical markets with a broad and differentiated product portfolio. We are also among the top three global
providers (based on our Order Intake in the addressable market, as of 2022) and the only company that can provide the full
spectrum of solutions across all vertical markets globally. Our leading market position is supported by our comprehensive
geographical footprint with operations in 24 countries (comprising 22 production facilities, 33 service centers and 19
engineering centers as of March 31, 2024) as well as our diverse product offering across a broad range of heat exchanger
products, which differentiates us from our competitors. Our solutions and products are often mission-critical to our clients’
operations because they are necessary to ensure the efficiency and safety of our clients’ operations while they only represent
a relatively small portion of the overall cost. Transformative Industries support the exponential growth of digital data by
providing the infrastructure for data storage, processing, and management of digital data. Innovations in cooling and energy
efficiency are transforming this sector. Power & Energy includes renewable sources, smart grids and energy storage
solutions. Advances in these areas are crucial for reducing carbon emissions and transitioning to a more sustainable energy
framework. Innovations in HVAC systems are enhancing energy efficiency, comfort in residential, commercial and
industrial buildings. Smart HVAC technologies and sustainable practices are at the forefront of this transformation. The
Carbon Capture Storage industry focuses on technologies to capture and store carbon dioxide emissions from industrial
processes and power generation, helping to mitigate climate change. Lastly, the Hydrogen industry is developing
technologies for producing, storing, and utilizing hydrogen as a clean energy source. Hydrogen has the potential to play a
significant role in decarbonizing transportation, industry and power generation.

As part of our High Five program, we focus on vertical markets within the strategic pillars High Tech and Green
Tech. These strategic pillars present a significant market opportunity to us which is forecast to grow significantly until
2027. We estimate that the total addressable market for heat exchangers in the vertical markets comprising our High Tech
and Green Tech pillars amounted to €2.4 billion and €1.1 billion in 2022, respectively (source: Frost & Sullivan Report,
MarketsandMarkets Report, Third Party Report and internal company assessments). These vertical markets are also
forecast to have the most attractive growth rates, expanding at a CAGR of 8% and 20%, respectively, between 2022 and
2027. During the same period, we reduced our exposure to Oil & Gas, Chemicals and Power & Energy from 37% of our
Order Intake for the year ended December 31, 2021 to 29% in the twelve months ended March 31, 2024.

Our decentralized model of local production, near our customers, helps us maintain our leading positions in our
core geographic regions. Our ability to provide a one-stop shop product approach combined with our service offering is
increasingly valued by customers. Compared to smaller, regionally focused peers, we believe we have a better
understanding of technical, health, safety and environmental regulation standards globally and locally. Combined with our
scale and logistical strength to carry out large projects which are generally command improved margins. We believe that
this differentiated product and service offering has been instrumental for recent contract wins from key customers. For
example, we were awarded an order from a leading US-based bitcoin mining platform for adiabatic hybrid coolers. We
developed a customized solution focusing on water and energy consumption. As a result, our cooling solution required
70% less water and 25% less energy than existing models, which also aligns well with our own long-term sustainability
goals. Another example is an order from a US-based hyperscaler in the Data Center vertical market. Through measures,
such as joint technology workshops with the customer, material optimization and a design-to-cost approach, we believe we
were able to reduce the material requirements for our heat exchanger solutions by approximately 10% compared to existing
models. Our global scale also underpins the strength of our brand, which places us well to continue to strengthen our
positions in these fast growing and transformative end-markets segments and vertical markets.

**_Well-positioned to benefit from long-term sustainable secular megatrends, such as increasing environmental awareness_**
**_and the changes triggered by energy transition, along with the growth of digitalization_**

We believe we are strategically well-positioned to benefit from underlying megatrends across our strategic pillars
and vertical markets. The key pillars and vertical markets we serve are characterized by underlying growth supported by
long-term sustainable trends.

For example, the High Tech market, which accounted for 39% of our Order Intake for the twelve months ended
March 31, 2024, is projected to increase at a CAGR of 8% from 2022 to 2027 due to strong and growing demand for data
centers. The Green Tech market, which accounted for 7% of our Order Intake for the twelve months ended March 31, 2024,
is expected to grow at a CAGR of 20% between 2022 to 2027 based on an increasing focus on energy efficiency and
environmental awareness, which, in turn, is driving regulatory changes aimed at climate protection and heat recovery for
residential and commercial buildings as well as for industrial applications (source: Frost & Sullivan Report,
MarketsandMarkets Report, Third Party Report and internal company assessments).

Similar global trends and the (re)-industrialization in Conventional markets underpin the growth outlook across a
range of industries, with the services business also being transformed by a shift to, and higher demand for, high-proximity
and intelligent services.

**_Difficult to replicate business model, underpinned by differentiated engineering solutions, service capabilities and_**
**_customer responsiveness_**

We believe our differentiated technical offerings and service capabilities are difficult to replicate and,
consequently, create high barriers to entry and prevent new competitors from easily entering our markets. Our application
engineering expertise and production know-how are based on decades of experience and supported by our network of 19
engineering centers and more than 450 engineers worldwide. Our innovation portfolio includes hybrid coolers for High
Tech, our advanced diffusion bonded heat exchanger “K°Bond” used in oil rigs, LNG, regasification facilities and CO2
stations, natural refrigerants, high pressure laser (HPL) for Green Tech and hydrogen leakage testing for Services. In
particular, our advanced manufacturing technologies, including 3D design and simulation, help to improve product
performance and reduce failure rates. In addition, computational fluid design and simulation is validated by our inhouse
labs and supports the development of our thermal design know-how and proprietary software, which enables us to design
solutions according to customer requirements.

Our differentiated technical solutions are complemented by our strong Service offering and proximity to our
customers, including the ability to provide local service to global customers based on our presence in 24 countries and the
ability to service other third-party brands. This is backed by performance agreements, aimed at maximizing customers’
return on investment and predictive maintenance to reduce operational downtime. We have a full-service portfolio spanning
start-up (safe delivery, installation and early start post installation support), inspection and maintenance (period checks),
repairs and overhauls, testing and monitoring (understanding condition of equipment), spare parts (designed to match the
original parts), upgrades and replacements (for outdated components) and consulting and training (leading to competency

**_High revenue visibility from strong Order Intake and Order Backlog development_**

Our Order Intake and Order Backlog provide us with high revenue visibility, and we believe the strong
development in our Order Intake and Order Backlog will support our future performance and continued growth. From 2021
to 2023, Order Intake increased at a CAGR of approximately 24%, from €1,099 million in the year ended December 31,
2021, to €1,698 million in the year ended December 31, 2023 and Order Backlog increased from €615 million as of
December 31, 2021 to €1,103 million as of December 31, 2023. Over the same period, our revenue increased from €931.7
million in the year ended December 31, 2021, to €1,347.9 million in the year ended December 31, 2023, resulting in a
consistent ratio of Order Intake to revenue of more than 1.0x (“book-to-bill ratio”) across the periods. Moreover, for the
twelve months ended March 31, 2024, our book-to-bill-ratio amounted to 1.1x. Revenue visibility is further enhanced by
the fact that, historically, a majority of our Order Intake in any given year was converted into revenue in the same fiscal
year or the next succeeding year. The portion of our Order Intake in the years ended December 31, 2021, 2022 and 2023
that was or is planned to be converted into revenue in the same year or the next succeeding year represented 51% and 54%
of our revenue for the years ended December 31, 2022, and 2023 as well as 62% of our budgeted revenue for the year
ending December 31, 2024. We believe that our high revenue visibility also helps drive our profitability as it allows for
improved management of customer order fulfilment, efficient operations planning and hence limits impacts under
absorption.

Our diversified presence across geographic regions and vertical markets enables us to benefit from increasing
demand in specific regions and vertical markets without being overly dependent on any single region or vertical market.
Order Intake for the year ended December 31, 2023, included €860 million in KTS, €388 million in RT, €258 million in
PHE and €210 million in MCS, driven to a significant extent by strong growth in KTS.

For the twelve months ended March 31, 2024, Order Intake was led by High Tech, followed by Conventional and
with Green Tech and Service broadly equal. Americas and EMEA dominated the regions and APAC has been steadily
growing.

The increase in Order Intake has been driven primarily by high demand for data center applications (particularly
in the United States due to hyperscalers) and HVAC applications (driven by catch-up in China). The growth has also been
attributable to large projects, including a carbon capture project in North America (approximately U.S. $118 million in
contract value) and an Oil & Gas project in Brazil (approximately U.S. $62 million in contract value).

**_Consistent and sustained progress in implementation of operational excellence plan will further enhance profitability_**
**_development_**

We have a strong track record of successfully implementing operational excellence measures across our
businesses to enhance profitability. These include initiatives to drive revenue growth, such as pricing adjustments and
production capacity realignments to increase and optimize production capacity to grow with our customers. To strengthen
our position, we are also refocusing our innovation pipeline to consistently introduce new products on a global scale. They
also include measures focused on our cost position, such as numerous supply chain initiatives across our supply chain on
a global scale (with 74 identified measures completed within 2024), production capacity utilization measures (including
production re-organization) and evaluating product mix to identify and focus on most profitable products and customer
demand. In addition, beginning in 2022, we initiated a range of actions and measures to systematically improve our cash
position by focusing on working capital. These included, among others, regular forecasting and active monitoring of cash
management and cash conversion cycles, enhancements of enterprise resource planning systems to better track inventory
levels and reduce slow-moving materials as well as actively managing receivables through initiating standard customer
debt collection policies. As a result, we reduced trade working capital w/o retention from 12.1% of revenue for the year
ended December 31, 2021 to 1.1% of revenue for the year ended December 31, 2023. Over the same period, we managed
to increase our Free Cash Flow Conversion rate from 57.8% for the year ended December 31, 2021 to 61.5% for the year
ended December 31, 2023.

Over the last three years, we have set several measures to improve our operational efficiency (e.g. quality cost
improvements from inward quality review and improvements in internal processes) and commercial efficiency. Our
commercial efficiency focuses on the core areas (i) target selling (e.g. focus on vertical markets), (ii) process simplification
(e.g. sales order review) and (iii) digitalization. The chart below illustrates the impact of the above mentioned measures on

**_Proven leadership team with track record of transformation, growth, and value creation_**

Bevan, our Chief Financial Officer, each of whom joined the Group in 2022 and have more than 30 years of experience in
various management and executive management positions at leading global companies. Our leadership team includes

our long-term objective of delivering sustainable growth.

**Our Strategy**

We started our journey to create consistency in performance, profitability and a platform for growth in 2021 with
the High Five strategic program. This set out five focus areas to concentrate on to build a better business. These five areas
comprise: (1) Grow High Tech, (2) Grow Green Tech, (3) More Service, (4) Grow APAC & Americas and (5) More
Digitalization.

**_Focus on growth in High Tech and Green Tech markets_**

We aim to utilize our strong technological capabilities and innovative solutions to capture the growing demand
from customers in the High Tech and Green Tech markets, such as, Data Centers, HVAC, Carbon Capture Storage,
Renewable Energy and LNG. These vertical markets are characterized by high growth potential, complex requirements,
and stringent quality standards, which create attractive opportunities for us as a reliable and flexible partner. We plan to
expand our presence in these vertical markets by developing new solutions and applications, enhancing our customer
relationships, and pursuing selective acquisitions that complement our portfolio and geographic footprint.

**_Continue to grow our Service business_**

We intend to leverage our large installed product and customer base to continue to grow our Service business. For
example, we are focused on improving the organizational setup of our Service business across our product groups by
establishing dedicated service responsibilities and pooling service skills across product groups in certain regions and
increasing transparency. In KTS, we are considering strategic cooperations with specialist service providers to drive our
service business coverage and support our strategic objectives to benefit from robust growth in our strategic pillars and
vertical markets. This way we can utilize our product and engineering knowledge with a technical service partner who has
a strong market foothold that we can leverage.

**_Increase market share in the Americas and APAC region_**

We intend to continue to focus on the growth of our global platform and improve our market share in the Americas
and APAC regions through investment in production capacity and local dedicated sales teams. For example, we aim to
leverage our scale to further penetrate existing markets and strengthen our positions in China, India and the United States,
by capitalizing on strong and growing demand in our Data Center business in the Americas as well as in our HVAC and
Carbon Capture Storage solutions in Green Tech market applications. In RT and MCS, we intend to increase production
capacity and optimize production locations in the United States as well as build up a dedicated sales team for the
Transportation market. In the APAC region, we plan to continue to focus on product localization in the region and investing
in our sales and distribution networks.

**_Continue to reduce complexity and focus on digitalization to drive operational excellence_**

We continue to pursue our strategy of operational excellence by reducing complexity and enhancing digitalization
across our functional and business areas. This means focusing on activities like “80/20” where we seek to improve the
profitability of our product range, optimizing SAP in key locations, reducing process complexity through digital tools such
as Tagetik (our financial consolidation tool) and SAP (our core ERP). We also continue to deploy tools such as Power BI
to help us, for example, manage inventory reduction and improve our supply chain management globally. In addition, we
are exploring the use of Artificial Intelligence to support our sales and engineering processes, along with implementing
SAP CPQ and LO-VC. We continue to focus on the optimization of our operational footprint, especially in EMEA region,
and ensure we are manufacturing the right products in the right place for cost optimization and customer requirements.

**Trading Update**

Based on preliminary management accounts, we estimate that revenue for the months April and May 2024
amounted to approximately €258.8 million (compared to approximately €217.6 million for April and May 2023) and
EBITDA for the months April and May 2024 amounted to approximately €32.1 million (compared to approximately €21.9
million for April and May 2023). The increase in revenue was primarily driven by a strong development in the EMEA,
offsetting slightly lower revenue in the Americas and APAC. EBITDA increased at a higher rate than revenue driven by
favorable changes in product mix. The result of April and May 2024 includes expenses of €4.1 million for restructuring in
Germany (PHE).

**Recent Developments**

In April 2024, we decided to reduce production capacity at two of our German production facilities in PHE. The
capacity reduction reflects lower demand for heat pumps in Europe and, in particular, in Germany following a recent
decrease in energy prices as well as regulatory uncertainty. We expect that the capacity reduction will impact approximately
150 employees and have booked a provision in a mid-single digit million amount to cover expected costs and expenses.

**Outlook**

_The following discussion has been prepared by, and is the responsibility of, the management of the Issuer and is_
_solely based on a large number of estimates and projections, including, among others, with respect to economic conditions,_
_realizable sales prices and market growth projections, all of which are inherently uncertain, and operating data used by_
_management. There can be no assurance that these estimates will be realized or that actual results will not be higher or_
_lower than estimated. The following discussion is further based on a number of assumptions, including, among others, no_
_significant deterioration of economic and political conditions in the markets in which the Group operates, no significant_
_disruptions in the supply chain relevant to the business of the Group, no material price increases of raw materials, no_
_unexpected changes in governmental regulations worldwide, no significant slippage in customer purchase order_
_placement, no significant further softening in European heat pump market, continued growth in our Americas and APAC_
_regions and consistency of foreign exchange rates._

Based on our budget for 2024, we estimate an increase in order intake to approximately €1,750 million and an
increase in revenue to approximately €1,600 million. We estimate Normalized EBITDA for 2024 to significantly exceed
the prior year. Our budgeted revenue increase is broad-based, with all segments contributing, and is based on the high order
backlog, and expected order intake. We anticipate strongest revenue growth in KTS, followed by RT, both driven by strong
Data Centre grow, and we estimate moderate growth in MCS and PHE.

**The Transactions**

The Issuer estimates that the gross proceeds from the Offering will be €425.0 million. The Issuer intends to use
the gross proceeds from the Offering (i) to redeem the Existing Notes in full, (ii) for general corporate purposes, including
expenses expected to be incurred in connection with a production footprint alignment program in the EMEA region as well
as certain capital expenditures and (iii) to pay costs, fees and expenses related to the Transactions (as defined below).

In addition, Mangrove LuxCo IV S.à r.l. will repay all amounts outstanding under and subsequently cancel the
Existing L/G Facility Agreement and the Existing RCF Facility Agreement and enter into the Super Senior Facilities
Agreement on or about the Issue Date. The Offering, the use of proceeds therefrom, the repayment of all amounts
outstanding under and subsequent cancellation of the Existing L/G Facility Agreement and the Existing RCF Facility
Agreement and the entry into the Super Senior Facilities Agreement are collectively referred to herein as the
“Transactions.”

**Sponsor**

Founded in 1997 and owned by its partners, Triton is a leading European mid-market sector-specialist investor.
Triton focuses on investing in businesses that provide mission critical goods and services in its three core sectors of
Business Services, Industrial Tech, and Healthcare. Triton has over 200 investment professionals across eleven offices and
invests through three complementary “All Weather” strategies: Mid-Market Private Equity, Smaller Mid-Cap Private
Equity, and Opportunistic Credit.

required by law. Subject to certain exceptions and limitations, if the Issuer or the
applicable Guarantor or paying agent is required by law to withhold or deduct such
taxes with respect to a payment on any Note or Guarantee, the Issuer or the
applicable Guarantor will pay the Additional Amounts necessary so that the net
amount received after such withholding or deduction is not less than the amount
that would have been received in the absence of the withholding or deduction. See
“Description of the Notes—Withholding Taxes.”

If certain changes in the law of any relevant taxing jurisdiction become effective
after the issuance of the Notes that would impose withholding taxes on the
payments on the Notes and would require the Issuer or any Guarantor to pay
Additional Amounts (as described in “Description of the Notes—Withholding
_Taxes”), the Issuer may redeem the Notes in whole, but not in part, at any time, at_
a redemption price of 100% of the principal amount, plus accrued and unpaid
interest, if any, and Additional Amounts, if any, to the date of redemption. See
“Description of the Notes—Redemption for Taxation Reasons.”


**Tender Offers................................ In connection with certain tender offers for the Notes, if holders of not less than**

90% in aggregate principal amount of the applicable outstanding Notes validly
tender and do not withdraw such Notes in such tender offer and the Issuer, or any
third party making such a tender offer in lieu of the Issuer, purchases, all of the
Notes validly tendered and not withdrawn by such holders, the Issuer or such third
party will have the right to redeem the Notes that remain outstanding in whole, but
not in part, following such purchase at a price equal to the price offered to each
other holder of Notes. See “Description of the Notes—Optional Redemption.”

**Change of Control ........................ If the Issuer experiences a Change of Control, the holders of the Notes will have**

the right to require the Issuer to offer to repurchase the Notes at a purchase price
equal to 101% of their principal amount, plus accrued and unpaid interest and
Additional Amounts, if any, to the date of repurchase. See “Description of the
_Notes—Change of Control.”_

generally be required to include such OID in gross income (as ordinary income) as
it accrues (on a constant yield to maturity basis) for US federal income tax purposes
in advance of the receipt of cash payments to which such OID is attributable and
regardless of the holder’s regular method of accounting for US federal income tax
purposes. See “Taxation—Certain US Federal Income Tax Considerations—

                 - create or permit to exist certain liens;

                 - impose restrictions on the ability of the restricted subsidiaries to pay dividends;

                 - transfer or sell certain assets;

                 - merge or consolidate with other entities;

                 - engage in certain transactions with affiliates; and

Certain of the covenants will be suspended if and for as long as we achieve

(a) Related to the closure of production facilities in Wingles, France, in December 2023. The adjustment mainly includes expenses of €8.4 million
for severance, €1.5 million in consulting and legal costs in 2023. In December 2022, we recorded an inventory allowance of €3.1 million.

(b) In the first quarter of 2022, KTS was carved out to a separate subgroup of legal entities in connection with a potential sale of KTS’ business.
The adjustment relates to corresponding consulting, legal and stamp-duty costs (€5.4 million in 2021 and €3.2 million in 2022). As part of this
strategic realignment, inventories and certain assets were impaired (€0.2 million in each of 2021 and 2022) and the decision was made to close
the production for MCS and KTS in Pune, India, which led to severance costs. The adjustment also includes €0.2 million of personnel expenses
in 2022 related to the transition period from the former CEO and current CEO.

(c) Relates to severance payments for redundancies in our sales team in connection with key customer prioritization initiatives and the
digitalization of order processing.

(d) Relate to various measures and initiatives agreed in connection with the Group’s refinancing in 2019, including reorganization and downsizing
of KTS in Spain, the exit of MCS production in India and capacity adjustments for KTS in France.

(e) Relate to initiatives in MCS, RT and PHE in the United States, including changes to the product portfolio in MCS, a shift in product focus to
dry coolers for data center and HVAC applications in RT as well as the relocation of PHE business operations to Knoxville, Tennessee. In
2022, the adjustment mainly relates to inventory write-offs (€7.4 million).

(f) Relates primarily to the sale of the Dry Cooling Systems (DCS) business. DCS Heller was sold in December 2020, followed by the sale of the
cooling tower service business in October 2021 and the sale of certain assets of the air-cooled condenser business (DCS-ACC) in March 2022.
The remaining DCS-ACC business was wound down. In 2021, the adjustment relates to other operating income from the reversal of provisions
related to the winding down of the DCS-ACC business (€17.7 million). In 2022, the adjustment includes €0.4 million for severance payments
and €0.2 million for consulting costs related to the winding down of the DCS-ACC business. In January 2022, we divested the ENEXIO Water
Business, and the associated consulting expenses and impairment of assets held for sale due to the lower than anticipated selling price (€1.6
million) were normalized in 2021. In 2022, the adjustment also includes a warranty provision of €1.4 million for a potential claim in Germany.

(g) The adjustment comprises severance payments, impairment of inventories, consulting expenses and provision releases in relation to initiatives
across various product groups and sales entities.

(h) Relates to the litigation proceedings with former bondholders of the Galapagos group. Legal costs amounted to €11.5 million in 2023, of
which €3.6 million had already accrued prior to 2021. Two settlement payments, in each case in the amount of €2.5 million, were made in
December 2023 and in March 2024.

(i) Relates to legal and notary fees of €2.0 million in connection with the Group’s refinancing in 2019, with the adjustment made in 2021 as well
as consulting expenses related to the extension of the revolving credit facility and associated consulting services in November 2023 and
January 2024.

(j) Relates the sale of the building and land in France, which resulted in a gain of €1.5 million in 2021 and €4.8 million in 2023 (with a purchase
price of €8.0 million). The purchase receivable was factored and a corresponding liability was recognized. In 2021, the adjustment includes
the effect from the sale of non-current assets in Sarstedt, Germany (€0.1 million).

(k) Relates to a GEA legacy project from 2008. ENEXIO contracted a construction of a dry cooling solution for a power station in Lephalale,
South Africa. As part of the purchase price allocation, we recognized a provision of €49.3 million for the estimated risks associated with the
project as well as a corresponding receivable from a reimbursement right (70% of the respective provision, €35.5 million). Following the
decision of a final court in 2021, the remaining provision of €18.3 million was released.

(m) Mainly relates to impairment charges related to the closure of production facilities in Wingles, France, in December 2023.

**RISK FACTORS**

_An investment in the Notes to be issued in the Offering involves a high degree of risk. In addition to the other_
_information contained in this Offering Memorandum, you should carefully consider the following risk factors before_
_purchasing the Notes. If any of the events described in the risk factors below occur, our results of operations and financial_
_condition could be materially and adversely affected and accordingly the value of the Notes, which in turn could adversely_
_affect the Issuer’s ability to repay the Notes. The risks described herein are not the only risks we face. Additional risks and_
_uncertainties not currently known to us or that we currently deem to be immaterial may also materially adversely affect_
_our business, financial condition, results of operations or prospects and, thus our ability to fulfil our obligations under the_
_Notes and the Guarantees. In any such case, we may not be able to pay interest or principal on Notes when due and you_
_may lose all or part of your investment in the Notes._

_This Offering Memorandum also contains forward-looking statements that involve risks and uncertainties. Our_
_actual results may differ materially from those anticipated in these forward-looking statements as a result of various_
_factors, including the risks described in this section and elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum. See “Forward-Looking_
_Statements.”_

**Risks Related to our Business and Industry**

**_We are exposed to risks associated with changes in global economic conditions and economic developments in the_**
**_countries in which we operate_**

As a global manufacturer of heat exchangers and other cooling & heating products, we are exposed to risks
associated with fluctuations in the global economy. A slowdown in the global economy and elevated levels of private and
public debt in various countries may cause demand to decline in our key markets. The situation may be exacerbated by
protectionist tendencies, persistently elevated levels of inflation, uncertainties regarding future monetary policy, armed
conflicts that remain unresolved and related migration trends, as well as the spread of infectious diseases. Some recent
developments which have significantly impacted global macroeconomic conditions include the ongoing military conflicts
in the Ukraine (the “Russia-Ukraine Conflict”), the conflict in Gaza and attacks by Houthi rebels on merchant shipping
vessels in the southern Red Sea region as well as the COVID-19 pandemic. See also “—The COVID-19 pandemic had an
_adverse effect on our revenue and profitability, cash flow and liquidity, growth plans and prospects, and any future_
_pandemic or other public health incidents could also have similar effects” and “—The Russia-Ukraine Conflict and the_
_sanctions imposed by numerous countries and multinational entities in response, as well as countermeasures by Russia,_
_have had, and may continue to have, adverse impacts on the global economy, the global capital markets, supply chains,_
_energy prices and supplies, any of which could negatively impact our operations.”_

The Russia-Ukraine Conflict and the sanctions and export control measures instituted by the European Union (the
“EU”), the United Kingdom, the United States, Canada and Japan, among others, contributed to increased inflationary
pressures (including increased prices for oil and natural gas), gas supply shortages, supply chain disruptions, market
volatility and economic uncertainty, particularly in Europe. The inflationary environment and related intensified general
price increases (in particular due to rising energy costs), combined with an increase in interest rates, resulted in a slowdown
of customer demand and thus would have had an impact on our growth. While we may increase product prices in order to
mitigate the impact of inflation and increases in energy costs, competitive pressures may constrain our ability to do so and
we may remain subject to market risks with respect to inflationary pressures. Furthermore, increasing inflation has put
upward pressure on the cost of raw materials (see “—Increases in raw material prices, energy costs and prices for input
_materials and intermediate products may result in higher manufacturing or purchasing costs and lower margins, and we_
_may not be able to pass such increased costs on to our customers fully or at all”) and other operating costs, and our ability_
to raise prices to counteract increased raw materials prices and other operating costs (such as labor costs) may be limited,
which may reduce our operating profit to the extent where we are not able to pass on related price increases to our
customers. In addition, our initiatives, in particular the enforcement of price adjustment clauses in our customer contracts,
to mitigate headwinds from inflation in our raw materials and other operating costs may not be sufficient to offset these
risks.

As part of the capital goods industry, we are also exposed to fluctuations in the overall investment climate. Among
other things, fluctuations in growth rates or forecasts of gross domestic product, interest rate environments and alterations
in government investment subsidies, can result in significant changes in demand for capital goods in the markets in which
we operate, potential cancellations of orders already booked or the reorganization of longer-term business relationships.
Therefore, our revenue and results of operations are influenced, and will continue to be influenced, by macroeconomic
trends and the general state and performance of the global economy. Moreover, uncertainty in connection with trade
tensions between the United States and China and further changes to the trade policy of the United States may have a
material adverse effect on the overall economies of EU countries and other markets in which we operate, including APAC
and MEA. The uncertain political development in the United States and potential restrictions and limitations impacting
international trade may have a negative impact on the export economy in general, and on our results of operations in
particular. If individual countries take increasingly protectionist measures to improve their competitiveness in the global

23


-----

market and other countries introduce countermeasures, this may result in market access barriers, such as higher import
duties or more complicated certification processes in order to reduce imports.

Any of the aforementioned factors could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial position, results
of operations and ability to fulfill our obligations under the Notes and the Guarantees.

**_The COVID-19 pandemic had an adverse effect on our revenue and profitability, cash flow and liquidity, growth plans_**
**_and prospects, and any future pandemic or other public health incidents could also have similar effects._**

The COVID-19 pandemic created significant macroeconomic uncertainty, volatility and disruption and had
serious adverse economic consequences, including declining economic growth, numerous business insolvencies and
significantly increased unemployment. As a result of the COVID-19 pandemic and measures imposed to contain the
outbreak of the disease, particularly in Europe and the United States, our business operations experienced delays and
disruptions, including, but not limited to, supply chain interruptions and delays in delivery of products or projects to some
of our customers.

Potential impacts of any further outbreaks of disease or other public health threats in the future include but are not
limited to: (i) staffing shortages if portions of our workforce are unable to work effectively due to illness, quarantines,
government actions, facility closures, or other restrictions; (ii) short- or long-term disruptions in our supply chain and our
ability to deliver products to our customers; (iii) deterioration in the markets that we or our customers operate in, which
may result in lower sales or a lack in the ability of our customers to pay us; and (iv) significant volatility or negative
pressure in the financial markets, which could adversely affect our access to capital and/or financing. Any adverse effect
on our ability to access capital and/or secure financing could also have the effect of heightening many of the other risks
described in this “Risk Factors” section and have a material adverse effect on our business, financial position, results of
operations and ability to fulfill our obligations under the Notes and the Guarantees.

**_The Russia-Ukraine Conflict and the sanctions imposed by numerous countries and multinational entities in response,_**
**_as well as countermeasures by Russia, have had, and may continue to have, adverse impacts on the global economy, the_**
**_global capital markets, supply chains, energy prices and supplies, any of which could negatively impact our operations._**

The Russia-Ukraine Conflict prompted the EU and numerous countries to impose sanctions on a range of Russian
and Belarusian state and corporate entities and individuals, including extensive trade embargoes, travel bans, asset freezes
and the exclusion of certain Russian and Belarusian banks from the global financial system, among other measures. In
response, Russia has sanctioned persons and entities within so-called “non-friendly” countries and terminated gas supply
contracts with several countries and entities in Europe. The unpredictable nature of the conflict means that further sanctions,
against Russia and Belarus (or Russian and Belarusian entities) and further retaliatory actions by Russia and Belarus against
the imposing countries, including the possible expropriation of assets owned by nationals of, or companies based in, such
sanctioning countries, including us, may be forthcoming.

While we have a subsidiary in Russia, sales in the region were ceased in January 2023 and the Russian subsidiary’s
operations were ringfenced for disposal in May 2023. A disposal process is currently being pursued. However, there can
be no assurance if and at which terms such disposal may be completed. Under Russian law, among other things, any
disposal is required to be made at a discount compared to a valuation prepared by an approved valuer and subject to
government approval. For the time being, the Russian entity operates under its own brand name and has established its own
supply chain. In addition, in October 2022, we ceased all trading with Belarus. In the year ended December 31, 2023,
Kelvion Mashimpeks LLC (our Russian subsidiary) accounted for 1.1% (€16.0 million) of our total revenue. However, our
business, financial condition and results of operations have been and could continue to be materially adversely affected by
the Russia-Ukraine Conflict in a number of ways. The Russia-Ukraine Conflict and the related sanctions have created
significant global economic uncertainty and have threatened to exacerbate pre-existing global economic challenges such
as those arising from the COVID-19 pandemic and its consequences, increasing inflation (including energy prices) and
slowing economic growth. The conflict and the related sanctions have also caused and may continue to cause volatility in
oil and natural gas prices and could potentially lead to shortages or further energy price increases of these resources. These
developments have caused and may continue to cause significant increases in energy prices which, in turn, impact our input
costs. In addition, the conflict has provoked a significant return home of Ukraine labour employed in different European
countries, creating labour availability tension in some industries, notably manufacturing and transportation.

If any of the foregoing risks were to materialize, our business, financial condition, results of operations and ability
to fulfil our obligations under the Notes and the Guarantees could be materially and adversely affected. Such risks may
also have the effect of heightening other risks, such as those relating to inflation, capital markets volatility and our ability
to access additional capital, any of which could materially and adversely affect our business, financial condition and results
of operations. We, our suppliers or our customers may be unable to obtain or maintain sufficient financing, including
working capital financing, and credit insurance.

24


-----

Our working capital requirements can vary, depending in part on the level, variability and timing of our customers’
production, and the payment terms with its customers and suppliers. Our liquidity could also be adversely impacted if our
suppliers were to suspend normal trade credit terms and require payment in advance or on delivery. If our available cash
flows from operating activities are not sufficient to fund our ongoing cash needs, we would be required to look to our cash
balances and availability for borrowings to satisfy those needs, as well as potential additional sources of capital, which
may not be available on satisfactory terms, in sufficient amount or at all. There can be no assurance that we, our suppliers
or our customers will continue to have such ability. This may increase the risk that we cannot produce our products or will
have to pay higher prices for our inputs. These higher prices may not be recovered in our selling prices.

**_Certain industries and end-markets we serve are cyclical and our results may be adversely impacted by such cycles and_**
**_negative developments._**

We serve a variety of end-markets, including, Data Centers, HVAC, Power & Energy, Oil & Gas, and Heavy &
Light Industry. Demand for our products and services is dependent on the levels of investment in these end-markets and
industries, which, in turn, is affected by a number of macroeconomic factors, such as economic growth and GDP, levels
of capital investments, inflation and interest rates as well as the availability of credit and financing. These industries and
end-markets are also characterized by different trends and market drivers. A negative development in any of our primary
end-markets, particularly in Data Centers, could have a negative impact on our business, financial position and results of
operations. Any of the aforementioned factors could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial position,
results of operations and ability to fulfill our obligations under the Notes and the Guarantees.

**_Changes in government spending and legislative actions and initiatives relating to renewable energy and electric power_**
**_may adversely affect demand for our products and services._**

Demand for our products and services may be negatively impacted by changes in government spending and
renewable energy policies and initiatives. Many countries in which we operate have, or are considering, mandates that
require specified percentages of power to be generated from renewable sources. In addition, some countries are considering
limits on both the development of new nuclear power plants and on the continued operation of existing nuclear power
plants following environmental incidents. Subsidies of renewable energy sources could result in reduced investment in
conventional power plants, which tend to be more heat exchanger-intensive than many of the renewable energy
technologies currently deployed. Furthermore, the continuing political discussion relating to the future energy mix (among
other jurisdictions, in Germany) could lead to delayed investment decisions or to reduced investments by our customers,
in particular in the oil and gas and energy sectors, which could have a material adverse effect on our results of operations.
For example, in the year ended December 31, 2023, 11.6% of our revenue resulted from sales to customers in the Power &
Energy and, therefore, policy changes in connection with transitions to renewable energy sources could have an adverse
impact on our revenue and results of operations. In addition, demand for products in PHE is affected by demand for heat
pumps and has been negatively impacted by regulatory uncertainty in relation to the phase out of conventional heating
systems since the end of 2023. Any further changes in government spending and renewable energy policies and initiatives
could have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations and ability to fulfill our obligations under the
Notes and the Guarantees if they result in reduced demand for our products and services in traditional coal, nuclear and
gas-fired power plants.

**_We may be unable to successfully implement ongoing and future improvement programs and may incur additional costs_**
**_in connection with such programs._**

We have in the past implemented, and intend to continue to implement, improvement programs aimed at aligning
our production capacities with the demand in the relevant end-markets by closing certain manufacturing sites and
transferring the manufacturing to other sites. For example, we stopped production at our site in Wingles, France, which
had been loss-making for a number of years, in 2023, as the market of heat pumps, which experienced a boom as a result
of the energy crisis at the beginning of 2022, has experienced decline. In connection with the closure of the production in
Wingles, France, we agreed a redundancy plan and incurred other closure costs in an aggregate amount of €14.0 million in
the years ended December 31, 2022 and December 31, 2023. We are also evaluating certain other footprint alignment
programs in the EMEA region, e.g. in Western Europe, which could result in the closure of additional sites and redundancy
plans. In particular, we are in the final stage of assessing a footprint reduction for one site in Western Europe and expect
to conclude this assessment in the near future. While no definitive decision has been taken as of the date of this Offering
Memorandum, we currently estimate that the closure costs (including costs relating to the termination of leases and
relocation costs) as well as redundancy costs will amount to approximately €25 million to €30 million and the total costs
will amount to approximately €52 million, which will be – directly or indirectly – funded from the proceeds of the offering
of the Notes. See “Use of Proceeds.” However, our actual costs may be significantly higher due to a number of factors,
some of which are beyond our control. In addition, there can be no assurance that we will be able to implement the planned
restructuring measures on time, for example due to the need to find an agreement with employee representatives or
landlords.

25


-----

In addition, even if we are able to implement our footprint alignment program as planned, there can be no
assurance that such measures result in the efficiency gains or cost savings currently anticipated by us. We may, for example,
experience delays in ramping up production at our new sites or such sites may not be as efficient as anticipated due to
factors such as availability and skills of the local workforce and the need to use new suppliers. Furthermore, a reduction of
our labor force at the affected sites could adversely affect our business, e.g., through strikes, lawsuits, business interruptions
or reputational damage.

The materialization of any of the risks described above could have a material and adverse effect on our business,
financial condition and results of operations, which could in turn adversely affect our ability to fulfill our obligations under
the Notes and the Guarantees.

**_We face country risks in the regions in which we operate, including in emerging markets._**

We are active in numerous countries worldwide. We have a global production footprint, with production sites in
more than 20 countries around the world, including Germany, the United States, the United Kingdom, the Netherlands,
France, Spain, Poland, the Czech Republic, Qatar, South Africa, India and China, as well as service and engineering hubs
in additional jurisdictions. Our operations in any of the countries in which we operate, and particularly in emerging markets,
are subject to the following risks:

      - changes in the rate of economic growth;

      - unsettled political or economic conditions;

      - expropriation or other governmental actions;

      - war and social unrest;

      - terrorist attacks or other armed conflicts;

      - bribery and corruption;

      - national and regional labor strikes;

      - confiscatory taxation or other adverse tax policies,

      - deprivation of contract rights;

      - trade regulations affecting production, pricing and marketing of products;

      - reduced protection of intellectual property rights;

      - restrictions on the repatriation of income or capital;

      - exchange controls;

      - inflation;

      - currency fluctuations and devaluation;

      - the effect of global environmental, health and safety issues on economic conditions;

      - market opportunities and operating restrictions; and

      - changes in financial policy and availability of credit.

Moreover, financial and political turmoil in an emerging market may adversely affect the economic conditions of
other emerging markets or countries in the region, as investors may move their money to more stable, developed markets.

The uncertainty over whether governments will implement changes in policies or regulations affecting these or
other factors in the future may contribute to economic uncertainty in such markets. Furthermore, the performance of
emerging market economies has historically been affected by the political climate in these countries. Political crises have
had a negative impact on the confidence of investors and the public in general, and they have adversely affected the
economic development of these countries.

26


-----

In addition, we may conduct business with customers or service or agency partners in countries that are subject to
export control regulations, trade embargoes, economic sanctions or other forms of trade restrictions imposed by the United
States, the European Union or other countries or multilateral organizations. It is possible that any expansion into or within
sanctioned countries could adversely impact our ability to gain or retain investors, customers or suppliers or result in
reputational harm or other adverse consequences. Further, should legal developments require us to modify or terminate our
activities in such countries, we may be exposed to customer complaints or contractual remedies or other adverse
consequences. Any of the aforementioned factors could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial position,
results of operations and ability to fulfill our obligations under the Notes and the Guarantees.

**_We generate a significant amount of Order Intake and revenue from a limited number of large customers._**

Although our customer base is large, we depend on certain large customers for a significant proportion of our
revenue and Order Intake. For example, in the year ended December 31, 2023, our ten largest customers generated
approximately 46% of our Order Intake (year ended December 31, 2022: approximately 32%), with the largest customer
generating approximately 25% of Order Intake in the year ended December 31, 2023 (year ended December 31, 2022:
approximately 20%). Furthermore, our largest customer generated approximately 18% of our revenue in the year ended
December 31, 2023.

The loss of all or a substantial portion of our business with any of our largest customers, and in particular our
largest customer, could have a material adverse impact on our business, financial condition and results of operations. We
may make fewer business with these customers for a number of reasons, including but not limited to:

      - reduced demand for our customers’ products or services, including, in particular, as a result of cyclical
downturns that disproportionately affect our customers’ industries;

      - failure to deliver products or solutions that meet our customers’ specifications and our contractual
obligations;

      - technological changes;

      - reduced or delayed customer requirements; or

      - bankruptcy or insolvency of a customer.

Any significant change in the revenue or Order Intake we generate from our largest customers could have a
material adverse effect on our business, financial position, results of operations and ability to fulfill our obligations under
the Notes and the Guarantees.

**_We may not be able to realize revenues represented by our Order Intake and Order Backlog._**

We present Order Intake and Order Backlog as operational key performance indicators in this Offering
Memorandum. Order Intake refers to binding customer contracts and purchase orders concluded and received in the
respective reporting period at the respective price, while Order Backlog refers to the binding customer contracts and
purchase orders concluded and the portion of the associated transaction price for which the amount of sales has not yet
been recognized in accordance with IFRS. See “Summary Financial and Other Information—Order Intake and Order
_Backlog”. There can be no assurance that these contractual terms will remain unchanged, or that the order intake or order_
backlog will result in an actual recognition of revenue within the period initially anticipated, if at all. We may experience
variances in the realization of estimated Order Intake and Order Backlog because of delays or cancellations, scope
adjustments, external market factors and economic factors beyond our control. In addition, many of our contracts grant
the customer the right to change, delay or cancel purchase orders at any time after they have been placed against the
payment of proven damages suffered by us as a result of such change, delay or cancellation or, in certain cases, against
payment of fixed contractual penalties. If the estimated Order Intake or Order Backlog fails to materialize as anticipated,
this could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations and ability to fulfill
our obligations under the Notes and the Guarantees. Our Order Intake and Order Backlog does not provide a precise
indication of the time period over which we are contractually entitled to receive such revenue and there is no assurance
that such revenues will be actually received within the anticipated timeframes or at all. Our Order Intake and Order
Backlog are computed based on facts known and assumptions deemed appropriate at the computation date.

Our definition of Order Intake and Order Backlog may not necessarily be the same as that used by other
companies engaged in activities similar to us. As a result, the amount of Order Intake and Order Backlog reported by us
may not be comparable to similar metrics reported by such other companies.

27


-----

**_We are exposed to intense competition and our competitive position may deteriorate._**

The market for heat exchangers in which we operate is highly competitive. We compete with both large
international market participants and numerous smaller regional and local suppliers that vary depending on the region.
See also “Business—Competition.” Our competitive position also varies in the individual product sub-markets (such as
for different types of heat exchangers and cooling towers) and regions. If we are unable to continue to provide our
services to existing clients, to develop new service portfolios, to attract new clients, to respond to client trends, to increase
our operating efficiency and to reduce our operating and overhead costs, we may not be able to successfully compete in
the relevant markets. Furthermore, in many of the markets in which we compete, customers place a strong emphasis on
local manufacturing capabilities, and we may be unable to quickly expand our manufacturing capacities as required in
certain fast growing segments, and thus lose market share. Any expansion undertaken in markets which are generally
characterized by lower costs of production may lead to more intense competition in those markets. Should we fail to
maintain our market position in the relevant markets or build-up a meaningful market position in new markets, this could
have a material adverse effect on our business, financial position, results of operations and ability to fulfill our obligations
under the Notes and the Guarantees.

Any development in markets in which we operate is determined to a certain extent by technological changes
and innovation and our strategy is therefore particularly directed towards being perceived as a technology leader in the
respective markets. This requires continuous investments in research and development. Despite our efforts and
investments, existing or new competitors may develop their products and technologies further or create alternative ones
that are more attractively priced, offer higher quality or a broader functionality or are more appealing than our products
for other reasons. Furthermore, our research and development efforts may be insufficient to ensure that we are able to
