meet our customers’ demands on time, or we may be unable to meet product specifications due to a lack of research and
development expertise. Additionally, our existing competitors and new entrants may have greater operational, financial
and other resources or may otherwise be better positioned to develop new products and compete for opportunities and,
as a result, our business may be less successful. If new or more advanced products can be offered at more attractive
prices, or if such products are more attractive than our products for other reasons, such as greater functionality, demand
for our products could fall, which could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial position, results of
operations and ability to fulfill our obligations under the Notes and the Guarantees.

Some of our customers and end customers are facing increasing pricing pressure and could be affected by costcutting pressures. If our competitors are able to offer products at prices significantly below ours or if new low-cost
competitors enter the market, we may be unable to reduce our costs or offer similar pricing, which could have a material
adverse effect on our business, financial position, results of operations and ability to fulfill our obligations under the
Notes and the Guarantees.

**_We depend on the ability to maintain the quality of our products and processes and to develop and manufacture new_**
**_products in a timely manner in line with market trends and the pace of technological development._**

Our success depends on our ability to recognize market trends and technological changes and to develop new
and improved products and product applications to the market in a timely manner. We invest in technology, new
materials and innovation which we believe will be critical to our long-term growth and we must continually adapt our
expertise in response to changes in megatrends, emerging technological innovations, industry standards and customer
requirements or preferences. In addition, digitalization is progressing rapidly and has already transformed certain
sectors. The pace of implementation and adaptation represents an important success factor in this regard and, therefore,
also a risk. For customers, one of the determining factors in purchasing our components and systems is the quality of
our products and manufacturing processes. Our products are often mission-critical for the applications in which they are
used. Given that products that have already been introduced in the market are subject to risks related to the product quality
expected by customers, a decrease in the actual and perceived quality of these products and processes could damage our
image and reputation, as well as those of our products.

There can be no assurance that (i) we will be successful in developing new products or solutions or in bringing
them to market in a timely manner, (ii) products or technologies developed by competitors will not render our offerings
less competitive, (iii) customers will not substitute our products with those of competitors or alternate technologies,
(iv) we will be able to anticipate our customers’ needs and provide products to meet those needs or (v) we will be able
to adjust our cost structure in the event of contraction of demand. Should we fail to develop appropriate strategies as a
response to these or similar market trends or not be able to enhance existing products, develop new products or keep
pace with developing technology, growth opportunities or existing customers could be lost. Furthermore, if we devote
resources to the development of new technologies and products that fail to be accepted in the market or that fail to be
commercially viable, all or part of these research and development expenses may be lost and our business may suffer.

The materialization of any of the risks described above could have a material adverse effect on our business,
financial position, results of operations and ability to fulfill our obligations under the Notes and the Guarantees.

28


-----

**_Increases in raw material prices, energy costs and prices for input materials and intermediate products may result in_**
**_higher manufacturing or purchasing costs and lower margins, and we may not be able to pass on such increased costs_**
**_to our customers fully or at all._**

We are exposed to risks relating to the availability, quality and cost of raw materials, energy and intermediate
products. In particular, we require various metals such as steel, copper, aluminum and titanium. The market price and
availability of these products that we use for our operations can fluctuate sharply depending on the market situation. For
example, the COVID-19 pandemic resulted in significant fluctuations in the price of copper on the London Metal
Exchange, with a decrease of up to 20% around the outbreak and spread of the pandemic followed by significant price
increases in the subsequent two years. A shortage of raw materials and energy sources could also arise from decreases
in extraction and production due to natural disasters or political instability or unrest in extracting and producing
countries. In addition, since many of these materials, in particular copper and aluminum, are usually purchased in U.S.
dollars, a stronger U.S. dollar could represent a further price risk for companies that are outside of the United States and
whose operating currency is not tied to the U.S. dollar. In addition, certain countries may impose anti-dumping policies
on imports of specific materials from third countries, thereby rendering the cost effectiveness no longer competitive.

Currently, we do not use commodity derivatives as hedging instruments against price fluctuations of raw materials.
Although we have entered into longer-term supply agreements with various suppliers in order to reduce commodity price
risk, we are not fully shielded from the risk of rising commodity prices. In addition, we have experienced in the past, and
may continue to experience in the future, material cost increases at the time of purchasing the necessary raw materials for
a project as compared to the time when we negotiated the contract for the project. As we may not be able to pass price
increases on to our customers, such price increases could reduce our profit margins. However, if we are able to pass price
increases on to our customers, this could reduce our revenue and have a material adverse effect on our business, financial
position, results of operations and ability to fulfill our obligations under the Notes and the Guarantees. In addition, supply
interruptions of production materials, resulting from shortages, labor strikes, supplier insolvencies or other factors could
have a negative effect as well.

In addition, we also rely on a variety of intermediate products produced by other manufacturers that are integrated
into the final products that we provide to the end-customer. These include finished mechanical components such as fans
and chiller units. Should our suppliers raise prices, this will result in higher costs. In addition, if we experience limited
availability or quality issues with our suppliers of these intermediate products, we could be forced to seek alternative
suppliers that may charge higher prices and cause delays in delivering products to customers. These delays and higher costs
may also have a negative effect on our business, financial position, results of operations and ability to fulfill our obligations
under the Notes and the Guarantees.

**_We may be required to perform portions of our projects locally or source materials from certain countries._**

Some countries in which we operate have regulations requiring, and some customers in foreign countries prefer, a
minimum degree of local content be included in projects in, or products destined for installation in, their country. For
example, certain customers require that we do not use products manufactured in a certain country (e.g., China or India),
source materials from local suppliers or that manufacturing take place at specific facilities (e.g., in Europe). These
requirements and preferences may require us to outsource significant functions to manufacturers in foreign countries or
otherwise to establish manufacturing capabilities in foreign countries, or to source raw materials, product parts or semifinished goods from countries that are not those from which we would normally source (e.g., due to lower manufacturing
costs) if such restrictions were not in place. These requirements may negatively impact our profit margins and result in
additional complexity and costs with respect to project management, which, in, turn, could have a material adverse effect
on our business, financial position, results of operations and ability to fulfill our obligations under the Notes and the
Guarantees.

**_A disruption in our supply or delivery chain could cause us or one or more of our suppliers or customers to halt_**
**_production._**

As a global manufacturer of heat exchangers and other cooling & heating products, we rely on global supply
chains, which are prone to disruptions. These disruptions may result from many reasons, including closures of supplier
facilities or critical manufacturing facilities due to strikes, mechanical breakdowns, electrical outages, fire, explosions,
public health crises as well as logistical complications resulting from weather, other natural disasters or armed conflicts,
mechanical failures and delayed customs processing. The lack of a subcomponent or raw material necessary to manufacture
one of our products could require us to prolong our production period. For example, in the past, we have experienced
temporary supply shortages or constraints in copper and fans which resulted in extended lead times. Risks may also arise
in the course of significant projects, including risks beyond our control. These may include problems in contract design,
the miscalculation of orders, changes in economic and technical conditions, flaws in project management or inadequate
performance by subcontractors. Even when products are ready to be shipped, or have been shipped, delays may arise before
they reach our customers. When we cease timely deliveries, we have to absorb our own costs for identifying and solving
the cause of the problem, as well as expeditiously producing and shipping replacement products. In addition, any such

29


-----

disruption in our supply and delivery chains may result in a delay and trigger penalty payments under our customer
contracts. The realization of any of these risks could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition,
results of operations and ability to fulfill our obligations under the Notes and the Guarantees.

**_We are dependent on third parties for the delivery of raw materials as well as the distribution and delivery of our_**
**_products, and disruptions or delays may adversely affect our business._**

We depend on effective supply and distribution operations of third parties to obtain necessary inputs for our
production processes and to deliver our products to our customers. Damage or disruption to such supply or distribution
capabilities due to, among other things, weather, natural disasters, terrorism, political instability, public health crises, wars
and military conflicts, strikes or the financial instability of suppliers and distribution providers could impair our ability to
manufacture and deliver our products to customers in a timely manner. If our suppliers are unable to meet their obligations
under purchase orders or supply agreements, we may be unable to locate suitable alternatives, may be forced to pay higher
prices to obtain such inputs from other suppliers or even change suppliers. The unavailability, for whatever reason, of any
raw material or component required to manufacture our products could require us to decrease or suspend production
activities at one or more of our facilities, potentially for a prolonged period, and the risk of any such delay would be borne
by us. To the extent that we are unable to effectively manage such events if they occur, or cannot financially mitigate the
likelihood or potential impact of such events with respect to our suppliers and distributors, they could have a material
adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations and ability to fulfill our obligations under the Notes
and the Guarantees.

Our ability to provide our products to our customers depends on our ability to negotiate reasonable terms with
carriers, including trucking and shipping companies. The COVID-19 pandemic, for example, adversely impacted global
transportation and logistics capacities in the face of increased demand for such services. In addition, the Russia-Ukraine
Conflict as well as the recent attacks by Houthi rebels on merchant shipping vessels in the southern Red Sea region has
exacerbated this situation, resulting in increased costs of transportation and logistics services, as well as supply chain
disruptions. The market has become more constrained, with transportation resources, including drivers of heavy goods
vehicles, becoming scarce and causing a corresponding increase in costs. To the extent that our third-party carriers increase
their rates in the future, including to reflect higher fuel, maintenance, labor or other costs due to increased inflation,
regulation, taxation or otherwise, we may not be able to pass on such increases to our customers in a timely manner or at
all. Any material increases in our transport and distribution costs that we are unable to pass on to customers could have a
material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations and ability to fulfill our obligations under
the Notes and the Guarantees.

**_We are exposed to risks in connection with our Research and Development activities._**

In order to maintain our competitiveness, we are required to continuously invest in new solutions, applications,
manufacturing technologies and products. If we devote resources to the pursuit of new solutions, applications,
manufacturing technologies or products that fail to be accepted in the marketplace or that fail to become commercially
viable, all or part of our research and development (“R&D”) costs may be lost. Furthermore, should we be unable to
secure sufficient funding to finance our R&D activities, we could lose our competitive position in a number of important
markets. We incurred €16.5 million in R&D expenses in the year ended December 31, 2023 (€14.0 million in the year
ended December 31, 2022). See “Business—Research and Development.”

We also work with strategic partners in the area of research and development, when entering a new market and
in connection with large projects, in part within the framework of a partnership (for example, with construction
companies), and at other times by way of a cooperation arrangement (for example, with universities and research
institutions). In some cases, our partners provide a substantial portion of the capital resources for the project in question
or other material services. We, in turn, commit in the underlying agreements to perform certain activities in connection
with the project. If we fail to fulfill our obligations under the relevant partnership or cooperation agreements, either in
whole or in part, this may lead to claims for damages, contractual penalties or termination of the partnership or
cooperation agreement, as applicable, by our partners. In addition, the successful implementation of a project may be
endangered or impaired through a breach of contract by one of our partners or through unforeseen events. Moreover, the
success of a partnership or cooperation arrangement requires that the partners constructively pursue the same goals. In
our joint venture projects, certain intellectual property or proprietary information may (need to) be disclosed to joint
venture partners, who may use said technologies exclusively for their own purposes outside of the context of the project.
See also “—Legal, Taxation and Environmental Risks—There is a risk that we may infringe the intellectual property
_rights of third parties.” In addition, in the event that we decide on a divestment of or withdrawal from a joint venture,_
there is a risk that no buyer will be found for the shares in the joint venture, there will be no other way to sell the shares
for other reasons or that the partner will claim damages. There is also a risk that, in the event of the loss of a joint venture
partner, we will need to invest considerable resources in a new partnership.

The materialization of any of these risks could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial position,
results of operations and ability to fulfill our obligations under the Notes and the Guarantees.

30


-----

**_Changes in our product mix or our portfolio of large projects can have a significant impact on our profitability and profit_**
**_margins._**

Some of our products have higher profit margins than others. Some of our products also have a much higher
internally manufactured cost component. Therefore, changes in product mix from quarter-to-quarter or from year-to-year
can have a significant impact on our results of operations and profitability through a change in our manufacturing costs
and specifically in our manufacturing costs as a percentage of revenue. In addition, certain large projects make up a
substantial portion of our revenue, and as these projects are phased out, this can also have a significant impact on our
reported revenue and margins for our product groups that are active in the project business (in particular KTS) from quarterto-quarter or from year-to-year. A change in our product mix and the timing of revenue recognition from large projects can
have a material adverse effect on our business, financial position, results of operations and ability to fulfill our obligations
under the Notes and the Guarantees.

**_Our project business is subject to risks, including delays and cost overruns, which could have an adverse impact on our_**
**_trade working capital and results of operations._**

A considerable portion of our business is project-based, involving the delivery of engineered solutions for large
and often complex projects, and we may undertake additional large projects in the future. In particular, our business in
KTS, which is our largest product group by revenue, is largely project-based. Our customers may also require certain
upgrade projects for existing facilities with unforeseen complications. These projects and other efforts of this type are
subject to risks of cost overruns or delays inherent in any large project as a result of numerous factors, including, but not
limited to, the following:

    - shortages of equipment, materials or skilled labor;

    - work stoppages and labor disputes;

    - unscheduled delays in the delivery of ordered materials and equipment;

    - local customs strikes or related work slowdowns that could delay importation of equipment or materials;

    - weather interferences;

    - difficulties in obtaining necessary permits or approvals or in meeting permit or approval conditions;

    - design and engineering problems;

    - inadequate regulatory support infrastructure in the local jurisdiction;

    - unforeseen increases in the cost of equipment, labor and raw materials;

    - unanticipated actual or purported change orders;

    - client acceptance delays; and

    - failure or delay of third-party equipment vendors or service providers.

The risks described above are particularly relevant when we enter into long-term engineering contracts, which
represent a significant part of our business. Under some of these contracts, we assume a significant portion of the risk
associated with the project’s completion. In addition, these contracts may provide for warranty obligations that remain in
force for several years after the project’s completion. See also “Legal, Taxation and Environmental Risks—We are exposed
_to product liability claims and the risk that our products may not fulfill customer requirements or specifications.”_

We have experienced and may continue to experience several performance and quality issues with the products,
components and services provided by subcontractors, which may substantially affect the cost of a project. In certain
industries, such as the petrochemical industry, the quality expectations are particularly high, leading to very intensive
service and labor costs, and poor-quality issues may more easily result in a deviation from the original cost calculation and
time schedule for a project. Payment schedules for our large projects can also have a significant impact on, and result in
volatility of our, liquidity and working capital position. We typically negotiate upfront and milestone payments which
result in cash inflows. Over time this advanced cash is reduced as projects are started and materials are purchased due to
requirements for the manufacturing of the equipment. Cash balances can also be impacted by the timing of payments and
earlier or delayed payments can have an impact.

The failure to complete an upgrade, refurbishment or new construction project on time, or at all, or the inability to
complete a project in accordance with its design specifications, may result in loss of revenues, penalties, or delay,
renegotiation or cancellation of a project contract. Additionally, capital expenditures for large upgrade, refurbishment and
construction projects could materially exceed our planned expenditures. If we experience substantial delays and cost
overruns in our projects, this could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial position, results of operations
and ability to fulfill our obligations under the Notes and the Guarantees.

31


-----

**_Our production and development processes are exposed to operational risks in the form of interruptions which may lead_**
**_to production bottlenecks or production downtime, as well as accidents, safety defects, defective performance, quality_**
**_defects or environmental incidents._**

As of the date of the Offering Memorandum, we have 22 production sites in more than more than 20 countries.
In addition, construction sites where we carry out projects pose specific safety risks. Operational disruptions or
interruptions at our facilities and sites may occur, including for reasons beyond our control (such as aircraft crashes,
terrorism, epidemics, political unrest, natural disasters or other acts of God) or for other reasons (such as fire, floods,
explosion, release of hazardous substances, or strikes, as well as interruptions relating to the supply of energy, raw
materials and pre-products or IT failures). For example, in recent years, we experienced delays in connection with
leakage on hydraulic press cylinders, resulting in temporary unplanned downtime, pressing tooling breakdowns and
brazing furnace problems with vacuum pumps. Furthermore, our facility in Knoxville, Tennessee, was recently damaged
following unusually heavy rainfall and we have been forced to reallocate production capacity to other plants, including
in Europe as a result. This is expected to result in production delays and increased costs.

Operational disruptions and interruptions and process weaknesses may lead to significant production
downtimes and interruptions relating to services provided and products delivered to customers. If disruptions occur,
alternative facilities with sufficient capacity or capabilities may not be available, may cost substantially more or may
take significant time to start or transfer production. Each of these scenarios could materially adversely affect our business
and financial performance. If any of our production facilities is unable to manufacture our products for an extended
period of time, our sales may decline due to the disruption and we may not be able to manufacture sufficient volumes of
products to meet our customers’ needs, which could cause them to seek other suppliers.

In addition, our reputation and important customer relationships are dependent on our customers’ confidence in
the safety, quality and environmental compatibility of our services and projects. Actual or alleged accidents at projects,
safety defects, defective performance, quality defects or environmental incidents could lead to substantial financial liability
and could affect the demand for our products and services with resultant adverse financial consequences. Accidents
occurring during the execution of major projects can cause serious damage to persons and property and could permanently
damage our reputation in the public opinion, even if we were not actually responsible for causing such damage and no fault
can be attributed to us. This could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial position, results of operations
and ability to fulfill our obligations under the Notes and the Guarantees.

**_We are exposed to the potential default of contracting parties and credit risk._**

We are exposed to a risk of payment default by our customers who have agreed to purchase products from us,
by contracting parties with whom we or any of our subsidiaries work in consortiums or similar joint ventures, and other
partners and subcontractors. Trade receivables amounted to €158,880 thousand as of December 31, 2023. The amount
of overdue trade receivables is an indication of the risk that we run in connection with potential bad debts. As of
December 31, 2023, overdue trade and other receivables from third parties amounted to €43.1 million, or 27.1% of our
total receivables trade and other receivables from third parties, and bad debt allowances on our total trade receivables
amounted to €12.3 million. In the past, we have from time to time experienced payment default by certain customers that
were unable to pay for delivered goods due to financial difficulties. Even though we regularly collect credit information
on new customers and, if needed, on existing customers in an attempt to limit our exposure to credit risk, we may be
unsuccessful in identifying significant potential credit risks.

Additionally, other parties with whom we have entered into financial or other arrangements could also be in
default, e.g., in the event of their insolvency or where they have no access to credit facilities. For example, we have in
the past been unable to hold a supplier accountable for defective products due to the insolvency of the supplier.

The default of our customers or other contracting parties could have a material adverse effect on our business,
financial position, results of operations and ability to fulfill our obligations under the Notes and the Guarantees.

**_Our business, in particular our project business, is dependent on financing being available to us, our customers and_**
**_our suppliers._**

We produce, in part, complex industrial products, and our customers require substantial own equity or borrowed
funds in order to finance such products. A significant portion of our business, in particular in KTS, consists of projects
that depend on financing being available to our customers. A general decline in demand or a shortage of available
financing opportunities may make it more difficult to implement such projects. Existing orders may be deferred or
cancelled, or customers may experience payment difficulties.

Our working capital requirements can vary, depending in part on the level, variability and timing of our
customers’ production, and the payment terms agreed on with our customers and suppliers. Our liquidity could also be
adversely impacted if our suppliers were to suspend normal trade credit terms and require payment in advance or on
delivery or customers fail to pay or seek to renegotiate lower milestone payments. If our available cash flows from

32


-----

operating activities are not sufficient to fund our ongoing cash needs, we will be required to look to our cash balances
and availability for borrowings to satisfy those needs, as well as potential additional sources of capital, which may not
be available on satisfactory terms, in sufficient amount or at all. There can be no assurance that we, our suppliers or our
customers will continue to have such ability. This may increase the risk that we will be unable to produce our products
or will have to pay higher prices for our inputs without being able to pass these higher prices on by way of our selling
prices.

Any of these factors could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial position, results of operations
and ability to fulfill our obligations under the Notes and the Guarantees.

**_Our accounts receivables may remain outstanding for a significant period of time._**

Payment conditions, in particular due dates for payments by our customers, vary depending on the type of
contract and business. With respect to our component business, we record revenue and corresponding trade receivables
when products are delivered to customers, and with respect to certain products, when customer acceptance occurs
following delivery. Payments received prior to product delivery, or customer acceptance, as applicable, are recorded as
unearned revenue. Any payment delays cause capital to be tied up in receivables, which may result in pressure on our
cash flows and liquidity. We sell a portion of our trade receivables to financial services companies under a factoring
agreement; these are derecognized in our financial statements once the majority of the risks and rewards have been
substantially transferred to the financial services company. With respect to the project business, receivables and revenues
from construction contracts are recognized using the percentage of completion method. Advance payments on
construction contracts are reported separately as a liability. Although we typically benefit from customer prepayments
for newly-awarded projects in our project business, we have experienced in the past and may in the future experience
payment delays or customers deciding to cease prepayments as a result of customers revising their trading terms.

We may experience low accounts receivable turnover and payment delays due to an unexpected abandonment
or delay of projects, cancelation of orders and payment delays from certain customers due to financial difficulties. Delays
in collections and the significant period of time our accounts receivable remain outstanding may negatively impact our
cash flow and liquidity, which could have a material adverse effect on our financial position and ability to fulfill our
obligations under the Notes and the Guarantees.

**_Our assets, such as goodwill, are subject to the risk of impairment. Potential negative changes in the value of our assets_**
**_may result in write-downs and therefore negatively affect our financial position._**

As of December 31, 2023, goodwill allocated to our cash-generating units and other intangible assets amounting to
€125.3 million, and deferred tax assets in the amount of €47.1 million were reported in our consolidated statement of
financial position. We determine the value of the intangible assets in accordance with applicable accounting principles.
Goodwill is subject to an impairment test which must be performed at least annually or if particular circumstances or
changes in circumstances occur that indicate impairment. Within the context of carrying out the annual impairment tests in
accordance with IFRS 3/IAS 36, goodwill is allocated to cash-generating units where synergies are to be expected. A
comparison of the fair values attributed to the units with their carrying values including goodwill has so far not resulted in
the need for impairments. Due to the significance that general economic factors have in the context of assessing the value
of goodwill, a continued global downturn and a potential rise in interest rates worldwide could potentially necessitate an
impairment of goodwill. These non-cash impairment charges could adversely affect our results of operations in future
periods, and could also significantly impact certain financial ratios.

In addition, deferred tax assets for tax loss carry forwards are only recognized if it is probable that taxable income
will be available for the loss carry forwards to be utilized. Deferred tax assets are calculated on the basis of management
estimates on the expected timing and amount of income to be taxed and the future tax planning strategies. Therefore, an
impairment loss may have to be recognized if the expectations on which the amount of deferred taxes are based are not
fulfilled. An impairment loss with respect to goodwill or deferred tax assets could have a material adverse effect on our
financial position and ability to fulfill our obligations under the Notes and the Guarantees.

**_Any failures or disruptions of our information technology could affect our operations and our ability to serve customers._**

We rely on information technology for our day-to-day operations. These systems and processes include, but are
not limited to, ordering materials from suppliers, managing inventories and stock, processing transactions, summarizing
and reporting results of operations, complying with regulatory, legal or tax requirements, and other processes necessary to
manage the business. Any interruptions, failures, manipulation or damage to these information technology systems could
lead to delays or interruptions in our business processes. A range of factors beyond our control, such as telecommunication
problems, software errors, inadequate capacity at IT centers, fire, power outages, attacks by third parties, computer viruses
and the delayed or failed implementation of new computer systems, could interfere with the availability of our IT systems.
While we have not to date experienced any material debilitating IT disruptions or cyber-attacks, data leakage or system or
production losses in recent years, there remains a risk of cyber incursions or improper use of privileged access rights

33


-----

granted to administrators. This risk could be particularly damaging if any such cyber-attack or data leakage were to lead to
a failure to maintain the confidentiality of personal or other sensitive data. See also “—Legal, Taxation and Environmental
_Risks—We handle personal data in the ordinary course of our business, and any failure to maintain the confidentiality of_
_that data could result in legal liability for us and reputational harm to our business.” We do not have any cyber-security_
or other data security insurance in place, nor do we insist on any of our business partners taking out such insurance. Any
material disruption or slowdown of our systems could cause information to be lost. Our existing safety systems, data
backup, access protection, user management and IT emergency planning may not be sufficient to prevent information loss
or disruptions to our IT systems. In addition, if changes in technology cause our IT systems to become obsolete, or if our
IT systems are inadequate to handle our growth, our reputation may be damaged.

In addition, from time to time, we may be required to make investments to maintain and/or upgrade our IT systems
and networks and such investments may be significant, take longer or be more costly than expected or cause interruptions
to our existing systems. For example, we are currently in the process of moving to SAP S/4 HANA, an enterprise resource
planning software used to manage various business functions, which could cause issues including, but not limited to, delays,
cost overruns or system interruptions.

Any failure to properly guard against the failure, interruption or malfunctioning of our IT systems or to maintain
our IT systems could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations.

**_Our compliance and risk management systems may not be sufficient to adequately prevent or detect legal, financial or_**
**_operational risks._**

Our business is subject to various laws and regulations relating to, among other things, prevention of illegal
employment, bribery, corruption and money laundering, as well as compliance with antitrust, data protection, consumer
protection and minimum wage regulations. We are reliant on the compliance of our employees with applicable laws and
compliance policies that we have implemented. Existing risk management and internal compliance procedures and controls
may not be sufficient to prevent or detect inadequate practices, fraud and violations of law by us, our employees or third
parties acting on our behalf.

Employees may commit criminal, unlawful or unethical acts (including corruption) or our compliance and risk
management and our monitoring capabilities may prove insufficient to prevent or detect any breaches of law. Any such
acts or breaches of law could cause significant civil penalties and damage claims, as well as considerable damage to our
reputation in the market, thereby negatively affecting future business opportunities and could have a material adverse effect
on our business, financial condition and results of operations.

**_We rely on the experience and talent of our senior management and our ability to recruit and retain key employees for_**
**_the success of our business._**

Our success depends on the performance of dedicated and qualified employees, executive staff, the management
of our product groups and the experience and talent of our senior management. We may not succeed in retaining such
management, staff and employees in key positions or in recruiting and/or training a sufficient number of new employees
with necessary qualifications and skills. If we are unable to retain or recruit a sufficient number of management, staff and
skilled employees, in particular those with technical training in the areas of heat transfer, fluid dynamics and the endindustries we serve, this could impair our ability to maintain our competitiveness and market positions as well as our ability
to achieve future growth. This could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial position, results of operations
and ability to fulfill our obligations under the Notes and the Guarantees.

**_We have significant pension liabilities with respect to post-retirement benefits._**

We maintain a number of defined benefit pension plans, primarily for employees in Germany. In addition, we
have a number of historical pension plans (generally closed to new employees) that provide for the payment of retirement
benefits and certain disability and survivor benefits. After meeting certain qualifications, an employee’s right to future
benefits vests. In most cases, the future benefits payable are determined on the basis of the employee’s length of service,
earnings and position. New employees are generally only granted benefits that are partly funded by employee contributions.
As part of the general benefits provided all employees have the opportunity to voluntarily defer part of their compensation.
Under this arrangement an agreed amount of their salary plus an employer contribution of up to 100 % of the deferred
amount is converted into a pension benefit. See “Business—Employees—Pension Liabilities”.

As of December 31, 2023, the present value of our defined benefit obligations under such plans amounted to
€25.4 million. Changes in interest rates expose us to additional risk (non-cash) with respect to our defined benefit
obligations, and the low interest rate environment in recent years has increased this risk due to the relatively long period
of the obligations. Current pension payments are financed through our cash flows and, in respect of certain countries, from
a reinsurance policy. These liabilities are structurally senior to the Notes and the Notes Guarantees.

34


-----

**_Currency exchange and interest rate fluctuations may have a significant impact or our reported revenue, cash flows and_**
**_earnings._**

We operate globally and therefore enter into a number of customer, supplier and other contracts denominated in
different currencies. In particular, as a result of our international operations, we have significant assets and liabilities outside
the Eurozone, particularly in China, the United States, South Africa, Brazil, India, Poland, Czech Republic as well as Great
Britain. These assets and liabilities are denominated in U.S. dollar, British pound or other local currencies. When the net
asset values are converted into euro, the currency fluctuations result in period to period changes in those net asset values.
Our equity position reflects these changes in net asset values. We hedge foreign currency items as they arise in order to fix
prices on the basis of hedging rates, and limit some currency risk, mainly from sales and procurement transactions. However,
hedging may not eliminate all risk. Despite hedging arrangements, changes in exchange rates may affect the translation into
euro of revenues, costs, assets and liabilities of subsidiaries that use a currency other than the euro as their functional currency.
A depreciation of other currencies against the euro will mean that, despite constant sales volumes and nominally constant
prices, we will, after translation into euro, generate lower revenue and profits for purposes of our consolidated financial
statements. A number of our subsidiaries report their results in currencies other than the euro, which requires us to convert the
relevant items into euro when preparing our consolidated financial statements. Any increase (or decrease) in the value of the
euro against any foreign currency that is the functional currency of any of our operating subsidiaries will cause us to
experience foreign currency translation losses (or gains, as the case may be) with respect to amounts already invested in such
foreign currencies. These currency risks, or any losses resulting from related hedging transactions, could have a material
adverse effect on our business, financial position, results of operations and ability to fulfill our obligations under the Notes
and the Guarantees.

**_The assumptions made in preparing the business outlook included in the Offering Memorandum may prove incomplete or_**
**_inaccurate._**

The business outlook included in this Offering Memorandum reflects a significant number of assumptions,
projections and estimates made by the Issuer’s management. These assumptions relate to commercial expectations and
other external factors, including, but not limited to, political, legal, fiscal, market and economic conditions and applicable
legislation, regulations or rules, all of which are difficult to predict and are beyond the Issuer’s control. Accordingly, the
assumptions made in preparing the business outlook could prove incomplete or inaccurate and there may be differences
between the Issuer’s actual and projected results. Any such differences could have a material adverse effect on our business,
financial position, results of operations and ability to fulfill our obligations under the Notes and the Guarantees.

**Legal, Taxation and Environmental Risks**

**_We are subject to various strict and evolving governmental regulations, laws and standards including environmental,_**
**_health and safety protection._**

Our operations and properties, as well as our products, are subject to extensive international, national, provincial
and local laws, regulations and standards relating to environmental, (occupational) health and safety protection. These
laws, regulations and standards govern, among other things: air emissions of air pollutants, waste management and disposal,
noise emissions, product safety, occupational health and safety, production, handling, treatment, storage, carriage or
transportation, supply and disposal of materials, in whichever form or aggregate state, including, for example, chemicals,
products and waste, and the remediation of contaminated land, (ground)water and buildings. The scope of these laws,
regulations and standards varies across the different countries in which we operate. For example, our operations in
European countries must comply with the national laws of the individual countries as well as directly applicable EU and
international regulations. Our operations and products are subject to a variety of environmental, (occupational) health and
safety-related requirements, including permit requirements derived therefrom. Failure to comply with these product- or
operations-related requirements with respect to both existing and future business operations, including any failure to obtain
and maintain required permits, or failure to comply with requirements imposed by obtained permits and/or additionally
applicable laws and regulations, could expose us to administrative, civil or even criminal sanctions and liabilities, including
fines and penalties, operational impacts or constraints or even mandatory shutdowns ordered by competent regulatory
authorities. With regard to products, in addition to the risk of incurring administrative, civil or even criminal sanctions and
liabilities, any non-compliance with applicable regulatory requirements could also result in products becoming
unmarketable or subject to marketing restrictions.

Our operations, in particular our production activities, subject us to various statutory and regulatory compliance
and litigation risks under (occupational) health, safety, and employment laws. There can be no assurance that there will be
no accidents, even fatal accidents, or incidents suffered by our employees, contractors or other third parties on our sites or
in the context of our business operations. If any accidents or incidents occur, we could be subject to administrative, civil
or even criminal liability and litigation, which could result in us incurring fines, penalties, other sanctions or (temporary)
operational impediments, including extensive regulatory supervision and operational or marketing limitations. The
realization of any of such events could have a material adverse effect on our business and results of operations.

35


-----

We also operate in countries where environmental, (occupational) health and safety laws, regulations and
standards and their enforcement are still developing. As environmental, health and safety laws and enforcement in both
developing and developed countries are increasingly becoming more stringent, we expect our costs in connection with our
compliance with these laws to increase in the future. Furthermore, our interpretation of applicable current and future
environmental and (occupational) health and safety laws, regulations and standards may prove to be incorrect, and the
relevant authorities’ interpretations or enforcement of such laws and regulations may change. As a consequence, we may
also be exposed to financial penalties, which may have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations,
financial condition or prospects. In addition, changes in such laws, regulations and standards could require us to make
additional investments to maintain compliance, and failure to comply could result in the imposition of fines and other
remedial measures.

Furthermore, we require various licenses, permits and other authorizations typical for manufacturers and operators
of production facilities in the jurisdictions in which we operate. These licenses, permits and other authorizations are
generally subject to a variety of conditions that are stipulated either within the licenses, permits and other authorizations
themselves, or under the applicable laws, regulations and standards governing the issuing authorities. The continuation of
these licenses, permits and other authorizations may be subject to annual examinations or random inspections by the
relevant authorities to ensure that our premises and operations comply with all relevant regulations. Failure to comply with
these and other licenses, permits and other authorizations themselves or with applicable laws, regulations and standards,
or failure to comply with requirements to maintain or obtain such licenses, permits and other authorizations and failure to
comply with regulatory changes or changes in the law may result in existing or future licenses and authorizations being
withdrawn or not granted in the future. Moreover, any breach or material non-compliance with such licenses, permits and
authorizations or applicable laws, regulations or standards would negatively affect our operations and result in
administrative, civil or even criminal liabilities, which could harm our reputation, business, financial condition and results
of operations.

**_We may face risks relating to climate change that could have an adverse impact on our business._**

Greenhouse gas emissions have increasingly become the subject of substantial international, national, regional,
state, and local attention. Greenhouse gas emission laws and regulations have been promulgated in certain of the
jurisdictions in which we operate, and additional greenhouse gas requirements are in various stages of development.
Implementing such laws and regulations can be complex and may result in additional material costs for us.

In the EU, regulations attempt to both reduce greenhouse gas emissions and to establish a mechanism for trading
in carbon dioxide emission allowances. For example, the EU Emission Trading System (the “EU ETS”) imposes an EUwide emissions cap applying to the total amount of greenhouse gas emissions that can be emitted by in-scope operations
and provides for the trade, with allowances for such emissions for certain sectors and companies. As a result of the EU
ETS, we are and may in the future be further affected by increasing costs related to greenhouse gas emissions. The EU
ETS was comprehensively revised in 2023 and the corresponding legal acts came into force in May and June 2023. The
revisions include a plan to annually reduce the EU-wide emissions cap, with a linear reduction factor increasing from 2.2%
(2021-2023) to 4.3% (2024-2027) and 4.4% (2028-2030). The revisions provide for the previous carbon leakage protection
measures, in particular free allocation, to be gradually phased out and introduces the so-called Carbon Border Adjustment
Mechanism. The Carbon Border Adjustment Mechanism aims to address risks of carbon leakage by subjecting imported
and domestic products to equivalent carbon pricing. Generally, EU manufacturers will need to buy allowances for their
emissions and importers from outside the EU will likewise need to buy carbon certificates, corresponding to the carbon
price that they would have paid if they had manufactured the products in the EU. Under the currently applicable EU ETS,
the EU-wide emissions cap is lowered annually by a linear factor of 2.2% of the average annual total quantity of emission
allowances issued in the EU between 2021 and 2023. This linear factor will be raised to 4.3% from 2024 to 2027 and to
4.4% from 2028 to 2030. The revision also includes a one-off reduction of the EU-wide quantity of emissions allowances
by 90 million in 2024 and by 27 million in 2026. According to this reduction path, the total quantity of newly issued
allowances will be zero in 2040. Until then, the transitional free allocation allowances will continue on a reduced scale. On
June 5, 2023, the 2023 Directive (EU) 2023/959 amending the Emissions Trading Directive 2003/87/EC (the “Emissions
**Trading Directive”) entered into force. According to the amended version of the Emissions Trading Directive, the free**
allocation will be reduced to 0% until 2030, except for district heating, which will continue to receive a free allocation of
30%. As a result, affected companies whose emissions exceed their emission allowances will have to purchase a significant,
and steadily increasing, share of increasingly pricy emission allowances in auctions, which may result in substantial
additional costs for such companies. An exemption is available for certain energy-intensive industries which are exposed
to a significant risk of relocation of plants to countries with less stringent climate protection laws (a phenomenon known
as “Carbon Leakage”). These industries are determined by the European Commission every five years. The designated
industries will be allocated emission allowances free of charge for the period until 2023 at 100% of a pre-determined
quantity. It cannot be determined with certainty whether the exemption applies to us. In this respect, enormous costs could
be incurred for the purchase of emission certificates.

Further, the United States Congress has considered legislation that would establish a nationwide limit on
greenhouse gases. In addition, the US Environmental Protection Agency (the “EPA”) has issued regulations limiting

36


-----

greenhouse gas emissions from mobile and stationary sources pursuant to the US Clean Air Act. The Carbon Pollution
Standards for New, Modified and Reconstructed Power Plants apply to brand new sources built in the future or to an
existing unit that meets certain, specific conditions. They reflect the degree of emission limitations achievable through the
application of the best system of emission reduction for which the EPA has determined that emission reduction has been
adequately demonstrated for each type of unit. While we are currently not subject to such CO2 emissions regulations, our
plant in Muskegon, Michigan, United States is considered a so-called stationary source under the US Clean Air Act. In
case of changes to current legislation, we could in the future be subject to limitations in this regard.

When effective, such measures could require us to modify existing permits or obtain new permits, implement
additional or more restrictive emission control technology, curtail operations, or increase our operating costs. Thus, any
additional regulation of greenhouse gas emissions, including through a cap-and-trade system, technology mandate,
emissions tax, reporting requirement or other program, could adversely affect our business, financial condition, and results
of operations. In addition, this could also have an impact on our suppliers or vertical markets (particularly Oil & Gas).

**_We may not be able to obtain certain certifications required for certain areas of our business, in particular the power_**
**_industry, in a timely manner, and this may delay our order intake with respect to such projects._**

In order to access projects in certain industries, such as the nuclear and oil and gas industries, applicable
regulations and some customers require that we undergo a certification process regarding our internal processes as
providers and the characteristics and quality of our products. These certification processes are complex, time-consuming
and lengthy, and may depend on factors that are, in part, beyond our control, such as obtaining approvals from regulatory
authorities and independent third-party audits. For example, certification processes regarding certain products that we
supply to customers in the oil and gas industry can be particularly complex and lengthy. A delay or a denial in any of such
certification processes would prevent us from winning orders until the required certifications have been granted and we
may therefore not yet be able to profit from valuable business opportunities. This could have a material adverse effect on
our business, financial position, results of operations and ability to fulfill our obligations under the Notes and the
Guarantees.

**_Compliance with chemical regulations applicable to both our products and raw materials could adversely affect our_**
**_business, financial condition and results of operations._**

In our production activities, we use hazardous chemicals that are subject to regulation by the EU and other national,
provincial and local laws, regulations and standards as well as enforcement by governmental authorities in the countries in
which we operate. In order to obtain regulatory approval of certain new products and production processes, we may be
required to demonstrate to the relevant authorities that the product is safe for its intended uses and that production is safe
and will still be applied in accordance with the applicable regulations. The process of seeking approvals can be timeconsuming and subject to unanticipated and significant delays. Approvals may not be granted to us on a timely basis, or at
all. Any delay in obtaining, or any failure to obtain or maintain, these authorizations or approvals would adversely affect
our ability to conduct certain production-related activities, to introduce new products, to continue distributing and
marketing existing products and to generate revenue from those products, which could have a material adverse effect on
our business, financial condition and results of operations.

In addition, our products (and the raw materials used to produce them) are subject to extensive environmental and
industrial hygiene regulations governing the registration and safety analyses of the substances they contain. We must
comply with a broad range of regulations relating to the authorization, testing, manufacturing and labelling of our products
and those of our suppliers. In some jurisdictions, including the United States and the European Union, these types of
regulatory controls and restrictions have become increasingly demanding and we expect this trend to continue.

Further, Regulation (EC) No. 1907/2006 concerning the Registration, Evaluation, Authorisation and Restriction
of Chemicals (“REACH”) stipulates general rules for the marketing of substances, mixtures and articles in the European
economic area, and imposes various obligations which vary according to the hazardous properties of the substances, their
form, quantity and concentration, as well as the role of the actors in the supply chain. Applicable obligations include,
among others, a duty to register substances, notify of substances in articles, communicate information in the supply chain
and down to the customers, comply with restrictions and/or authorization requirements. REACH also imposes substantial
obligations with regard to the testing, evaluation, assessment and registration of building block and semi-specialty
chemicals. Pursuant thereto, we are required to demonstrate that the risks to human health or the environment associated
with our use of relevant substances are adequately controlled by carrying out periodic testing of their toxicological level.
These testing procedures can be costly and time-intensive and may lead to an increase in production or purchasing costs.

All substances currently required for our business are registered in accordance with REACH. However, regulatory
review of the registrations may result in a need to update registrations. Furthermore, the registration of additional substances
contained in new products manufactured or imported by us may become necessary. This, as well as maintaining ongoing
broader compliance with all applicable regulatory requirements (not merely registration requirements), may give rise to
further costs and, under certain circumstances, even operational impacts. Respective compliance also pertains to Regulation

37


-----

(EC) No 1272/2008 on Classification, Labelling and Packaging, as amended from time to time (the “CLP Regulation”),
which sets out hazard classes and criteria for the classification, labelling and packaging of substances and mixtures and
imposes related classification, labelling and packaging requirements on, in particular, manufacturers, importers and
suppliers. Both REACH and the CLP are amended from time to time, in particular in relation to new substances being
identified as substances of very high concern, being subjected to new authorization, restriction or information
communication requirements or substances, including raw materials, chemicals or substances contained in products, being
(re-)classified under the CLP. Compliance with amended laws and regulations subjects our operations to new or altered
regulatory requirements and may further impact our operations and give rise to significant costs and other impacts, such as
substances not being available on time for production and products not being marketable.

The EU is considering a ban or the introduction of thresholds on so-called “forever chemicals” – per- and
polyfluoroalkyl substances (“PFAS”), a large class of thousands of synthetic perpetual chemicals that are used throughout
society but increasingly deemed to be environmental pollutants, with some being associated with negative effects on human
health, are not directly used in our products. The EU-wide regulation is expected to come into force in 2026. We are
therefore exposed to the risk that materials currently used by us in the production of most of our gasketed plate heat
exchangers, which contain PFAS, may become more expensive or, potentially, may no longer be readily available in the
future. We are working closely with our key gasket suppliers and monitoring the situation, particularly with the aim of
using alternative and recently developed compounds with PFAS levels that will be below the acceptable thresholds of the
future regulation. While we expect the alternative materials, which are currently in the validation process, to be similar in
cost to those materials currently in use, there is no assurance that the alternative materials will be more cost-effective or,
conversely, that they will exceed the current costs.

Any of the foregoing outcomes could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and
results of operations.

**_We may fail to comply with applicable laws and regulations, or changes in such laws and regulations could have an_**
**_adverse impact on us._**

We are active in numerous countries worldwide. We have a global production footprint, with production sites in
more than 20 countries around the world. Therefore, we are subject to various laws and regulations in the different
jurisdictions in which we are active. Due to the industry in which we operate, these laws and regulations impose
comprehensive compliance obligations on us and restrict our offering and operating activities. These obligations and
restrictions, in turn, can be difficult to administer because of their scope, dynamic nature and varied requirements and, as
such, our global operations expose us to the risk of violating, or being accused of violating, such laws and regulations. In
addition, rapidly changing export control rules and regulations have in the past resulted in us, and may in the future lead to
a risk of inadvertently violating specific countries’ export control regulations and laws. Our failure or alleged failure to
comply with these laws and regulations may expose us to reputational harm as well as significant financial penalties and/or
operational implications.

Should we be in violation of existing laws and regulation or fail to comply with changing laws and regulations,
this could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, or results of operations.

**_Our products, services and know-how may not be fully protected by intellectual property rights, our intellectual property_**
**_rights may be infringed or challenged by third parties and we may infringe third parties’ intellectual property rights or_**
**_be faced with claims regarding infringement with regard to the use of intellectual property._**

We own a number of patents and other intellectual property that are of significant importance to our business.
The granting of patents does not necessarily imply that they are effective or that potential patent claims can be enforced
to the degree required or desired. Additionally, the patents we have applied for or intend to file for registration in
connection with new technological developments may not be granted in each of the countries where we consider this
necessary or desirable. Third parties may infringe our patents and/or intellectual property rights and we may, for legal or
factual reasons, be unable to halt such infringements. With respect to certain product areas, continuous further
development of products and maintaining technical leadership is necessary to prevent competitors from copying our
products.

If we are unable to protect our intellectual property, we may not be able to profit from the advances in
technology we have achieved, which could lead to a reduction in future results of operations. This could affect our
competitive position and any resulting reduction in revenues would have a material adverse effect on our business,
financial condition and results of operations.

Additionally, we may infringe the patents or other intellectual property rights of third parties, given that our
competitors also have pending applications for patent protection. With regard to patent rights, if we have not validly
claimed such inventions, employees may assert claims against us in relation to the ownership rights of the invention or
remuneration. This may result in the prohibition of our ability to use the affected technologies or the need to purchase
licenses, alter manufacturing processes or pay compensation. Know-how and industrial secrets that are not patented or

38


-----

cannot be patented are also of significant importance in our business, in particular in areas with technologically
demanding products and production processes. For example, there is a risk that our competitors may have been granted
patents for products and production processes that, at the time in question, we had already produced or implemented
without a patent. In the relevant country, this could lead to restrictions regarding the sale of the affected products, the
application of the relevant production processes or to an obligation to pay license fees. We may not be able to protect
our industrial secrets and third parties may develop the same or similar know-how independently.

Any restrictions on delivery and production due to patent infringement, or production interruptions resulting from
patent infringement, whether due to a change in a manufacturing process or due to other reasons, or the subsequent
acquisition of corresponding licenses could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial position, results of
operations and ability to fulfill our obligations under the Notes and the Guarantees.

**_We handle personal data in the ordinary course of our business, and any failure to maintain the confidentiality of that_**
**_data could result in legal liability for us and reputational harm to our business._**

From time to time, we process personal data (including, in certain instances, names and addresses) as part of our
business, and therefore we are subject to and must comply with strict data protection and privacy laws across several
jurisdictions. Moreover, data protection laws and rules impose certain standards of protection and safeguarding on our
ability to collect and use personal information relating to customers and potential customers and could make us liable in
the event of a loss of control of such data or as a result of unauthorized third-party access. Unauthorized data disclosure
could occur through cyber-security breaches as a result of human error, external hacking, malware infection, malicious or
accidental user activity, internal security breaches, and physical security breaches due to unauthorized personnel gaining
physical access.

We, our distributors, suppliers and other business partners may be the subject of breaches of security by hackers.
A future breach of our system or that of one of our distributors, suppliers or other business partners may subject us to
material losses or liability, including fines, claims for unauthorized use of personal and sensitive data or other claims.
Inadequate technology or security measures, the failure to follow proper security protocols or other factors may result in
data loss or unauthorized disclosure or a compromise or breach of our systems and the data we receive, store and process.
Security measures may be breached or data may be lost or disclosed by third parties (for example, through social
engineering techniques to induce disclosure of passwords or other sensitive information, other actions to gain access to our
data or our customers’ or partners’ data, or the use of ineffective security measures or failure to follow proper security
protocols), human error (such as the use of weak passwords or unencrypted devices), malfeasance or vulnerabilities
(including vulnerabilities in third-party products upon which we rely). A misuse of such data or a cyber-security breach
could harm our reputation, increase our operating expenses in order to correct the breaches or failures, expose us to
uninsured liability, increase our risk of regulatory scrutiny, subject us to lawsuits, or result in the imposition of material
penalties and fines under any applicable international laws or regulations.

For example, we are subject to extensive laws and regulations on privacy, information security and data protection,
the main and most relevant of which relate to the collection, protection and use of personal and business data, including
the EU Regulation 2016/679 (General Data Protection Regulation, the “GDPR”), the German Federal Data Protection Act
(Bundesdatenschutzgesetz, the “BDSG”), the UK Data Protection Act 2018 and the UK General Data Protection
Regulation, (together, the “UK GDPR”). See “Regulation—Data Privacy.” The costs of complying with the GDPR are
increasing, particularly in the context of ensuring that adequate data protection and data transfer mechanisms are in place.
For example, the GDPR and the UK GDPR impose substantial fines and other administrative sanctions for violations of
the data protection rules. The imposition of these sanctions will depend on the nature of the infringed provision and the
concomitant circumstances, and may include formal warnings, cease-and-desist orders and fines of up to €20 million (or
£17.5 million) or up to 4% of the total worldwide annual turnover of the undertaking in the preceding financial year,
whichever is higher, for each infraction. Additional penalties may apply, such as an immediate prohibition of the data
processing activity. Further adverse consequences of an infringement of the GDPR may include civil claims for material
and immaterial damages from the affected individuals. Implementing legislation of individual Member States, such as the
BDSG, also provides for criminal sanctions for specific violations, which may also entail the loss of any profits realized as
a result of infringements of the GDPR. Finally, in addition to these regulatory risks, any infringement of such legislation
could lead to reputational risk and significantly undermine customers’ trust in our business. See “—Our business may suffer
_if our reputation is damaged.” In addition, if we are otherwise unable to transfer personal data between and among countries_
and regions in which we operate, it could affect the manner in which we provide our products, the geographical location
or segregation of our relevant systems and operations, and could adversely affect our business, financial condition and
results of operation.

In the United States, risks of actual or perceived non-compliance includes enforcement actions under federal and
state laws, rules and regulations. In addition, privacy advocates and industry groups have approved, and may propose and
approve in the future, self-regulatory standards with which we must comply or that contractually apply to us. US state laws
in this area are complex and developing rapidly and subject to potentially differing interpretations. Many state legislatures
have adopted legislation that regulates how businesses operate, including measures relating to privacy, data security and

39


-----

data breaches. These requirements may be interpreted and applied in a manner that is inconsistent from one jurisdiction to
another or may conflict with other rules or our practices. As we seek to expand our business, we are, and may increasingly
become, subject to various laws, regulations, standards, and contractual obligations relating to data privacy and security in
the jurisdictions in which we operate. Despite our efforts, our practices may not comply, now or in the future, with all such
laws, regulations, requirements, and obligations and this could, among other things, result in the following: claims,
proceedings, or actions against us by governmental entities or others or other liabilities; the incurrence of significant
defense-related expenses or the imposition of monetary penalties; an increase in our costs of doing business; a loss of
customers or manufacturers; an adverse effect on our reputation, brand, and business; the requirement to change our
operations and/or to cease using certain data sets; or an adverse effect on our financial condition and operating results. We
may also be contractually required to indemnify and hold harmless third parties from the costs or consequences of noncompliance with any laws, regulations, or other legal obligations relating to privacy or security or any inadvertent or
unauthorized use or disclosure of data that we store or handle as part of operating our business.

In China, we are subject to extensive laws and regulations regarding cyber-security and data protection. For
example, under China’s Cybersecurity Law, any collection, use, transfer and storage of personal information of a Chinese
citizen through a network by the network operator should be based on the three principles of legitimacy, justification and
necessity and requires the consent of the data subject and the disclosure to the latter of the rules, purposes, methods and
ranges of such collection. The Personal Information Protection Law (the “PIPL”) further clarifies the scope of application,
the definitions of personal information and sensitive personal information, the legality of personal information processing
and the basic requirements of notice and consent, among other things. Non-compliance can result in fines of up to RMB
50 million or 5% of the prior year’s total annual revenue for the personal information processor and/or a suspension of
services or data processing activities. Other potential penalties include the imposition of a fine of up to RMB 1 million on
the person in charge or directly responsible personnel and, in serious cases, criminal liability under other local Chinese
law. The PIPL also prohibits responsible personnel for violations of the PIPL from holding high level management or data
protection officer positions in relevant enterprises. China’s data localization requirements are becoming increasingly
common in sector-specific regulations. We cannot predict what impact the new laws and regulations, in particular the Data
Security Law or PIPL, or the increased costs of compliance, if any, will have on our operations in China due to their recent
enactment and the limited guidance available, particularly on PIPL. It is also generally unclear how the laws, which are
often broadly drafted and leave considerable discretion to the relevant government authorities, will be interpreted and
enforced in practice by those authorities.

**_Labor disputes could disrupt our operations or lead to higher labor costs._**

We are subject to the risk of labor disputes, which may disrupt our operations. Labor laws applicable to our business
activities in certain countries are relatively rigorous and provide for the strong protection of employees’ interests. In
addition, many of our employees are members of unions or represented by works councils, employee representatives or
other bodies. For example, we are a party to collective bargaining agreements in various countries, including Germany,
France, Spain and the Netherlands. Pursuant to such agreements, we are often required to inform, consult with and request
the consent or opinion of union representatives or works councils in managing, developing or restructuring certain aspects
of our business. These employee protections and rights may consequently require us to spend greater time and expense in
altering or amending employees’ terms of employment or making headcount reductions. These labor laws and consultative
procedures could also limit our flexibility with respect to employment policy or economic reorganization and could limit
our ability to respond to market changes efficiently. Even where consultative procedures are not mandatory, important
strategic business decisions could be negatively received by some employees and employees’ representative bodies, which
could lead to labor actions that disrupt our business.

Although we believe our relations with employees are good, our operations may nevertheless be materially
affected by strikes, work stoppages, work slowdowns or other labor-related developments in the future, including
disagreements with works councils or other employee co-determination bodies. We are involved in negotiations with regard
to collective bargaining agreements, some of which may be approaching expiration or renewal (for example, in Germany),
on an ongoing basis in the ordinary course of our business. This is a process which ultimately results in higher costs for us,
whether in the form of wage increases or in terms of the repercussions for our operations of strikes by our workforce.
Additionally, in the event of non-compliance with certain welfare obligations stipulated in the collective bargaining
agreements applicable in Germany, the Netherlands, the United Kingdom, France and Spain, it is possible that the collective
wage currently in place pursuant to our “in-house” or company-specific collective bargaining agreements could return to
the wage levels pursuant to the collective bargaining agreements for the chemicals industry. These and other similar laborrelated incidents or matters could disrupt our operations and adversely affect our business, financial condition and results
of operations.

**_We are exposed to product liability claims and the risk that our products may not fulfill customer requirements or_**
**_specifications._**

Our products play an important role in regulating the operation of industrial processes. We could be subject to
claims or lawsuits relating to an actual or alleged failure of our products that may result in a failure of an industrial process,

40


-----

and such failure may cause significant financial losses, injury or death, which could negatively affect our business. For
example, in 2019, an explosion and fire occurred at the site of one of our end-customers and is claimed to have a link to
certain products delivered by us. Following the incident, the insurer of our end-customer asserted that our product was
responsible for the explosion and fire and therefore liable for damages. While we rejected these assertions and are not party
to any legal proceedings in relation to the incident of the date of this Offering Memorandum, we may still be exposed to
material liability in the future. Awards of damages, settlement amounts and fees and expenses resulting from this or other
claims and the public relations implications of any such claims, could have an adverse effect on our business.

We also cooperate with manufacturers and other suppliers which provide us with the materials and intermediate
products used in our operations. As we do not have direct control over the quality of the materials and intermediate products
