**Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosures About Market Risk**

In the ordinary course of business, we are exposed to a variety of markets risks, including currency risks, credit
risk and liquidity risk. We monitor and manage these risks as part of our overall risk management. The following section
briefly describes the significant market risks to which we are exposed. This description does not address other risks to
which we are exposed in the ordinary course of business, such as operational risks. See “Risk Factors.”

**_Currency Risk_**

We have significant assets and liabilities outside the Eurozone, particularly in China, USA, South Africa, Brazil,
India, Poland, Czech Republic and Great Britain. These assets and liabilities are denominated in local currency. When the
net asset values are converted into Euro, the currency fluctuations result in period to period changes in those net asset
values. Our equity position reflects these changes in net asset values.

We also have transactional currency exposures which arise mostly from sales or purchases in currencies other
than the functional currency. In order to mitigate the impact of currency exchange rate fluctuations for the operating
business, all companies are required to economically hedge foreign currency items, as they arise in order to fix prices on
the basis of hedging rates. Currency risks are economically hedged for recognized assets and liabilities, unrecognized firm
commitments, and highly probable forecasted transactions, when denominated in another currency than the functional
currency of the company. The hedging periods are determined by the maturity of the economical hedged items and are
usually up to twelve months, but may also exceed that period significantly in exceptional cases.

Hedge accounting in the sense of IFRS 9 is not applied. All economic hedging transactions – to the extent legally
permissible – are handled by our group treasury department. Our companies report their exposures to group treasury, which
enters on behalf of the respective companies into corresponding derivative transactions with banks. The economical
hedging transactions are closely monitored by group treasury.

For additional information, see Note 5.10 of the 2023 Audited Consolidated Financial Statements.

**_Credit Risk_**

Credit risk refers to the risk that counterparties may default on their contractual obligations resulting in a financial
loss to us. In general, we have adopted a policy of only dealing with creditworthy counterparties and obtaining sufficient
collateral in the form of advanced payments where appropriate, as a means of mitigating the risk of financial loss from
defaults.

We monitor the exposure and the credit ratings of our existing and potential counterparties continuously.
Companies active in the component business use credit limits to assess their counterparty default risk, whereas a maximum
risk limit is defined for each party. In most cases, this limit is derived from recognized credit rating agencies and credit
default swaps if available. Appropriate action is taken if the individual limit is exceeded. Companies active in the project
business ascertain the financial standing of potential customers on a case-by-case basis using all available financial
information. Before a project order is accepted, the assessment is additionally reviewed under internal risk procedures. In
the case of export transactions, confirmed and unconfirmed letters of credit are used alongside sureties, guarantees, and
cover notes, including from export credit agencies.

79


-----

Trade receivables consist of a large number of customers, spread across different industries and regions. Hence,
there is no concentration of risk. Valuation allowances take account of specific credit risks.

Derivative financial instruments are concluded only with financial institutions with high credit-ratings assigned
by international credit-rating agencies so as to reduce the credit risk involved.

We do not have any critical credit risk exposure to any single counterparty or any group of counterparties having
similar characteristics. The credit risk on cash and cash equivalents is limited because the counterparties are banks with
high credit-ratings assigned by international credit-rating agencies and also typically are our lenders. Therefore, the credit
quality of financial assets which are neither past due nor impaired is assessed to be good. The maximum exposure to credit
risk of financial assets is the carrying amount.

For additional information, see Note 5.10 of the 2023 Audited Consolidated Financial Statements.

**_Liquidity Risk_**

We are exposed to liquidity risk which may mean that it may be unable to meet payment obligations because it
has insufficient cash funds at its disposal. To manage our short, medium and long-term funding and liquidity requirements
the management has established an appropriate liquidity risk control framework consisting _inter alia of a multi-year_
financial plan and a rolling month-by-month cash forecast. We manage the liquidity risk by maintaining adequate reserves,
banking facilities, and reserve borrowing facilities as well as by monitoring forecasted cash flows at regular intervals.

The cash flow from operating activities is the most important source of liquidity. In order to optimize borrowing
and the use of our cash funds, cash pools in various countries are established. The cash pools automatically balance the
accounts of the participating companies every day by crediting or debiting a target account. This prevents separate cash
investments and borrowings by these companies to a large extent.

For additional information on credit lines and guarantees, see Note 8.2 of the 2023 Audited Consolidated Financial
Statements.

**Critical Accounting Policies**

The Consolidated Financial Statements have been prepared in accordance with IFRS. The preparation of financial
statements in conformity with IFRS requires the use of estimates and assumptions that affect the reported amounts of assets
and liabilities, the disclosure of contingent assets and liabilities at the date of the financial statements and the reported
amounts of sales revenues and expenses during the relevant period. Although such estimates and assumptions are based on
management’s best knowledge of current events and circumstances, the actual results ultimately may differ from those
estimates and assumptions. The section below presents accounting policies which require management to make judgments
and certain assumptions as the underlying facts are of uncertain nature. As a result, any changes in these facts or
assumptions may affect the results presented in the Consolidated Financial Statements.

**_Impairments of property, plant and equipment, and intangible assets_**

The determination of impairments of property, plant and equipment, and intangible assets involves the use of
estimates that include, but are not limited to, the cause, timing, and amount of the impairment. Impairment is based on a
large number of factors, such as changes in current competitive conditions, expectations of growth in the heat exchanger
industry, increased cost of capital, changes in the future availability of financing, technological obsolescence,
discontinuance of services, current replacement costs, prices paid in comparable transactions, and other changes in
circumstances, which indicate that an impairment exists. The identification of impairment indicators, as well as the
estimation of future cash flows and the determination of fair values for assets (or groups of assets) require management to
make significant judgements concerning the identification and validation of impairment indicators, expected cash flows,
applicable discount rates, useful lives, and residual values.

The carrying amounts of intangible assets, items of property, plant and equipment, and groups of cash-generating
units with goodwill are reviewed if they are likely to have been impaired by events or changes in circumstances. In addition,
indefinite-lived intangible assets and cash-generating units with goodwill are tested for impairment at least once a year.
The impairment test compares the asset’s carrying amount against its recoverable amount (“impairment test”). The
recoverable amount is defined as the higher of internal value in use and fair value less costs of disposal (net realizable
value). An estimate of fair value less costs to sell is only required if the value in use is less than the carrying amount. If the
carrying amount exceeds the recoverable amount, an impairment loss in the amount of the difference is recognized. In this
case, the impairment loss is first deducted from the goodwill of the cash-generating unit with goodwill. Any amount
exceeding goodwill is allocated proportionately to the carrying amounts of non-current non-financial assets.

Fair value less costs of disposal is generally the benchmark for measuring the impairment of product groups
classified as “held for sale”. The valuations of other intangible assets, which were performed as part of the impairment test,

80


-----

are based on management assumptions. Previously recognized impairment losses are reversed if the reasons for the
impairment no longer apply, except in the case of goodwill. Impairment losses are reversed up to a maximum of the
amortized historical cost.

**_Leases_**

We use estimates and judgements that affect the determination of the lease term – e.g., determining the enforceable
period and whether a lessee is reasonably certain either to exercise a renewal option or not to exercise a termination option.
We determine the lease term at the commencement date. As a lessee, we are required to reassess the lease term on the
occurrence of a significant event or change in circumstances that is within its control and directly affects whether it is
reasonably certain to exercise (or not to exercise) an option included in the original contract. Both lessees and lessors revise
the lease term if there is a change in the non-cancellable period. This requires ongoing monitoring and increases financial
statement volatility. Lease payments are discontinued at the rate implicit in the lease if that rate can readily be determined.
Otherwise, discounting is at the incremental borrowing rate. The incremental borrowing rate, which is mainly applied, is
based on the risk adjusted interest rates and determined for the respective lease terms and currencies.

**_Impairment_**

We recognize loss allowances for expected credit losses (“ECLs”) on financial assets measured at amortized cost,
debt investments measured at FVOCI and contract assets. We measure loss allowances at an amount equal to lifetime
ECLs, except for the following, which are measured at 12-month (a) ECLs debt securities that are determined to have low
credit risk at the reporting date; (b) and other debt securities and bank balances for which credit risk (i.e., the risk of default
occurring over the expected life of the financial instrument) has not increased significantly since initial recognition. Loss
allowances for trade receivables (including lease receivables) and contract assets are always measured at an amount equal
to lifetime ECLs. When determining whether the credit risk of a financial asset has increased significantly since initial
recognition and when estimating ECLs, we consider reasonable and supportable information that is relevant and available
without undue cost or effort. This includes both quantitative and qualitative information and analysis, based on our
historical experience and informed credit assessment, that includes forward-looking information. We assume that the credit
risk on a financial asset has increased significantly if it is more than 30 days past due.

At each reporting date, we assess whether financial assets carried at amortized cost and debt securities at FVOCI
are credit-impaired. A financial asset is ‘credit-impaired’ when one or more events that have a detrimental impact on the
estimated future cash flows of the financial asset have occurred. Evidence that a financial asset is credit-impaired includes
the following observable data: (a) significant financial difficulty of the debtor or it is probable that the debtor will enter
bankruptcy or other financial reorganization. Loss allowances for financial assets measured at amortized cost are deducted
from the gross carrying amount of the assets. For debt securities at FVOCI, the loss allowance is charged to profit or loss
and is recognized in OCI. The gross carrying amount of a financial asset is written off when we have no reasonable
expectations of recovering a financial asset in its entirety or a portion thereof.

**_Recognition and measurement of deferred tax assets and income tax uncertainties_**

We operate in a large number of countries and is therefore subject to different tax jurisdictions. Calculating tax
liabilities requires management to make various estimates. Management believes that it has made a reasonable estimate of
tax uncertainties. However, no assurance can be given that the actual outcome of these uncertainties will correspond to the
estimates made. Any deviations may have an impact on the level of tax liabilities or deferred taxes in the year of the
decision. When assessing the recoverability of deferred tax assets, management judges the extent to which realization of
the deferred tax assets is sufficiently likely. The question of whether the deferred tax assets can actually be realized depends
on whether sufficient future taxable income can be generated against which the temporary differences or tax loss
carryforwards can be offset. Management therefore analyses the times at which the deferred tax liabilities reverse, and
expected future taxable income. Management forecasts whether deferred tax assets can be realized on the basis of expected
future taxable income. Deferred tax assets decline if the estimate of planned taxable income decreases, tax benefits available
as a result of tax strategies are reduced, or the amount or timing of future tax benefits is restricted by changes in law. For
additional information, see Note 6.7 of the 2023 Audited Consolidated Financial Statements.

**_Recognition and calculation of construction contracts_**

Identification and definition of performance obligation, as well as timing of revenue recognition are based on
management’s estimates. Further, the recognition of construction contracts using the percentage of completion method is
based on management’s estimates of the cost to complete the contracts. Changes in estimates or differences between the
estimated cost and the actual cost to complete have a direct effect on recognized earnings from construction contracts. The
operating units continuously review the estimates and adjust them if required.

81


-----

**_Obligations under pension plans_**

The present value of pension obligations depends on actuarial assumptions. These assumptions comprise discount
rates, expected wage and salary increases, as well as the pension growth rate and mortality rates. These assumptions can
differ significantly from actual future outcomes as a result of changes in market and economic conditions, and can therefore
have a material effect on the level of the obligation and the related expenses.

The discount rate of the net carrying amount is calculated at the end of each year. This is the rate used to calculate
the present value of future cash outflows expected to be required to settle the obligation. In order to calculate the discount
rate, we use the interest rate on high-quality corporate bonds denominated in the same currency in which the benefits are
paid and whose terms to maturity correspond to those of the pension obligations. For additional information, see Note 5.4.1
of the 2023 Audited Consolidated Financial Statements.

**_Litigation_**

In some cases, our companies are parties to litigation. The outcome of this litigation could have a material effect
on our net assets, financial position, and results of operations. Management regularly analyses current information on these
legal disputes and recognizes provisions for probable obligations including legal costs. Both internal counsels and external
lawyers make this assessment. When deciding on the need to recognize provisions, management takes into account the
probability of an unfavorable outcome and its ability to estimate the amount of the obligation with sufficient reliability.

**_Determination of fair value of financial instruments_**

The level of management judgement, required in establishing the fair value of financial instruments for which
there is a quoted price in an active market, is usually minimal. Similarly, there is little subjectivity or judgement required
for instruments valued using valuation models which are standard across the industry and where all input parameters are
quoted in active markets (e.g., for foreign exchange rate derivatives). The level of subjectivity and degree of management
judgement required is more significant for those instruments valued using models and techniques where some or all of the
parameter inputs are less or not observable. Management judgement is required in the selection and application of
appropriate parameters, assumptions and modelling techniques. This applies especially in establishing the fair value of the
embedded derivatives.

**INDUSTRY**

**Introduction to the Heat Exchanger Industry: Heat Exchanger Types**

A heat exchanger is a device used for heat transfer from one medium to another, without mixing the two media.
Heat exchangers are used across a broad range of applications, including data centers, heating, ventilation, air conditioning
(“HVAC”), power & energy, oil & gas, food & beverages, chemicals, transportation and heavy & light industry and other
vertical markets. An important commercial feature of heat exchangers is that they typically represent only a small portion
of the machinery and equipment cost but have a high-value impact as they are important in maintaining optimal
temperatures for industrial processes. For example, heat exchangers prevent machines from overheating, which could result
in significant and costly downtime in production processes. Heat exchangers are also vital for maintaining the reliability,
efficiency, and longevity of data center operations. They ensure that servers remain cool and perform optimally. Heat
exchangers typically use either a liquid medium, where water or another liquid is used to cool or heat the fluid flowing
through, or air media, where air is used as the cooling or heating medium. Examples of liquid cooled heat exchangers
include shell and tube heat exchangers and plate heat exchangers, while examples of air-cooled heat exchangers include air
fin coolers, radiators, and condensers. Heat exchangers frequently need to operate in difficult environments, including a
broad range of temperatures (from -200 °C to +900 °C) and pressures (from -1 bar to +800 bar), as well as needing to be
resistant to corrosion, fouling and scaling. Because of this range of requirements, heat exchangers are technologically
advanced products that require sophisticated engineering capabilities. The key parameters which differentiate heat
exchangers are temperature and flow of heat, which are in turn determined by the material characteristics such as thermal
conductivity, density, specific heat, fluid viscosity, fluid velocity and surface emissivity, as well as gas characteristics.

From a technology perspective, there are four basic types of heat exchangers/heat removal devices: shell and tube
heat exchangers, plate heat exchangers, air-cooled heat exchangers and cooling towers.

_Shell and tube heat exchangers consist of a pressure vessel known as a “shell,” with a bundle of tubes inside of_
it. One fluid runs through the tubes, while another flows over the tubes within the shell, to transfer heat between the two
fluids. Shell and tube heat exchangers are widely used because of the high flexibility in allowing for a broad range of
pressures and temperatures. The key applications for shell and tube heat exchangers include power generation, food and
beverage, waste heat recovery, desalination, pharmaceuticals, oil and gas, petrochemical, and marine applications.

_Plate heat exchangers consist of a frame that holds together several metal plates that are either sealed by gaskets_
or brazed or welded together. Hot and cold fluids enter the heat exchanger via separate ports, and flow in the alternate
channels that are formed by a pair of plates. The key advantage offered by plate heat exchangers is that the fluids are spread
out over the plates and therefore exposed to a larger surface area, which facilitates the transfer of heat. Plate heat exchangers
have a wide range of applications, including Data Centers, HVAC, food and beverages, Pharmaceutical and Biotech, Dairy
Industry, Chemical processing, Renewable Energy systems, industrial processes, refrigeration, oil and gas applications and
district heating and cooling.

In an air-cooled heat exchanger, a pressure vessel is used that cools a circulating fluid within a finned tube by
forcing ambient air over the exterior of the tubes. Air-cooled heat exchangers are favored in some applications because
they eliminate the need for a continuous water supply, reduce environmental impact, and provide reliable cooling in a wide
range of operating conditions. They are useful in remote locations or arid regions where water resources are limited. Key
applications broadly include Data Centers, Power generation, Petrochemical and Chemical Processing, Renewable Energy,
HVAC, refrigeration (for food and beverages), power, oil and gas, and Marine applications.

_Cooling towers are heat removal devices used to transfer unnecessary heat from process media to the atmosphere,_
using either the principle of evaporative cooling (wet cooling towers) or a closed-circuit cooling tower where there is no
direct contact between the process media and cooling air (dry cooling towers). Their ability to dissipate large amounts of
heat makes them a critical component in many cooling applications. Cooling towers are used for Data Centers, Renewable
Energy systems, power applications and, to some extent, other process applications such as chemicals and petrochemical
processing, oil and gas and district cooling systems.

The choice for a particular type of heat exchanger depends on the type of application and the characteristics of the
site (e.g., dry cooling is particularly relevant in arid areas, where water is scarce) and has a direct impact on the operational
cost of the application. While shell and tube exchangers currently represent the largest product segment in the global market
for heat exchangers and are popular owing to their flexibility and application in a wide range of environments characterized
by different pressures and temperatures, the segment for plate heat exchangers is presently growing rapidly, in part because
of energy efficiency concerns.

that the size of the global heat exchanger market in 2022 was U.S.$14.3 billion and is expected to grow at compounded

**Market and Industry Characteristics**

The global heat exchanger market is primarily driven by the following trends and features:

**_Demand for heat exchangers supported by mega trends_**

_Strong demand for data centers_

A data center comprises extremely sensitive electronic components that require a consistent temperature,
humidity, airflow, and cleanliness to prevent equipment failure. The strong growth in data centers is driven by several key
factors such as: (1) the emergence and popularity of artificial intelligence (AI) based applications, (2) increased demand of
cloud storage, (3) remote working and distant learning, (4) rise of data intensive technologies like machine learning (ML),
internet of things (IoT) and (5) increasing digitalization of businesses and processes. This has led to a need for advanced
processors that have high heat dissipation and require more power which in turn has resulted in a shift away from the
traditional data center architecture to the adoption of advanced, more efficient cooling solutions such as adiabatic cooling,
immersion cooling, economizer, or free cooling. Technology company’s increased investment in data centers is driving the
construction and development of hyperscale data centers globally. While, at the same time, global data protection regimes
are driving the development of local data center clusters, leading to regional data center demands.

_Heat recovery for new living quarters_

Heat exchangers play a crucial role in HVAC systems by transferring heat between two or more fluids, typically
air and a refrigerant, without mixing them. In the developed economies such as Europe and USA, strong regulatory
initiatives requiring clean energy equipment to replace fossil fuel boilers in new buildings are driving demand for HVAC
/ heat pumps. In emerging economies, growing population, raising levels of disposable income, and increasing living
standards coupled with global surface temperature rises in tandem with greenhouse gas concentrations are giving rise to
increasing demand to preserve an ambient environment in a building, leading to growing demand for HVAC systems.

_Increasing environmental awareness_

With the growing push for energy transition, several new industries are emerging out of the traditional industrial
applications such as renewable energy, hydrogen economy, fuel cells, carbon capture utilization and storage (“CCUS”),
among others. The global energy transition market is expected to grow driven by increasing regulatory standards,
environmental awareness, and continuous investments to shift the energy mix to more sustainable options. Heat exchangers

84


-----

play a crucial role in power plants across the value chain in maintaining optimum operating conditions from generation to
storage to distribution. By 2030, cumulative investments in energy are expected to reach U.S.$44 trillion, of which, 80%
i.e., U.S.$35 trillion will be towards transition technologies prioritizing efficiency, electrification, grid expansion and
flexibility (source: IRENA March 2023).

_Industrialization worldwide_

In the post-pandemic world, industrial development is increasingly shaped by digitalization and automation of
industrial production, a shift of global economic towards Asia and efforts to make industrial production more sustainable.
Energy-efficient equipment in energy-intensive vertical markets such as chemical and pharmaceutical manufacturers, food
and beverages processing plants, the oil and gas industry and the marine industry are key drivers for demand for heat
exchangers. New, energy-saving applications for heat exchangers, such as waste heat recovery systems, have become
increasingly important. The requirement by end-customers for products that reduce costs and limit environmental emissions
necessitates technological improvements.

_Shift towards intelligent service_

The shift towards intelligent services for heat exchanger applications refers to the integration of advanced
technologies and digital solutions to enhance the monitoring, maintenance and overall performance of heat exchangers.
This includes remote monitoring and diagnostics, predictive maintenance, condition-based monitoring, remote control and
optimization, digital twin technology, integration with enterprise systems. The aim is to leverage digitalization and
automation technologies to enhance operational efficiency, reliability, and sustainability while reducing the lifecycle costs
and enhancing customer value. As the demand for efficiency increases in a more environmentally aware world, these
intelligent services become more important.

**Market Development by Region**

In terms of geographical markets and as per definitions of the Frost & Sullivan Report, Asia Pacific is the largest
regional market for heat exchangers, followed by Europe, and North America. While Europe and North America are
characterized as a mature market, Asia Pacific has shown rapid growth in the past few years. The last years have witnessed
a shift in demand from developed to emerging markets, and thus emerging countries and regions such as Asia Pacific, Latin
America and the Middle East are expected to grow substantially on the back of growing population, rapid urbanization,
increased industrialization and growing digitalization.

**_Asia Pacific_**

The Frost & Sullivan Report estimates that the Asia Pacific global heat exchanger market size was U.S.$4.7 billion
in 2022, making it the largest regional market globally, and is expected to grow at CAGR of 7.7% between 2022 and 2027.
This compares to a 2020 market size for Asia Pacific of U.S.$4.2 billion, implying a CAGR of 5.9% between 2020 and
2022. According to the Frost & Sullivan Report, chemicals are the largest vertical market segment by far in Asia Pacific
followed by power generation.

The growing demand for heat exchangers in Asia Pacific is due to rapid urbanization, construction activities,
increasing capital expenditure by industrial companies, and strong consumer demand underpinned by population growth.
Asia Pacific is expected to emerge as the top chemical producer globally and emerging economies such as China and India
are expected to emerge as two of the top three countries in the power generation sector worldwide (source: Frost & Sullivan
Report). Additionally, constant investments in a range of industry vertical markets, such as the chemical and power
generation industries, are expected to boost demand for heat exchangers.

**_Europe_**

The Frost & Sullivan Report estimates that the European global heat exchanger market size was U.S.$4.6 billion
in 2022, making it the second largest regional market globally, and is expected to grow at CAGR of 6.5% between 2022
and 2027. This compares to a 2020 market size of U.S.$4.0 billion, implying a CAGR of approximately 6.9% between
2020 and 2022. Europe will remain a major heat exchanger market. Heat exchanger adoption is likely to increase due to
stringent requirements being implemented by EU government to reduce emissions.

**_North America_**

The Frost & Sullivan Report estimates that the North American heat exchanger market size was U.S.$3.7 billion
in 2022 and is expected to grow at a CAGR of 5.5% between 2022 and 2027, compared to a 2020 market size of U.S.$3.4
billion, implying a CAGR of 4.6% between 2020 and 2022. Power generation is the largest vertical market for heat
exchangers in North America followed by chemicals, oil & gas, HVAC & refrigeration and data centers. Expanding refinery
capacity and new chemical plant installations are expected to drive the North American heat exchanger market. North
America’s continually increasing energy consumption supported by the power generation industry, which relies largely on

85


-----

heat exchangers, is expected to expand substantially. The installation of surface heat exchangers to update existing power
plants and reduce carbon emissions is also expected to contribute to the growing demand for heat exchangers.

**_Latin America_**

The Frost & Sullivan Report estimates that the Latin American heat exchanger market size was U.S.$0.4 billion
in 2022 and expected to grow at a CAGR of 3.3% between 2022 and 2027 compared to a 2020 market size of U.S.$0.38
billion, implying a CAGR of 2.9% between 2020 and 2022. Primary applications for heat exchangers in Latin America are
in-vehicle radiators, air conditioning systems, and sewage treatment facilities. An increasing number of heat exchangers
being refurbished at conventional power stations, refineries, and chemical processing plants is expected to be a key factor
driving growth in the Latin American market for heat exchangers. A growing population, raising levels of disposable
income, and shifting living standards leading to increased demand for passenger vehicle and installation of HVAC systems
in residential areas are also expected to have a positive impact on demand for heat exchangers in this market.

**_Middle East and Africa_**

The Frost & Sullivan Report estimates that the Middle East and Africa heat exchanger market size was U.S.$1.0
billion in 2022 and is expected to grow at a CAGR of 4.5% between 2022 and 2027 compared to a 2020 market size of
U.S.$0.9 billion, implying a CAGR of 4.3% between 2020 and 2022. Oil & Gas is the largest vertical market in Middle East
and Africa for heat exchangers followed by chemicals, food & beverage, and power generation. Recent industry decline in
Oil & Gas is expected to impact the growth of the market, however Middle East and Africa is also the largest market for
commercial and residential centralized cooling systems, which is expected to drive heat exchanger market growth.

**Heat Exchanger Demand in Key Strategic Pillars**

Heat exchangers are used in processes across a diverse range of industries. The major vertical markets for the
global heat exchanger are the following: chemical (25%), power generation (22%), oil and gas (16%), HVAC and
refrigeration (9%), data centers (8%), food and beverages (8%) and other industries (source: Frost & Sullivan Report).
The major vertical markets for the Company follow a different split than that of the general market and can be categorized
as mainly as High Tech, Green Tech, and Conventional sectors. The following is a description of the specific applications
of our offering within each vertical market, as well as growth expectations and certain key drivers of each vertical market.

**_High Tech_**

The High Tech sector is defined as comprising primarily of Data Centers (Hyperscalers, Colocation, Modular etc).
As per the Frost & Sullivan Report, global Data Center heat exchange demand is expected to grow at a CAGR of 7.8%
between 2022 and 2027. APAC is expected to witness the highest growth in the data center cooling market as data center
installation ramps up and requires higher cooling due to the region’s hot climate. North America is the second-largest
market followed by Europe. The types of heat exchangers used for data center are plate heat exchangers, liquid, or aircooled heat exchangers, adiabatic coolers, direct liquid / immersion cooler, economizer / free cooler. As processing power
of the Data Centers increase and artificial intelligence / machine learning systems gain momentum, the cooling requirement
of Data Centers are expected to increase. Along with air-cooled and chilled water solutions, data center operators are
expected to increasingly deploy liquid cooling to increase efficiency of cooling solutions and reduce operational
expenditure. North America is the leader in deploying advanced cooling solutions such as liquid coolers, adiabatic cooling,
and economizer.

Vertical market applications include, white space cooling, either air based (CRAC, CRAH) or liquid based (Direct
to Chip, Immersion Cooling, Edge Cooling), heat rejection and recovery, utility cooling and backup generator cooling.

**_Green Tech_**

The Green Tech sector is defined as comprising of HVAC, Carbon Capture Storage (CCS), Hydrogen economy
and Liquified Natural Gas (LNG). This sector focuses on those application practices, processes and products aimed at
minimizing environmental impact and promoting conservation of resources. It encompasses a wider range of technologies
and solutions that strive to directly or indirectly address environmental challenges such as climate change, pollution,
resource depletion and ecosystem degradation.

_HVAC & Refrigeration_

The HVAC industry is growing, driven by rapid expansion in commercial and residential building development
projects and purchases, worldwide. In developing economies, increasing urbanization and industrialization have created
demand for more HVAC-equipped enterprises and residential complexes. Energy efficiency is now required for new
HVAC installations. Governments globally have implemented legislation to encourage the use of HVAC systems that
satisfy industry standards for energy efficiency. The global heat exchanger demand from HVAC and refrigeration
applications is expected to grow at CAGR of 5.9% from 2022 to 2027 as per the Frost & Sullivan Report.

86


-----

_Carbon Capture Storage (CCS)_

CCS is an engineered system of technologies, refined over several decades, in the process of mitigating CO2
emissions from large point sources such as power plants, refineries and other industrial facilities, or the removal of existing
CO2 from the atmosphere. Captive markets, where the producer of CO2 is also the consumer, such as in chemical production
or natural gas processing for enhanced oil recovery, account for the majority of global carbon capture activity. The United
States are the largest CCS market followed by Europe and APAC. Carbon capture is an increasing focus for all companies
to leverage their competitive advantage in an emerging industry. Heat exchangers are essential in CCS processes for their
role in energy efficiency, thermal processing, thereby reducing operational costs, and also forms a significant part of the
investment in CCS projects.

_Hydrogen economy_

Hydrogen economy is an umbrella term used to denote hydrogen’s role alongside low-carbon electricity to reduce
emissions of greenhouse gases. It represents a significant growth market with diverse applications across various sectors
such as heavy industry, long-haul transport, and long-term energy storage. This diversity of applications provides a wide
range of opportunities. Currently, most hydrogen is produced from natural gas. Investment in technologies for producing
green hydrogen (from renewable energy sources) and blue hydrogen (from natural gas with carbon capture and storage)
could yield significant returns as these technologies mature and scale up. The growth of the hydrogen economy is driven
by growing demand for cleaner fuel, coupled with increasing governmental regulations for desulphurization of petroleum
products. Heat exchangers are an essential part of hydrogen generation as the technology / electrolysis process of generation
of hydrogen is an exothermal process. Plate Heat Exchangers and Air Fin Coolers are typically used for this purpose.

_Liquified Natural Gas (LNG)_

LNG is natural gas that has been cooled down to -162 °C to transform it into a liquid, making it easier and safer
to transport. Natural gas primarily is methane and, when burned, releases water vapor and CO2. With emissions at 30-50%
less than from other combustible sources, natural gas is regarded as the cleanest of the fossil fuels. LNG is considered as
bridge fuel which can make energy transition easier. Fuel switching, primarily from fossil to LNG can reduce CO2
emissions and air pollutions. In the backdrop of recent geo-political situation and Europe’s quest to reduce dependency on
Russian gas supply, LNG prices have risen sharply. Increased prices spurred a high level of new supply expected from
2024 to 2028. 193 million tons per annum nameplate capacity is expected to be added by 2028, which would represent
40% of the current capacity, implying 9% CAGR supply growth between 2024 and 2028. (source: IEEFA Report). Heat
exchangers are used along the whole value chain of LNG starting from extraction, treatment, liquification, transportation,
regasification and end use (power generation, gas boilers, hydrogen production).

**_Conventional Sectors_**

Conventional sectors are defined as comprising of oil & gas, chemicals, power and energy, food & beverage,
transportation, and heavy & light industry.

_Chemicals_

As per the Frost & Sullivan Report, the chemical industry was the largest consumer of heat exchangers globally
in 2022 contributing 25% of the heat exchanger demand and heat exchanger demand from this sector is expected to grow
at a CAGR of 7.2% between 2022 and 2027. As more oil and gas businesses diversify into chemicals and petrochemicals
to create new demand for oil and gas goods, the demand for heat exchangers is expected to continue to remain steady for
this sector. China is the largest chemicals market accounting for approx. 60% of the APAC market, as per the Frost &
Sullivan Report. Heat transfer is an energy-intensive phase in many chemical processes and not prioritizing efficiency
might therefore result in inflated costs. The most popular kind of heat exchangers used in the chemical processing sector
are Shell-and-Tube units because of their adaptability and capacity to handle fluids with various levels of particles. As a
result, the chemical sector drives significant demand for Shell-and-Tube heat exchangers as it is capable of confining
substances.

_Power Generation_

As per the Frost & Sullivan Report, the power generation industry was the second largest end-market for heat
exchangers globally in 2022, contributing 22% of the heat exchanger demand and heat exchanger demand from this sector
is expected to grow at CAGR of 5.9% between 2022 and 2027. Population rises driving electricity generation contributing
to growth of the heat exchanger market in the power generation industry. Europe is focused extensively on renewables,
and North America and APAC are constructing additional thermal power plants to maintain a continuous increase in power
generation capacity. The top three power generation countries are the United States, China, and India, with each spending
extensively in thermal and dependable power. China and India are two of the fastest growing markets for heat exchangers

87


-----

for the power generation sector, with heavy investment in coal-fired and natural-gas-fired power plants to satisfy the
predicted rise in energy demand.

_Oil & Gas_

As per the Frost & Sullivan Report, the oil & gas industry was the third largest consumer of heat exchangers
globally in 2022 contributing 16% of the heat exchanger demand and heat exchanger demand from this sector is expected
to grow at a CAGR of 5.5% between 2022 and 2027. The upstream, midstream, and downstream segments of the oil and
gas industry all have a need for heat exchangers. Oil refiners can help to optimize energy use and reduce emissions by
combining efficient heat transfer technologies with process and application expertise. Up until it is burned, crude oil could
be heated significantly by using welded-plate heat exchangers, which could result in significant operational expenditure
reductions. Demand for heat exchangers in the oil and gas sector will rebound from the downturn during the forecast period
because of increasing exploration and production activity globally.

_Food & beverage_

As per the Frost & Sullivan Report, the food and beverage industry contributed to 8% demand for heat exchangers
in 2022 and heat exchanger demand from this sector is expected to grow at a CAGR of 6.6% between 2022 and 2027. In
the food and beverage sector, heat exchangers help reduce or eliminate microorganisms, which enhances product safety
and shelf life. A heat exchanger may be used to warm or cool goods prior to procedures including filling, drying, and
concentrating. For food processing techniques such as pasteurization and sterilization, heat exchangers are essential to
maintain specific ambient temperature and humidity. The viscosity and particle size of the product determine the kind of
heat exchanger used in this sector. The plate Heat Exchanger, used to move fluids swiftly, is the most used heat exchanger.
Global food trends influence heat exchanger innovation in numerous ways.

_Transportation, Heavy & Light Equipment_

This segment is not covered specifically in the Frost & Sullivan report as there is some crossover in other sectors
in their analysis. However, we split out this market segment to focus on heat exchangers applied in different types of
Transportation, Heavy and Light Equipment. Land transportation covers Rail, Road and Off-Road, as well as water
transportation (e.g. Marine and Shipping). Heavy and Light Equipment heat exchangers are applied for example in heavy
industry for production of large and heavy equipment, heavy machinery, coal, steel and other metals etc., and in light
industry for production of light equipment, industrial cooling, paper, textile and other consumer goods. This segment is
often characterized by direct end user relationships or OEM customers. The market dynamics are driven by growth in
infrastructure projects, global manufacturing growth, energy efficiency requirements driven by global sustainability drive
and general GDP growth Competition.

**Competition**

The competitive landscape in the heat exchanger industry is fragmented and varies significantly depending on the
specific technology (shell and tube, plate, finned tube, cooling tower), business model (project, component), vertical market
and geography. Depending on the region and the type of heat exchanger, we compete with both large international as well
as with numerous smaller regional and local competitors. The service business is primarily local. According to the Frost &
Sullivan Report, European manufacturers are the largest participants in the global market owing to large domestic markets
and domestic strength, although a large number of small competitors compete in most regional markets. The Frost &
Sullivan Report sees cost-effective manufacturers from the Asia Pacific region creating price pressures in the European
market. Key competitive factors are customer proximity, engineering competence and cost competitiveness, and customer
relationship. Rising raw material prices and a price sensitive customer base are resulting in thinner profit margins for
manufacturers, mainly because the ability to transfer increased cost of production to customers remains limited.

The Group’s global competitors are Alfa Laval, Lu-Ve, Güntner and Modine, S&T. Alfa Laval is our main
competitor the in Plate Heat Exchanger market whereas, Lu-VE, an Italian manufacturer focusing on refrigeration
technologies and is increasingly focusing on US and China. Danfoss is also a strong player in the market. In recent years,
Lu-VE has also grown through acquisitions, for example the acquisition of Refion from Alfa Laval in 2022 to expand its
portfolio mainly in the HVAC segment.

**BUSINESS**

**Overview**

We are a leading global provider of heat exchanger solutions with more than 100 years of experience in design,
manufacturing, installation and service (source: Frost & Sullivan Report). We have built our strategic pillars on (i) High
Tech applications and solutions, in particular for Data Centers with liquid and free cooling, (ii) Green Tech applications
and solutions in various vertical markets, such as Power & Energy, HVAC, Hydrogen, Liquified Natural Gas, Carbon
Capture Storage, (iii) Conventional applications, such as in the Refrigeration, Food & Beverage, Chemicals and Oil & Gas
vertical markets, as well as (iv) Service applications across all our vertical markets and product groups. Our diversified
presence across regions and transformative industries are supported by long-term underlying megatrends, such as
digitalization, energy transition and environmental concerns in general. Based on the breath of our product portfolio,
extensive global footprint, and diverse end-markets, as well as our technology leadership position and R&D capabilities,
we believe we are well-positioned to benefit from the long-term growth trends in our vertical markets.

Since 2021, under our new management, we have been implementing a comprehensive strategic program known
as “High Five”. The High Five program is designed to build a long-term sustainable business and comprises the following
five strategic pillars: (i) Grow High Tech, (ii) Grow Green Tech, (iii) More Service, (iv) Grow APAC & Americas and (v)
More Digitalization, with greater emphasis on reducing complexity through digitalization. At the same time, we divested
unprofitable businesses, such as the Enexio in recent years. Since the beginning of 2021 and despite several external shocks,
such as the Russia-Ukraine war and the spike in energy prices and inflation caused thereby, our Order Intake, Revenue and
Normalized EBITDA have increased from €1,099.3 million, €931.7 million and €78.8 million, respectively, for the year
ended December 31, 2021 to €1,697.9 million, €1,347.9 million and €146.9 million, respectively, for the year ended
December 31, 2023. Historically, our business operations have been primarily divided into four product groups: Kelvion
Thermal Solutions (“KTS”), Refrigeration Technologies (“RT”), Plate Heat Exchangers (“PHE”) and Machine Cooling
Systems (“MCS”). We also consider our key vertical markets and geographic regions in the management of our business.

      - _KTS provides air fin coolers and cooling towers for installations with large cooling requirements as well_
as air dryers used to remove humidity from air streams. KTS focuses on providing customized solutions
and primarily serves Data Centers, Power & Energy, Oil & Gas and Chemicals vertical markets. For the
twelve months ended March 31, 2024, KTS accounted for 44.6% of our revenue.

      - _RT supplies standard and customized heat exchangers for cooling and removing heat in different_
applications using air and liquid cooling methods. The primary vertical markets are HVAC, refrigeration
applications and Data Centers. For the twelve months ended March 31, 2024, RT accounted for 20.5%
of our revenue.

      - _PHE offers a range of gasketed, brazed and welded plate heat exchangers for a variety of applications_
and vertical markets, including HVAC, Food & Beverage, Chemicals, Power & Energy and Heavy &
Light Equipment. For the twelve months ended March 31, 2024, PHE accounted for 17.9% of our
revenue.

      - _MCS supplies heat exchangers for power generation, power transmission, large engine applications_
(marine and off-highway) and Green Tech applications such as biomass, green hydrogen, or renewable
energies. The primary vertical markets are Transportation, Heavy & Light Equipment, Power & Energy
and Oil & Gas. For the twelve months ended March 31, 2024, MCS accounted for 14.3% of our revenue.

Since the beginning of 2024, the RT, MCS and PHE have been managed on a regional basis in the following
geographic regions – Americas, APAC and EMEA.

In addition, all our product groups’ activities are complemented by a comprehensive after-sales support and
services offering, reflecting our ability to support our customers with full-service packages thereby reducing their operating
costs. We provide services both for our own products as well as for third-party products, managed on a centralized and
global basis across our product groups. For the twelve months ended March 31, 2024, our service business generated
revenues of €251 million and for the year ended December 31, 2023 revenues of €259 million, an increase of 21% compared
to the year ended December 31, 2022.

We have a large and diverse customer base, including many blue-chip customers, and have built long-standing
customer partnerships. Our customer base comprises more than 19,000 active customers (i.e., customers that have placed
an order with us in the last 24 months) and repeat orders over multiple years from more than 12,000 customers. Our
customer base is also diversified across vertical markets and geographies. For the twelve months ended March 31, 2024,
our Order Intake by strategic pillar can be broken down as follows: circa 39% in High Tech, circa 36% in Conventional
applications, circa 17% in services and circa 7% in Green Tech. During the same period, the Order Intake by geography

**_Difficult to replicate business model, underpinned by differentiated engineering solutions, service capabilities and_**
**_customer responsiveness_**

We believe our differentiated technical offerings and service capabilities are difficult to replicate and,
consequently, create high barriers to entry and prevent new competitors from easily entering our markets. Our application
engineering expertise and production know-how are based on decades of experience and supported by our network of 19
engineering centers and more than 450 engineers worldwide. Our innovation portfolio includes hybrid coolers for High
Tech, our advanced diffusion bonded heat exchanger “K°Bond” used in oil rigs, LNG, regasification facilities and CO2
stations, natural refrigerants, high pressure laser welded cassette (HPL) for Green Tech and hydrogen leakage testing for
Services. In particular, our advanced manufacturing technologies, including 3D design and simulation, help to improve
product performance and reduce failure rates. In addition, computational fluid design and simulation is validated by our
inhouse labs and supports the development of our thermal design know-how and proprietary software, which enables us to
design solutions according to customer requirements.

Our differentiated technical solutions are complemented by our strong Service offering and proximity to our
customers, including the ability to provide local service to global customers based on our presence in 24 countries and the
ability to service other third-party brands. This is backed by performance agreements, aimed at maximizing customers’
return on investment and predictive maintenance to reduce operational downtime. We have a full-service portfolio spanning
start-up (safe delivery, installation and early start post installation support), inspection and maintenance (period checks),
repairs and overhauls, testing and monitoring (understanding condition of equipment), spare parts (designed to match the
original parts), upgrades and replacements (for outdated components) and consulting and training (leading to competency
of client personnel). We believe the breadth of our portfolio of Services offers customers seamless operation across the
globe.

The responsiveness to our customers, and our close working relationship build trust in our solutions and delivery.
This builds long-term partnerships and trust fostering reliability as evidenced by the high proportion of our 19,000 active
customers (i.e., customers that have placed an order with us in the last 24 months) that have placed repeat orders over

**_High revenue visibility from strong Order Intake and Order Backlog development_**

Our Order Intake and Order Backlog provide us with high revenue visibility, and we believe the strong
development in our Order Intake and Order Backlog will support our future performance and continued growth. From 2021
to 2023, Order Intake increased at a CAGR of approximately 24%, from €1,099 million in the year ended December 31,
2021, to €1,698 million in the year ended December 31, 2023 and Order Backlog increased from €615 million as of
December 31, 2021 to €1,103 million as of December 31, 2023. Over the same period, our revenue increased from €931.7
million in the year ended December 31, 2021, to €1,347.9 million in the year ended December 31, 2023, resulting in a
consistent ratio of Order Intake to revenue of more than 1.0x (“book-to-bill ratio”) across the periods. Moreover, for the
twelve months ended March 31, 2024, our book-to-bill-ratio amounted to 1.1x. Revenue visibility is further enhanced by
the fact that, historically, a majority of our Order Intake in any given year was converted into revenue in the same fiscal
year or the next succeeding year. The portion of our Order Intake in the years ended December 31, 2021, 2022 and 2023
that was or is planned to be converted into revenue in the same year or the next succeeding year represented 51% and 54%
of our revenue for the years ended December 31, 2022, and 2023 as well as 62% of our budgeted revenue for the year
ending December 31, 2024. We believe that our high revenue visibility also helps drive our profitability as it allows for
improved management of customer order fulfilment, efficient operations planning and hence limits impacts under
absorption.

Our diversified presence across geographic regions and vertical markets enables us to benefit from increasing
demand in specific regions and vertical markets without being overly dependent on any single region or vertical market.
Order Intake for the year ended December 31, 2023, included €860 million in KTS, €388 million in RT, €258 million in
PHE and €210 million in MCS, driven to a significant extent by strong growth in KTS.

For the twelve months ended March 31, 2024, Order Intake was led by High Tech, followed by Conventional and
with Green Tech and Service broadly equal. Americas and EMEA dominated the regions and APAC has been steadily
growing.

**_Consistent and sustained progress in implementation of operational excellence plan will further enhance profitability_**
**_development_**

We have a strong track record of successfully implementing operational excellence measures across our
businesses to enhance profitability. These include initiatives to drive revenue growth, such as pricing adjustments and
production capacity realignments to increase and optimize production capacity to grow with our customers. To strengthen
our position, we are also refocusing our innovation pipeline to consistently introduce new products on a global scale. They
also include measures focused on our cost position, such as numerous supply chain initiatives across our supply chain on
a global scale (with 74 identified measures completed within 2024), production capacity utilization measures (including
production re-organization) and evaluating product mix to identify and focus on most profitable products and customer
demand. In addition, beginning in 2022, we initiated a range of actions and measures to systematically improve our cash
position by focusing on working capital. These included, among others, regular forecasting and active monitoring of cash
management and cash conversion cycles, enhancements of enterprise resource planning systems to better track inventory
levels and reduce slow-moving materials as well as actively managing receivables through initiating standard customer
debt collection policies. As a result, we reduced trade working capital w/o retention from 12.1% of revenue for the year
ended December 31, 2021 to 1.1% of revenue for the year ended December 31, 2023. Over the same period, we managed
to increase our Free Cash Flow Conversion rate from 57.8% for the year ended December 31, 2021 to 61.5% for the year
ended December 31, 2023.

Over the last three years, we have set several measures to improve our operational efficiency (e.g. quality cost
improvements from inward quality review and improvements in internal processes) and commercial efficiency. Our
commercial efficiency focuses on the core areas (i) target selling (e.g. focus on vertical markets), (ii) process simplification
(e.g. sales order review) and (iii) digitalization. The chart below illustrates the impact of the above mentioned measures on

**_Proven leadership team with track record of transformation, growth, and value creation_**

We benefit from an experienced management team led by Andy Blandford, our Chief Executive Officer, and Mark
Bevan, our Chief Financial Officer, each of whom joined the Group in 2022 and have more than 30 years of experience in
various management and executive management positions at leading global companies. Our leadership team includes
Harald Gössl, EVP Technology, and Steffen Thierfelder, EVP Sales & Services, each of whom also has more than 20 years
of experience. They are supported by leadership team with extensive industry experience and operational know-how,
including regional managers responsible for developing their respective markets. We believe that the collective industry
experience and operational know-how of our leadership team, combined with their extensive management experience,
provide us with a competitive advantage and are instrumental for the implementation of our strategy and achievement of
our long-term objective of delivering sustainable growth.

**Our Strategy**

We started our journey to create consistency in performance, profitability and a platform for growth in 2021 with
the High Five strategic program. This set out five focus areas to concentrate on to build a better business. These five areas
comprise: (1) Grow High Tech, (2) Grow Green Tech, (3) More Service, (4) Grow APAC & Americas and (5) More
Digitalization.

**_Focus on growth in High Tech and Green Tech markets_**

We aim to utilize our strong technological capabilities and innovative solutions to capture the growing demand
from customers in the High Tech and Green Tech markets, such as, Data Centers, HVAC, Carbon Capture Storage,
Renewable Energy and LNG. These vertical markets are characterized by high growth potential, complex requirements,
and stringent quality standards, which create attractive opportunities for us as a reliable and flexible partner. We plan to
expand our presence in these vertical markets by developing new solutions and applications, enhancing our customer
relationships, and pursuing selective acquisitions that complement our portfolio and geographic footprint.

**_Continue to grow our Service business_**

We intend to leverage our large installed product and customer base to continue to grow our Service business. For
example, we are focused on improving the organizational setup of our Service business across our product groups by
establishing dedicated service responsibilities and pooling service skills across product groups in certain regions and
increasing transparency. In KTS, we are considering strategic cooperations with specialist service providers to drive our
service business coverage and support our strategic objectives to benefit from robust growth in our strategic pillars and
vertical markets. This way we can utilize our product and engineering knowledge with a technical service partner who has
a strong market foothold that we can leverage.

**_Increase market share in the Americas and APAC region_**

We intend to continue to focus on the growth of our global platform and improve our market share in the Americas
and APAC regions through investment in production capacity and local dedicated sales teams. For example, we aim to
leverage our scale to further penetrate existing markets and strengthen our positions in China, India and the United States,
by capitalizing on strong and growing demand in our Data Center business in the Americas as well as in our HVAC and
Carbon Capture Storage solutions in Green Tech market applications. In RT and MCS, we intend to increase production
capacity and optimize production locations in the United States as well as build up a dedicated sales team for the
Transportation market. In the APAC region, we plan to continue to focus on product localization in the region and investing
in our sales and distribution networks.

**_Continue to reduce complexity and focus on digitalization to drive operational excellence_**

We continue to pursue our strategy of operational excellence by reducing complexity and enhancing digitalization
across our functional and business areas. This means focusing on activities like “80/20” where we seek to improve the
profitability of our product range, optimizing SAP in key locations, reducing process complexity through digital tools such
as Tagetik (our financial consolidation tool) and SAP (our core ERP). We also continue to deploy tools such as Power BI
to help us, for example, manage inventory reduction and improve our supply chain management globally. In addition, we
are exploring the use of Artificial Intelligence to support our sales and engineering processes, along with implementing
SAP CPQ and LO-VC. We continue to focus on the optimization of our operational footprint, especially in EMEA region,
and ensure we are manufacturing the right products in the right place for cost optimization and customer requirements.

**History**

The origin of our heat exchangers business dates back to the foundation of the company Gesellschaft für
Entstaubungs-Anlagen (“GEA”) by Otto Happel in 1920. Since then, we have manufactured and marketed our products in
various markets, supplying customers, by means of our global sales, service and production network, in highly diverse
sectors in more than 130 countries worldwide: energy; data center, chemical industries; marine applications; HVAC and
refrigeration; environmental applications, as well as the food and beverage industries. In 1999, GEA was acquired by mg
technologies AG (the successor of Metallgesellschaft AG) and was renamed GEA Group AG in 2005. In 2014, the GEA
heat exchangers segment was acquired by Triton and formally split off from the GEA Group and, in 2015, rebranded under
the name Kelvion. In 2019, the Issuer and Mangrove LuxCo IV S.à r.l. (“Mangrove LuxCo IV”), a wholly-owned
subsidiary of the Issuer, were incorporated and Mangrove LuxCo IV acquired Galapagos BidCo S.à r.l., Luxembourg,
which held 100% of the shares in Kelvion Finance GmbH and all of its subsidiaries (together, the “Kelvion Group”) and
in ENEXIO Management GmbH and all of its subsidiaries (together, the “ENEXIO Group”). The acquisition included a
recapitalization of Galapagos Holdings S.A. and Galapagos S.A., which were the holding companies of the Kelvion Group
and the ENEXIO Group at that time. Following the recapitalization, the ENEXIO business was wound down, with disposals
of ENEXIO Hungary (2020), ENEXIO Service (2021), ENEXIO Water (2022) and the joint venture in India (2023).

In the first quarter of 2022, the project business of the Group (Kelvion Thermal Solutions) was carved out to a
separate subgroup of legal entities in connection with a potential sale. As of the date of this Offering Memorandum, the
sales process has been stopped. Management is now focusing on re-integration that may lead to certain advantages, e.g.
via sharing of best practices.

**Product Groups**

Our business operations are divided into four product groups: Refrigeration Technologies (“RT”), Machine
Cooling Systems (“MCS”), Plate Heat Exchangers (“PHE”) and Kelvion Thermal Solutions (“KTS”).

Each of our product groups primarily manages their own manufacturing and core business processes from logistics
through to production and sales. However, the product groups share, to a certain extent R&D, manufacturing and testing
facilities, as well as the support of various centralized Group functions, such as finance, human resources, IT and legal and
compliance. Each of the product groups sells to both third-party customers and to other product groups.

**_Refrigeration Technologies (RT)_**

The RT unit focuses on component business for HVAC and refrigeration applications and Data Center solutions
with significant growth potential. RT supplies a wide range of standard and customized heat exchangers for cooling and
removing heat from different types of data centers (hyperscale, colocation, modular etc.) using both air and liquid cooling
methods. The Data Center vertical market consists of cooling solutions such as air conditioning, chilling units, economizer
systems, liquid cooling systems, control systems and includes services such as consulting, installation & deployment and
maintenance and support. Our product offering includes air-cooled condensers which reject heat from refrigeration systems
and are often sold as part of a package of equipment with air coolers. RT’s customized air coolers are design-to-order units
for industrial or OEM solutions for food processing and distribution facilities. Our product offering also includes
customized radiators and dry coolers which are mainly used for power and industrial applications. Improving the energy
efficiency of commercial and industrial refrigeration equipment is essential for end users looking to reduce carbon footprint
and operating costs.

For the twelve months ended March 31, 2024, RT generated 20.5% of our revenue and 19.8% of our EBITDA,
respectively. As of and for the year ended December 31, 2023, the total Order Intake and Order Backlog for RT amounted
to €388.4 million and €240.9 million, respectively.

**_Machine Cooling Systems (MCS)_**

Through our MCS unit, we provide heat exchangers for power generation, power transmission, large engine
applications (marine and off-highway) and green applications such as biomass, green hydrogen, or renewable energies.
The business is mostly with OEM, e.g., for large engine manufacturers. However, we also engage in smaller projects, such
as solar, wind or solar photovoltaic. Our product offering includes charge air coolers, which cool down combustion-air
coming from the turbocharger before entering the engine. MCS’ shell and tube double safety heat exchangers assure the
secure handling of safety-critical media. It further includes box coolers which are fitted in the sea chest of small and
medium-sized vessels.

For the twelve months ended March 31, 2024, MCS generated 14.3% of our revenue and 28.5% of our EBITDA,
respectively. As of and for the year ended December 31, 2023, the total Order Intake and Order Backlog for MCS amounted
to €209.7 million and €92.5 million, respectively.

96


-----

**_Plate Heat Exchangers (PHE)_**

Through PHE, we provide a broad range of plate heat exchangers for a wide variety of applications in terms of
pressure and temperature demands for a wide range of customer industries. Ranging from HVAC and refrigeration to Food
& Beverage, Chemicals, Power, and Industrials. The product offering of our PHE unit includes fully welded plate heat
exchangers, used to save energy in demanding high pressure and temperature applications, as well as brazed plate heat
exchangers, often used for environmentally friendly heat pump applications. Our gasketed heat exchangers have are used
in a variety of industries as well as for heat recovery applications.

For the twelve months ended March 31, 2024, PHE generated 17.9% of our revenue and 11.8% of our EBITDA,
respectively. As of and for the year ended December 31, 2023, the total Order Intake and Order Backlog for PHE amounted
to €258.0 million and €121.6 million, respectively.

**_Kelvion Thermal Solutions (KTS)_**

KTS’ focus is our project business for demanding applications in the Oil & Gas and Chemicals vertical markets
and, similar to the RT unit, with significant growth potential in high tech data center business as well as green tech
applications such as hydrogen and Carbon Capture Storage (“CCS”) solutions. The engineering expertise of KTS plays a
key role in our differentiation against competitors. We benefit from a high degree of geographical diversification with sites
in all key regions, including Europe, NAFTA, Latin America, China and MEA. Our product offering includes air fin coolers
typically used for very large cooling requirements in different industries, _e.g., Oil & Gas and Chemicals, as well as air_
dryers which are used to remove humidity from an air stream in various process industries. Our focus in this product group
has shifted in recent years under the High Five strategy away from traditional Oil & Gas to High Tech and Green Tech
vertical markets.

For the twelve months ended March 31, 2024, KTS accounted for 44.6% of our revenue and 58.0% of our
EBITDA, respectively. As of and for the year ended December 31, 2023, Order Intake and Order Backlog for KTS
amounted to €860.1 million and €659.2 million, respectively.

**Services**

All of our product groups’ activities are complemented by a comprehensive after-sales support and services
offering. We provide services both for our own products as well as for third-party products. A predictive maintenance
approach to our service solutions forms one of the five strategic pillars for our operations. This enables us to tap into the
megatrend of a shift towards intelligent service solutions, with recent technological developments enabling smarter and
more proactive solutions and customers placing increasing value on full-service packages as a means of streamlining their
operating costs. Our service offering is not a discrete business division which we run separately from our four product
groups, because it is managed on a centralized and global basis across our product groups.

Our network of 33 service centers worldwide offers our customers availability at their location at all times. We
are continually optimizing our range of services, which include precise installation work, in-house or on-site trouble
shooting, visual inspection and performance audit as part of proactive maintenance, repair and cleaning, tube replacement,
provision of spare parts, and the chemical cleaning of product components in our own service workshops. We provide
support and assistance to our customers throughout the entire product life cycle, with a view to avoiding unscheduled
downtime due to equipment malfunctions, preventing unnecessary capex investments through equipment upgrades,
replacement of parts and regular maintenance, increasing process efficiency by ensuring optimal performance of heat
exchangers integrated within those processes, helping our customers manage and service the often varied brands (i.e., other
than our own products) they use in their operations and ensuring the proper level of skill within our customers’ own
maintenance organizations through the provision of training programs designed to ensure the competency and efficiency
of their in-house maintenance personnel. Our focus is on applying our expertise and innovation to optimally ensure the
quality, safety and efficiency of our products and our service packages, and thereby establish relationships of trust to secure
long-term partnerships with our customers.

**Competition**

The heat exchanger market is fragmented, and we are among the few global suppliers. The competitive landscape
varies significantly depending on the specific technology (shell and tube, plate, finned tube, cooling tower), business model
(project, component), end-market and geography. Depending on the region and the type of heat exchanger, we compete
with both large international and smaller regional and local competitors. We believe that our services business primarily
faces competition from local players and we currently do not expect increased competition from low cost countries.

In RT, our primary competitors include LU-VE Group, Güntner and Modine.

In MCS, our primary competitors are Modine and Vestas.

In PHE, our primary competitors include Alfa Laval, Danfoss and SWEP.

In KTS, our primary competitors include SPX, Evaptech, TAS and Verdon in the high tech market, Alfa Laval,
SNT Energy and CHART in the green market and SNT Energy and CHART in the Oil & Gas market.

**Customers**

Our products and solutions span the High Tech, Green Tech and Conventional market segments across a variety
of industries, sectors and regions. Our large base of customers operates in numerous vertical markets, including Data
Centers, HVAC, Power & Energy, Oil & Gas, Transportation and Food & Beverage. Our customer base comprises more
than 19,000 active customers (i.e., customers that have placed an order with us in the last 24 months) and repeat orders
over multiple years from more than 12,000 customers. In the year ended December 31, 2023, our ten largest customers
generated approximately 46% of our Order Intake (year ended December 31, 2022: approximately 32%), with the largest
customer generating approximately 25% of Order Intake in the year ended December 31, 2023 (year ended December 31,
2022: approximately 20%). Other than our largest customer, no single customer represented more than 5% of our Order
Intake in the years ended December 31, 2023 and 2022. Furthermore, our largest customer generated approximately 18%
of our revenue in the year ended December 31, 2023. The strength of this partnership is further demonstrated through the
significant capex investment we made, supported by this customer by funding approximately €10 million of capital
investments, through an earlier receipt of a higher milestone payment, which enabled us to increase capacity in one of our
manufacturing plants.

The primary vertical markets for RT are Data Centers, HVAC and refrigeration.

The vertical markets for MCS primarily include Chemicals, Electric Power Generation and Distribution,
Transportation and Heavy & Light Equipment.

The end-markets for PHE primarily include HVAC and refrigeration, Food & Beverage and Electric Power
Generation and distribution.

The end-markets for KTS are Data Centers, Power and Oil & Gas.

**Suppliers and Procurement**

We purchase goods and services locally from a few hundred suppliers across all regions in which we are active
and have long-term relationships with many of our suppliers. The primary raw materials used for the manufacture of our
products are steel, copper, aluminum and titanium. We typically seek to have multiple suppliers (usually two or three) for
key materials and components and believe that we are not dependent on any single supplier. In the year ended December
31, 2023, our ten largest suppliers by supplier spend represented approximately 28% of our total supplier spend.

Our procurement department function is embedded within our supply chain management (“SCM”) organization.
It is managed centrally in line with our overarching strategy and operates at the regional/entity level, reflecting our global
matrix organization. This approach is supported by a commodity management model spanning our entire SCM
organization, with a view to standardizing our collaborations with suppliers while enabling us to benefit from the
opportunities of a global supply base, for example through pooling purchasing volumes, expertise and technical knowledge.

With the exception of the individual specific procurement contracts between individual Group companies and
with their respective suppliers, we coordinate the strategic procurement for our operational product groups centrally in
order to increase our purchasing power. The most important material groups are managed by a designated commodity
manager and representatives of such Group companies for which the commodity is particularly relevant. The main task of
this commodity team is to develop and implement commodity-specific procurement strategies. The team negotiates prices
and volumes with selected suppliers in accordance with the chosen procurement strategy. In addition, local purchasing
employees support our commodity teams by managing the relationship with our key suppliers.

Given the increasing focus on sustainability considerations at the global level, on the one hand, and the broad
array of materials we procure and the number of suppliers we have from various countries, on the other hand, our SCM
function faces challenges in its efforts to harmonize systems and processes that reflect both global and local/regional ESG
requirements. In order to manage these challenges, we have defined ESG requirements for our suppliers on the basis of the
UN Global Compact and supplemented these with country-specific elements. The verification and validation of our
suppliers’ ESG performance is conducted by means of an ESG supply chain compliance (“request for information”)
questionnaire (the “ESG Supply Chain Compliance Questionnaire”) which is shared with relevant suppliers on at least
an annual basis. The number of suppliers involved in the most recent ESG Supply Chain Compliance Questionnaire
amounted to approximately 630 and included suppliers for both direct and indirect materials and services. This allows us
to proactively address and navigate ESG concerns within our supply chain.
