**Research & Development**

Our research and development efforts are directed towards innovative new products, applicable for Green Tech
and High Tech solutions and development of new product applications. New development of products goes hand in hand
with new manufacturing technologies for core processes, including Industry 4.0 and robotic technologies to respond timely
to customer needs and satisfy joint development with customers. In addition, we cooperate with several universities and
research institutions in various countries, including renowned partners such as Fraunhofer Institutes (e.g., Fraunhofer ISE,
Fraunhofer ICT), University of Kassel, Technical University of Dresden, Nuremberg Institute of Technology Georg Simon
Ohm, Helmholtz-Zentrum Dresden-Rossendorf, Research Council for Refrigeration Technology, all in Germany, Sintef
Energy Research in Norway, the Stellenbosch University in South Africa, Politecnico di Milano in Italy and the French
government-funded technological research organization CEA (Commissariat à l’énergie atomique et aux énergies
_alternatives). These partners carry out basic and applied research for us in areas including, among others, thermodynamics_
and fluid dynamics.

As of December 31, 2023, we had more than 100 employees dedicated to R&D and 19 engineering centers around
the world. For the year ended December 31, 2023, research and development expenses amounted to €16.5 million (€14.0
million in the year ended December 31, 2022). For the twelve months ended March 31, 2024, research and development
expenses amounted to €17.4 million.

**Intellectual Property**

We apply for patents in appropriate jurisdictions to protect our intellectual property, which is often the result of
our R&D activities. We currently have patents and pending patent applications in Germany and other countries. As of the
date of this Offering Memorandum, we have more than 100 patents, trademarks and design rights registered in more than
40 jurisdictions. While these patents and patent applications are important to the business, we do not believe any individual
patent is critical to our overall business. We also protect certain confidential information and know-how as trade secrets.
Furthermore, we rely on certain trademarks for our business, such as the Kelvion logo and trademark.

**Sales and Marketing**

Our regional organizational setup includes front-end sales teams in order to drive our international expansion.
Front-end sales teams are backed by global solutions engineering (application engineering) teams specializing in defined
industrial markets and providing support and application expertise with a strong focus on key accounts and industries. This
setup allows us to benefit from the advantages of having both a local presence in the markets in which we are active, such
as close contact with our customers and knowledge of local restrictions and technical specifications, and the centralized
pooling of specific market segment and application know-how. It also enables the front-end Sales teams to expand our
product offering as needed to address regional “white spots” (i.e., markets in which we do not yet have a sufficient
presence). As of the date of this Offering Memorandum, we have approximately 650 employees working in sales related
functions.

Our Global Solutions Engineering teams, with their industry-specific focus, serve to continuously optimize
business processes such as key account coordination, technical process development and project support, thereby acting as
a bridge between the product groups and our sales teams.

Our RT, MCS, PHE and KTS are responsible for manufacturing and product line management (for example,
charge air coolers and radiators) and for implementing the reorganization of the manufacturing footprint through Group
oversight, as well as targeting cost and lead time reductions through the consolidation, standardization and modularization
of our numerous product lines. In close cooperation with the Front-End Sales and Global Solutions Engineering teams, the
product areas are also driving the development of innovative products to address future market demand.

**_Tender Process and Project Controlling_**

We follow a standardized tender evaluation process through an internal tender review and approval system
supported by a digital tender review and approval system. Our tender review and approval system is built to support an
upfront assessment of risks and commercial conditions that need to be fulfilled before we submit a binding offer, including
an in-depth analysis to understand the specific technical requirements of potential clients. Depending on the expected
contract value, different approval levels are required, with significant contracts requiring the approval of our executive
management. While we are participating in tenders, our strategy is to establish ourselves as a long-term solutions provider
being able to meet customer requirements not only on a technology level, but also in terms of scale and capacity.

In order to mitigate the risk of fluctuations in commodity and material process, we aim to freeze the most relevant
material purchases by procurement binding offers prior to providing a quote to the customer. In addition, in recent years
we have started to successfully include material price escalation clauses in contracts with our customers in order to mitigate
adverse price fluctuations.

In addition, we conduct weekly reviews to monitor our performance across our projects.

**Environmental, Safety and Governance (ESG)**

ESG considerations are a key aspect of our corporate strategy aimed at securing our future as a strong and resilient
provider of long-term value to our customers and business partners, and embodied by our “R3” approach: We aim to
**respect all employees,** **reduce unsustainable usage of resources and** **report transparently to our business partners and**
stakeholders.

As part of our efforts to combat climate change, we aim to make our operations climate neutral by 2040. By way
of a first step, we have aligned our operations and our ESG strategy, initiatives and annual targets with the 17 Sustainability
Development Goals of the United Nations, and published our first ESG report in 2023. The attainment of our CO2 reduction
targets and those of our customers calls for innovation and smart technologies – all the more reason for us to continue to
develop and promote our broad range of innovative heat exchange technologies that facilitate the conduct of sustainable
operations in various markets around the world.

As an internationally active company, we are obligated to adhere to internationally accepted conventions of a
social, political and legal nature. Responsible business practices are second nature to us, and we strive to lead by example
when it comes to our social responsibility towards our employees and society as a whole. Our ESG strategy aims to create
a responsible company culture from a diversity, equity and inclusion (“DEI”) perspective at all company levels, and we
uphold human rights, fair working conditions, environmental protection and integrity, including anti-corruption efforts.

**_Environment_**

We attach great importance to environmental protection, climate change and energy efficiency along our entire
value and production chain – from our procurement of raw materials and our product development endeavors through our
internal manufacturing processes to our end products and servicing. With our waste reduction program and continuous
reduction of our CO2 footprint through innovation and the use of smart technologies, we intend to meet our customer
expectations of high quality and resource-efficient production and supply chain management, and to be carbon neutral by
2040. In line with our strategy, we could achieve for 2023 an increase in the consumption of energy from renewable
sources, a reduction in our direct (Scope 1) greenhouse gas (“GHG”) emissions and a reduction in the disposal of both
hazardous and non-hazardous waste.

_CO2 Footprint_

Our environmental focus is also demonstrated by our use of green energy and our energy-saving endeavors at our
plants: Since our production plant in Wuhu (China) was established in 1995, it has bundled our core competences – robust
production capabilities, extensive service offerings and deep technical expertise, backed up by the innovative strength of
our local R&D departments – to supply heat exchanger solutions to customers around the globe. The first solar panels were
installed in Wuhu in 2022 and the entire roof of the production facility is equipped with solar panels, substantially reducing
our CO2 emissions with more than 4.0 MW of green electricity generated. We believe that this initiative constitutes a strong
first step towards achieving our goal of 100% usage of green energy.

Our production site in Sint Maartensdijk, the Netherlands, halved its energy consumption, reducing CO2 emissions
from approximately 1,000 tons per year to approximately 500 tons per year, between 2021 and 2023. This was primarily
attributable to significantly lower electricity usage achieved through the implementation of a range of energy-saving
measures, such as reduction of the start-up time of machines prior to working hours, checks to ensure that machines are
not automatically switched on by timers or software at the weekends, remote measurement of individual appliances and
heating and ongoing campaigns to raise awareness among employees of energy-saving behavior among all colleagues,
including regular communication and postings on information displays, as well as an ideas box. As a next step, we are
expanding our focus to include waste heat recovery: In addition to implementing internal measures in this regard, we are
also collaborating with a network of local companies, as well as the city administration, to explore and implement further
ideas for more sustainable production. We are working with an industrial company on a project to reduce our CO2 emissions
by recovering waste heat for use in heating the production halls for our air cooler units. While our low-temperature factory
heating system is already sustainable, the use of waste heat from neighboring facilities opportunistically will reduce our
natural gas requirements and thereby enable us to reduce our carbon footprint.

**_Social_**

We believe that we set high standards for sustainable and environmentally conscious behavior, not only for
ourselves but also for our suppliers. As a matter of principle, we have a policy not to buy any materials that are associated
with the exploitation of people or with child labor, and also expect our business customers to observe these standards. We
are committed to providing a safe, healthy and also inspiring working environment with fair and respectful working
conditions for all members of our workforce. We continue to pursue our zero-accident strategy to eliminate the number of
accidents and ensure safe conditions and practices at our facilities. We fundamentally uphold diversity, equity and inclusion
(“DEI”) principles in all areas of our global operations and condemn discrimination of all kinds. These core principles are
a fixed and integral part of our HR policy, and are reflected in numerous corresponding programs worldwide, such as health
and safety at work initiatives and our Whistleblower Policy.

_Safety_

We develop innovative, high-quality products and processes for our customers, and product safety is a top priority
in our business operations. Our Safety Topic of the Month (“STM”) initiative relates to a monthly publication aimed at
raising awareness among our workforce of one of a broad range of safety topics, which are of particular relevance for the
employees at our production and service facilities. The STM material is published on our intranet and on blackboards on
every production site worldwide. Each STM focuses on a specific risk and provides clear instructions for the action to be
taken to reduce said risk. In addition, a safety and risk minimization checklist is made available to those responsible for
occupational health and safety matters on site.

As part of our Health, Safety & Environment (“HSE”) program, we have defined a global baseline with a view to
improving health and safety management at all of our production sites. This involves the completion of a self-assessment
questionnaire for each of our facilities based on seven categories, such as targets, qualifications and risk assessment, with
10-15 questions each. On the basis of the scores for 2023, the following steps were identified for 2024: (i) Connection of
lower scoring sites with the high scoring sites for the categories in question; (ii) setting up internal calls for the discussion
of the specific issues; and (iii) preparation of a cross-check audits, pursuant to which the HSE Manager for one production
facility will conduct an audit of another production facility. This should help cross learning, help create standardization
and drive performance improvement. The implementation of the steps identified each year for the following year ensures
continual improvements in the scores achieved by our facilities and promotes the maintenance of a robust health and safety
culture globally: It encourages our employees to take responsibility for their own safety and that of their colleagues, to
strive to attain and follow up on HSE goals and targets, and to complete HSE qualifications and training (for staff and
supervisors). It also facilitates the identification of (occupational) HSE risks, and encourages the carrying out of regular
inspections by those responsible for health & safety at our production sites and also investigations into near misses and
actual accidents, including root cause analyses and risk assessment reviews. We have adopted a similar approach in the
areas of quality and environment.

_Diversity, Equity & Inclusion (DEI)_

DEI are core values within our organization. It is our goal to have a diverse and talented workforce that also
reflects the diversity of our stakeholders and business partners. We are committed to maintaining a diverse, equal and
inclusive corporate culture, continually implementing corresponding improvements in all of our human resources processes
to provide a working environment which is free of prejudice and in which everyone is treated equally, and to attract and
retain top talent and foster greater innovation, creativity and, at the same time, productivity. Our DEI policy sets out our

our organization: Further examination of our existing human resources processes, in particular recruitment and talent
management, to attract more women and individuals from diverse backgrounds to our company, mentoring and “bonding”

our K°Women’s Network and a new women-focused mentoring program launched in February 2024, and DEI training for
employees and management.

transaction of Galapagos S.A. and Galapagos Holding S.A., the former direct and indirect shareholders of Galapagos BidCo
S.à r.l., which resulted in a recapitalization of the operating business of the Galapagos BidCo Group, a deleveraging of the
Galapagos BidCo Group’s balance sheet and access to new debt facilities and instruments with longer tenors (the

**REGULATION**

Our business, and in particular the operation of our production sites and marketing of products, is subject to
various regulatory requirements. Applicable laws and regulations may differ from site to site as well as markets due to
different national and local laws. The regulatory requirements relate in particular to our production processes and include,
_inter alia, laws and regulations relating to (occupational) health and safety measures for employees, the technical safety_
requirements for operating machines, the use and handling of chemicals, air emissions, soil contamination and the
management and disposal of waste, hazardous and toxic substances and other materials. For our sites and operations, we
are required to obtain and hold various permits and to comply with the requirements specified therein as well as
requirements under applicable laws, regulations and standards. We are further subject to foreign trade laws and may be
required to pay export duties or customs duties on materials and products that we export or import. We are subject to further
regulations in the various jurisdictions in which we operate, including antitrust laws and zoning and occupancy laws that
generally apply to manufacturing businesses. Further, marketing and placement activities with respect to our products and
our relationships with customers, suppliers and competitors are subject to regulatory requirements. The following is an
overview of the main laws and regulations that are relevant to our activities in Germany. Local laws and regulations that
deal with similar aspects apply in other jurisdictions in which we operate production sites or sell our products.

**Environmental Laws**

**_Air Emissions_**

We are required to comply with various environmental laws and regulations. In particular, our operations are
subject to laws and regulations designed to limit emissions. In Germany, the construction and operation of production sites
requires active permits under the Federal Emissions Protection Act (Bundes-Immissionsschutzgesetz, the “BimSchG”),
which encompasses various other licenses, authorizations and approvals necessary for the construction and operation of
facilities pursuant to other laws. The permits typically provide for a variety of auxiliary conditions aimed at protection of
other interests, such as neighbors and the environment. As part of our obligations under the BImSchG and supplementing
laws, regulations and standards, we are required to observe the emission standards set under the Technical Instructions on
Air Quality Control (Technische Anleitung Luft – the “TA Luft”), a revised version of which entered into force on
December 1, 2021.

In general, to the extent the respective facility operated in compliance with its legally definitive permits and
applicable laws and regulations, the operation of the facility can generally not be challenged or contested by third parties.
However, proportionate measures to mitigate any negative impact of a facility on the environment or neighbors may be
required; including, _e.g., adherence to stricter emissions thresholds. For instance, permits may be amended and_
administrative orders under the BimSchG may impose certain limitations (e.g., stricter requirements with regard to
permissible emissions or the use of the relevant facilities), with which we have to comply. To the extent certain measures
based on state-of-the-art technology are impossible or economically disproportionate to implement in light of extraordinary
costs, the regulator may grant certain privileges to the relevant facility (e.g., less strict emission thresholds than expected
with state-of-the-art technology). To the extent new legal standards are introduced, permits are dynamic and will, in general,
be adjusted so they meet the relevant new standards. Non-compliance of the operator with applicable permits, other
administrative decisions, laws, regulations or standards may also lead to a (temporary) restriction or, in severe cases, a
prohibition of further operation. The competent authority may also impose administrative fines or, in exceptional cases,
even ask for removal of the facility. Furthermore, non-compliance may result in additional administrative, civil or even
criminal liability as well as reputational damage, depending on the individual case.

**_Carbon Emissions_**

The EU ETS imposes an EU-wide emissions cap applying to the total amount of greenhouse gas emissions that
can be emitted by in-scope operations and provides for the trade with allowances for such emissions for certain sectors and
companies. The EU ETS was implemented in Germany with the German Greenhouse Gas Emission Trading Act
(Treibhausgas-Emissionshandelsgesetz, the “TEHG”). The provisions of the German Greenhouse Gas Emission Trading
Act provide that the facility operators subject to emissions trading are obliged to obtain a license to emit greenhouse gases,
to comply with a cap on emission allowances allocated to them and to maintain a monitoring process to determine and
documents their emissions. For newer facilities, this permit is typically integrated into the BImSchG permit. The regulations
also provide for the possibility of trading surplus allowances on the open market. The allowances are traded in certain
trading periods, which requires certain energy and industry sectors to comply with the applicable greenhouse gas emissions
caps. Overall, only a limited number of allowances—determined in advance for the trading period—are available to
emission sources, subject to the EU ETS. Participation in this system has been mandatory since 2005 for all industries with
high energy consumption levels.

The overall availability of emission allowances allocated free of charge has been constantly reduced over the
different trading periods. Under the revised EU ETS, the EU-wide quantity of emission allowances allocated annually is
reduced by a linear factor of 4.3% per year from 2024 compared to the average annual total quantity of emission allowances

104


-----

issued in the EU between 2008 and 2012 (which equals an annual reduction of 87,924,231 allowances to be issued in the
EU) and of 4.4% as from 2028 (or 89,968,981 per year). To achieve the target of cutting EU emissions by at least 55%
compared to 1990 by 2030 and to achieve climate neutrality within the EU by 2050, a further reduction of 90 million
allowances in 2024 and further 27 million allowances in 2026 will be made in accordance with Regulation (EU) No
2021/1119 establishing the framework for achieving climate neutrality (the “European Climate Law”). Based on this
reduction path, the total quantity of newly issued allowances will be zero in 2040. Until then, the transitional free allocation
of allowances will continue on a reduced rate. On June 5, 2023, the Directive 2023/959/EU amending the Emissions
Trading Directive 2003/87/EC (the “Emissions Trading Directive”) entered into force. According to the amended version
of the Emissions Trading Directive, the free allocation will be reduced to 0% until 2030 for most sectors, except for district
heating, which will continue to receive a free allocation of 30%. As a result, affected companies whose emissions exceed
their emission allowances will have to purchase a considerable and steadily increasing proportion of increasingly pricy
emission allowances in auctions, which may result in substantial additional cost for such companies. A further exemption
is available for certain energy-intensive industries which are exposed to a significant risk of relocation of plants to countries
with less stringent climate protection laws (“Carbon Leakage”). Since 2010, the European Commission determines every
five years which industries are threatened by Carbon Leakage. The designated industries are allocated 100% emission
allowances free of charge for the period until 2030. However, the allocation of 100% does not necessarily mean that the
allocation is in line with the demand. The product benchmarks, which determine the amount of allowances allocated free
of charge, are based on the average performance of the 10% most efficient facilities in a sector or subsector in the Union
and will decline by 0.3 to 2.5% per year, calculated from the year 2008, taking into account expected emission reductions
due to technological progress.

Some of the Carbon Leakage industry sectors may apply for financial compensation for the increase of electricity
costs due to the costs of EU ETS allowances being passed on to electricity prices. The compensation is not enforceable and
is granted from funds provided in the federal budget for that purpose for the relevant year.

**_Chemicals Legislation and Regulations_**

We use a number of chemicals and hazardous substances in our production processes and are therefore subject to
Regulation (EC) No 1907/2006 concerning the Registration, Evaluation, Authorisation and Restriction of Chemicals, as
amended from time to time (“REACH”). REACH aims to ensure a high level of protection of human health and the
environment, including the promotion of alternative methods for assessment of hazards of substances, as well as free
movement of substances on the internal market while promoting competitiveness and innovation. REACH standardizes
chemicals legislation within Europe, placing greater responsibility on industry participants – encompassing manufacturers,
importers, downstream users and distributors – making them responsible for the safety of the substances, mixtures and
articles placed on the market of the European Economic Area (the “EEA”) for industrial, professional and consumer use.
REACH sets out general rules for the marketing of substances, mixtures and articles in the EEA, and imposes various
obligations which vary according to the hazardous properties of the substances, their form, quantity and concentration, as
well as the role of the actors in the supply chain. Applicable obligations may include, e.g., the duty to register substances,
notify substances in articles to the European Chemicals Agency (the “ECHA”), duty to communicate information in the
supply chain and down to the customers, duty to comply with restrictions and/or authorization requirements.

In addition, we are subject to the provisions of the German Chemicals Act (Gesetz zum Schutz vor gefährlichen
_Stoffen—Chemikaliengesetz, the “ChemG”) and related ordinances (Rechtsverordnungen), most notably the Hazardous_
Substances Regulation (Gefahrstoffverordnung). The ChemG and supplementing regulations are intended to minimize the
risks from chemicals for humans and the environment. Based on the ChemG and related regulations, the competent
authorities have, among other things, the authority to require that certain materials or chemicals (i) may either not be
produced, marketed or used at all, (ii) may only be produced, marketed or used in a certain manner or for specific purposes,
(iii) may only be used under certain circumstances or (iv) may only be distributed to certain persons.

Regarding the transportation of dangerous goods at the international level the European Agreement concerning
the International Carriage of Dangerous Goods by Road as of September 30, 1957 (Accord européen relative au transport
_international des marchandises Dangereuses par Route, the “ADR”) as amended on January 1, 2023 and implemented_
into German law through the Dangerous Goods Regulation for Road, Rail and Inland Navigation (Gefahrgutverordnung
_Straße, Eisenbahn und Binnenschifffahrt) includes provisions applicable to the carriage of dangerous goods on roads._
Pursuant to the ADR, dangerous goods, as a general rule, may be carried internationally in road vehicles subject to
compliance with a number of conditions, such as packaging and labeling requirements. Specific dangerous goods (e.g.,
goods which are poisonous and explosive at the same time) are excluded from carriage on the road.

**_Soil Contamination_**

Pursuant to the German Federal Soil Protection Act _(Bundes-Bodenschutzgesetz, the “BBodSchG”), the_
responsibility for residual pollution and harmful changes to the soil lies with the party who caused a harmful soil change
or a contaminated site (polluter), its universal successor, the relevant property owner, the occupant of the relevant real
property and, if the title was transferred after March 1, 1999, the previous owner of the property, if they knew or must have

105


-----

known about the contamination. Under the BBodSchG, liability is not based on culpability, meaning that any of the abovementioned parties alone or together may be held liable for a contamination irrespective of any negligence or intent on their
part. Determining the party to be held liable for contamination-related measures lies in the discretion of the competent
authority. There is no predetermined statutory order in which the aforementioned parties can be required by the competent
authority to carry out remediation measures. When exercising its discretion, the competent authority takes into account the
effectiveness of remediation as a prevailing factor. Thus, the current owner of the contaminated property will generally be
held primarily liable, as he is usually in the best position to carry out the necessary remediation work. However, the party
that carried out the remediation work may be able to claim compensation from the other responsible parties irrespective of
which party is held liable by the competent local authority. Unless otherwise agreed upon, the obligation to provide
compensation under the BbodSchG, as well as the extent of such compensation, depends on the degree to which the hazard
or damage was primarily attributable to one party or the other. Liability is not based on culpability. Therefore, the
BbodSchG does not require the competent authority to prove negligence or intent on the part of the liable parties.

According to the BbodSchG the competent authority may require risk inspections, investigations, remedial
measures, including clean-up or containment, and other measures necessary for the protection of the soil and the prevention
of residual contamination or other harmful soil changes and related (ground)water contamination.

Regarding other environmental media, _e.g., (ground)water or protected natural resources, other laws, such as,_
_inter alia, the Federal Water Management Act (Wasserhaushaltsgesetz, the “WHG”) and the Environmental Damage Act_
(Umweltschadensgesetz, the “UschadG”) provide for further contamination-related liability of, in particular, polluters and
facility operators.

**Product Regulation**

Our heat exchange products are subject to certain product regulations in the countries where they are placed on
the market.

In the EU, product regulations such as Regulation (EU) No 2023/1230 of the European Parliament and of the
Council of 14 June 2023 (the “EU Machinery Regulation”) and Directive 2014/68/EU (the “EU Pressure Equipment
**Directive”), which provides for strict obligations with regard to product traceability, are relevant for our product portfolio.**
These Directives provide the regulatory basis for the harmonization of the essential health and safety requirements for
machinery and pressure equipment at EU level. As a manufacturer of heat exchangers, we must implement a conformity
assessment procedure to ensure compliance with those requirements, issue a declaration of conformity and affix the CE
marketing on the products. The EU Pressure Equipment Directive was implemented into German law by the Product Safety
Act (Produktsicherheitsgesetz, the “ProdSG”), which regulates the safety requirements for products brought to the German
market to ensure they do not present a risk to health and safety when properly installed, maintained, and used as intended.

Further, Commission Regulation (EU) No 206/2012 on eco-design requirements for air conditioners and comfort
fans and Commission Regulation (EU) No 327/2011 of March 30, 2011 with regard to eco-design requirements for fans
driven by motors with an electric input power between 125 W and 500 kW apply for our products. As we are distributors
of these products our customers expect compliance with eco-design requirements as with any other applicable regulation.
Under these Regulations related to eco-design, air conditioners must, _e.g., comply with requirements related to energy_
efficiency and sound power. As we manufacture and distribute heat exchangers containing substances depleting the ozone
layer we must further comply with the respective legislation. In the EU, for instance, Regulation (EU) 2024/590 of the
European Parliament and of the Council of 7 February 2024, provides for a gradual phase out of hydro-chloro-fluor-carbons
(HCFC), which are, inter alia, used in air conditioning equipment. In addition, the use of certain fluorinated greenhouse
gases in air conditioning systems of motor vehicles is gradually prohibited through Directive 2006/40/EC of May 17, 2006.
Similar restrictions may apply outside the EU in the United States implementing the Montreal Protocol on Substances that
Deplete the Ozone Layer of September 16, 1987, as amended.

Compliance with product regulations is enforced by the authorities on a random sample basis, whistleblowing or
notifications of competitors. The authorities may investigate the facts and issue orders, in a worst case scenario sales bans,
corrective actions and product recalls.

**Product Liability**

Marketing our products we are subject to provisions on product liability and may, therefore, be held liable in cases
of damage caused by a defective product manufactured by us. In the EU, for example, Directive 85/374/EEC of July 25,
1985, as amended by Directive 1999/34/EC of May 10, 1999 (the “Product Liability Directive”) applies to movables
which have been industrially produced. It establishes the principle of objective liability (liability without fault of the
producer) in cases of damage caused by a defective product. The Directive applies to damage caused by death or by personal
injuries and damage to an item of property intended for private use or consumption, with a lower threshold of €500. The
Product Liability Directive imposes no financial cap on a producer’s liability, yet it allows EU member states to cap a
producer’s liability for damages from death or personal injury caused by identical items with the same defect at no less

106


-----

than €70 million. Furthermore, the Product Liability Directive does not bar EU member states from offering injured parties
more comprehensive or extra rights under contractual or non-contractual liability grounds.

In September 2022, the European Commission published a draft proposal to update the Product Liability Directive.
This revision aims to modernize the regulations governing product liability for the digital era, create equal conditions for
manufacturers inside and outside the EU, and enhance consumer protection by easing the proof required in liability claims.

After preliminary discussions on this proposal, a compromised draft was agreed upon on January 24, 2024. The
European Parliament officially approved the updated Product Liability Directive in March 2024. Its formal ratification by
the European Council, announcement in the Official Journal of the European Union, and subsequent implementation are
anticipated in the first half of 2024. Once in effect, member states will have 24 months to incorporate the revised directive
into their national laws. However, the new Product Liability Directive does not allow any derogations in order to achieve
a higher or lower level of protection.

In Germany, the Product Liability Directive has been transposed into national law through the enactment of the
Product Liability Act (Produkthaftungsgesetz, the “ProdHaftG”).

**Occupational Health and Safety**

According to national and international provisions, we are in most jurisdictions obliged to take measures related
to health and safety at work. Knowledge of hazardous substances and associated health and safety risks are dynamic and
develop over time as the related standards do. In this context, we must, for example, perform risk assessments, maintain
registers of hazardous substances and issue working instructions to ensure the safe handling of hazardous substances and
manufacturing equipment by our employees. In general, compliance with employment safety regulations is subject to
regulatory supervision. We ensure compliance with the applicable legal requirements to protect health and safety for
humans involved in our operations. We seek to apply uniform health and safety standards across our business.

We are, in particular, subject to the Workers Protection Act (Arbeitsschutzgesetz, the “ArbSchG”) and the
German Hazardous Substances Regulation (Gefahrstoffverordnung, the “GefStoffV”). The latter in particular ensures the
safe handling and use of hazardous substances during production, and proper classification and labeling of products, and
provides comprehensive safety information to users and workers involved in maintenance and disposal activities.

**Data Privacy**

We are subject to laws across several jurisdictions regarding privacy and protection of personal data. Laws and
regulations related to data protection, privacy, cyber-security and other laws and regulations can be very stringent and vary
from jurisdiction to jurisdiction. These laws govern how companies collect, process, and share personal data, grant rights
to data subjects, and require that companies implement specific information security controls to protect certain types of
information.

In the European Union and the EEA, the principles on the legitimate processing of personal data are laid down in
the GDPR as well as national legislation supplementing the GDPR (such as the German Federal Data Protection Act
(Bundesdatenschutzgesetz, the “BDSG”). Personal data is defined broadly and includes any information related to an
identified or identifiable natural person (data subject). The GDPR implements stringent requirements obligations and
restrictions for, among other things, the collection, storage, transfer and other processing of personal data, in particular
(without limitation) for lawful processing, transparency, data subject rights, international data transfers, storage limitation,
data mapping and accountability, processor (service provider) obligations, joint controllership, notification of data breaches
and the requirement to designate a data protection officer.

The collection of personal data is confined strictly to specified, explicit and legitimate purposes, and the
processing of this data must be in alignment with these purposes. Furthermore, personal data must be adequate, relevant,
and limited to the purposes for which it is processed (principle of data minimization). The processing must be carried out
in a way that guarantees transparency, fairness, and appropriate security of the personal data. As a consequence, the GDPR
requires us to inform data subjects regarding, among others, the manner in which their personal data is collected, utilized,
and processed, the legal justification for its processing, and the entities with which their personal data is shared.

In addition, the GDPR and local data protection rules provide strict requirements on the processing of sensitive
personal data (so-called special categories of personal data), like genetic and health data of individuals, including on the
implementation of appropriate technical and organizational measures to ensure security of this data. Accordingly, certain
cyber-security requirements must be fulfilled to ensure that data is processed and stored safely. We are required to
implement appropriate technical and organizational measures to ensure a level of security appropriate to the organization’s
processing requirements and risk. Organizations must notify the relevant supervisory authority about data breaches within
certain time limits and, in some instances, provide notification to data subjects.

107


-----

In general, the transfer of personal data to third counties or international organizations outside the EU/EEA is
permitted only when certain steps are taken to ensure an adequate level of protection. In relation to data transfers from the
EU/EEA to the United States, the European Commission adopted its adequacy decision for the EU-US Privacy Shield in
July 2023 to facilitate EU-US data transfers. The GDPR requirements apply not only to third-party transactions, but also
to transfers of information between us and our subsidiaries, including employee information.

The GDPR and the BDSG introduced substantial sanctions for non-compliance and, depending on the nature of
the infringed provision, may consist of civil liabilities, cease-and-desist orders from competitors, criminal sanctions and/or
administrative fines, and adverse publicity and reputational damages. Administrative fines can amount to EUR 20 million
or up to 4% of the total worldwide annual sales of the preceding year, whichever is higher, for each violation. Even the
perception of privacy concerns, whether valid or not, may harm our reputation. The occurrence of any of these risks could
have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations and cash flows.

We are subject to evolving EU and national privacy laws on the use of cookies, tracking technologies and emarketing practices. In the EU, informed consent is required for the placement of certain cookies that are not technically
essential for use or similar tracking technologies on an individual’s device and for direct electronic marketing. Consent is
tightly defined and includes a prohibition on pre-checked consents and a requirement to obtain separate consents for each
type of cookie or similar technology. In Germany, the use of internet tracking technologies is regulated in the German
Telecommunications Digital Services Data Protection Act (Telekommunikation-Digitale-Dienste-Datenschutz-Gesetz, the
“TDDDG”) which implements Directive 2002/58/EC (the “ePrivacy Directive”) and applies in addition to the
requirements under the GDPR.

Furthermore, based on the EU and German Data and Digital Strategies, there are several initiatives pending and
new laws passed aimed at establishing a single, uniform digital European market with robust cyber-security requirements,
including the Digital Services Act, the Data Act, the Directive EU 2022/2557 on the resilience of critical entities (so-called
NIS2 Directive), and the Cyber Resilience Act. In addition, the Artificial Intelligence Act that was approved by the Council
on May 21, 2024.

**German Supply Chain Due Diligence Act**

The German Supply Chain Due Diligence Act (Lieferkettensorgfaltspflichtengesetz, the “LkSG”) requires
companies to manage certain human rights and environmental risks in their (global) supply chains by means of a cascade
of risk management measures, including, e.g., risk assessment, preventive and remediation measures as well as maintaining
a grievance mechanism/complaints procedure and reporting to the competent authority.

Since January 2024, the LkSG obligates companies with a workforce of, in principle, at least 1,000 employees in
Germany that have their headquarters, main administration, administrative headquarters, legal domicile, or a branch in
Germany to ensure that the canon of protected human rights and environmental obligations set out in the law are not
infringed and that corresponding risks are minimized and mitigated, both in their own business areas and in their wider
supply chain. The protected legal positions under the LkSG include, in particular, protection from child and forced labor,
slavery, disregard of occupational safety obligations and freedom of association, protection from discrimination and
withholding of adequate wages, protection from certain environmental pollutions, as well as land expropriation, torture and
cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment. Companies must also consider environmental obligations from a set of three
internationally recognized agreements, namely the Minamata Convention, the Stockholm Convention on Persistent Organic
Pollutants, and the Basel Convention. The specific content of the statutorily required systemic and dynamic corporate risk
management depends on a variety of factors, such as the nature and scope of the business (including the risks of the specific
industry and business and the type of products), as well as the company’s ability to influence the immediate cause.

All supply chain due diligence risk management is required to be on-going, as it should be carried out and/or its
effectiveness reviewed annually as well as on an ad hoc basis if the in-scope company has reason to expect a significantly
changed or significantly expanded risk situation in the supply chain, e.g., due to the introduction of new products, projects
or new business fields, or information received through the complaints procedure/grievance mechanism.

Enforcement rests with a federal authority, the BAFA, and may be initiated ex officio or by individual application
of an affected party. Should enterprises not adhere to their legal responsibilities, they could face administrative penalties.
These penalties can reach up to 2% of the enterprise’s yearly worldwide turnover. The system of fines based on revenue is
specifically applicable to enterprises generating over €400 million in annual revenue. Additionally, enterprises might be
disqualified from receiving public contracts if they are subjected to an administrative fine that exceeds a specified minimum
threshold.

108


-----

**European Corporate Sustainability Due Diligence Directive**

In addition, the European Commission, the Council of the European Union and the European Parliament have
agreed on a joint draft of the Corporate Sustainability Due Diligence Directive (“CSDDD”) on December 14, 2023. The
EU Parliament adopted the CSDDD on April 24, 2024 and the Council of the EU formally adopted the CSDDD on May
24, 2024. The CSDDD still needs to be transposed into national law.

The CSDDD will affect companies of more than 1,000 employees with a turnover of more than EUR 450 million.
It aims to foster sustainable and responsible corporate behavior in companies’ operations and across their global value
chains. To this end, the directive establishes a corporate due diligence duty for companies, requiring them to identify,
prevent, mitigate, address, and account for potential and actual adverse human rights and the environment impacts in the
company’s own operations, their subsidiaries and, where related to their value chain(s), those of their business partners.
Additionally, the CSDDD obligates large companies to adopt and put into effect, through best efforts, a transition plan for
climate change mitigation aligned with the 2050 climate neutrality objective of the Paris Agreement as well as intermediate
targets under EU climate law.

Under the CSDDD, companies are expected to integrate due diligence into their policies and management systems. They
must conduct due diligence regularly, take appropriate measures to address potential and actual adverse impacts and risks,
and publicly communicate on their due diligence efforts. The CSDDD also includes provisions for enforcement and access
to legal remedies for those affected by companies’ failure to comply with their risk management and due diligence
obligations. It aims to level the playing field for businesses in the EU by ensuring that all companies adhere to the same
high standards of corporate responsibility, thereby contributing to a sustainable economy and a better future.

**Super Senior Facilities Agreement**

**_Overview and structure_**

The Issuer and the Initial Guarantors are parties to a €235.0 million super senior facilities agreement to be dated
on or around the date of this Offering Memorandum (“Super Senior Facilities Agreement” and the multi-currency
revolving credit facility thereunder shall be referred to as the “Cash RCF Facility” and the bank guarantee Facility
thereunder shall be referred to as the “L/G RCF **Facility,” and the Cash RCF Facility and the L/G RCF Facility shall**
jointly be referred to as the “Super Senior Facilities”) with, among others, DEUTSCHE BANK
AKTIENGESELLSCHAFT, COMMERZBANK Aktiengesellschaft, ING Bank N.V., J.P. Morgan SE, National
Westminster Bank Plc, UniCredit Bank GmbH and Zurich Insurance Europe AG as mandated lead arrangers (together the
“Mandated Lead Arrangers”), certain affiliates of the Mandated Lead Arrangers and certain other institutions as original
lenders (together the “Original Lenders”), Deutsche Bank AG, London Branch as agent (the “Agent”) and as security
agent (the “Security Agent”).

The Super Senior Facilities Agreement provides for borrowings under the Cash RCF Facility of up to an aggregate
initial principal amount of €65.0 million and guarantees under the L/G RCF Facility of up to an aggregate principal amount
of €170.0 million on a committed basis. In addition, the Super Senior Facilities Agreement permits the incurrence of
“additional revolving facilities” and “additional guarantee facilities” (see “Description of Certain Financing
_Arrangements—Super Senior Facilities Agreement—Additional facilities”)._

The Cash RCF Facility may be utilized by any current or future borrower (subject to certain restrictions) under
the Cash RCF Facility in euro or certain other currencies by the drawing of cash advances and by way of ancillary facilities;
and the L/G RCF Facility may be utilized by any current or future borrower (subject to certain restrictions) under the L/G
RCF Facility in euro or certain other currencies by way of ancillary facilities.

Subject to certain exceptions, loans and guarantees may be borrowed, repaid and re-borrowed at any time.

Borrowings under the Cash RCF Facility are available to be used to (directly or indirectly) finance or refinance
the general corporate purposes and/or working capital requirements of the Issuer and its restricted subsidiaries (the
“Restricted Group”) including, without limitation, to refinance and/or repay existing revolving credit and receivables
financing arrangements of the Restricted Group (including factoring, securitization and other similar receivables
financings) and the financing and/or refinancing of (i) capital expenditure and related costs and expenses, (ii) acquisitions,
investments, joint ventures and related costs and expenses, (iii) operational restructurings and reorganizations of the
Restricted Group and related costs and expenses, (iv) payments (including to be made to vendors) in respect of working
capital related adjustments (howsoever structured) relating to or in connection with any acquisition, (v) payment of any
refundable VAT on any fees, costs or expenses related to or incurred or charged in connection with the finance documents
for the Notes, Super Senior Facilities and any other document designated as a “Transaction Document” under the Super
Senior Facilities Agreement by the Agent and Mangrove LuxCo IV or any acquisition and any original issue discount, fees,
flex and/or other related financing costs and/or (vi) interest payments due in respect of the Notes and any other
indebtedness.

Amounts utilized under the L/G RCF Facility shall be applied by the Issuer and its Restricted Group towards (i)
refinancing existing letters of credit and performance bonds of the types listed under sub-paragraph (ii) entered into, used
and/or needed by the Group and (ii) in the ordinary course of business of the Restricted Group, including but not limited
to operational business requirements of the Restricted Group such as warranty obligations, performance obligations,
advance payment obligations, tender obligations, rental obligations, customs obligations and similar letters of credit to
guarantee obligations of the Restricted Group in the ordinary course of business including, for the avoidance of doubt, (y)
back to back guarantees (issued to, inter alios, financial institutions) for outstanding obligations under such instruments
and (z) any existing guarantees which are rolled in, but excluding in each case any letter of credit or similar instrument
which constitutes a credit guarantee or similar credit security instrument securing financial obligations.

Mangrove LuxCo IV (the “Company”) and Kelvion Holding GmbH will be the “original borrowers” and the
Issuer, together with the Initial Guarantors, will be the “original guarantors” under the Super Senior Facilities.

114


-----

**_Interest Rate and Fees_**

_Interest rates_

The interest rate on cash advances under the Cash RCF Facility will be the rate per annum equal to the aggregate
of the applicable margin and (a) in respect of Term Rate Loans, EURIBOR in relation to cash advances in euro, Term
SOFR in relation to cash advances in U.S. dollars or the applicable Term Reference Rate for cash advances in any other
currency (in each case as such term is defined in the Super Senior Facilities Agreement) and (b) in respect of Compounded
Rate Loans, the Compounded Reference Rate for that day for that Compounded Rate Currency (in each case as such term
is defined in the Super Senior Facilities Agreement) (each with a zero floor). Following the date that is the end of the
second full fiscal quarter date after the Issue Date and provided that no Material Event of Default or Compliance Certificate
Event of Default (as each such term is defined in the Super Senior Facilities Agreement) has occurred and is continuing,
the margin on the Cash RCF Facility will be subject to reduction if certain “senior secured net leverage ratios” (which are
to be calculated in the same way as the “Consolidated Senior Secured Net Leverage Ratio” under and as defined in the
Indenture for the Notes (see “Description of the Notes—Certain Definitions”) are met.

_Commitment fees_

A commitment fee will be payable on the aggregate undrawn and uncancelled amount of the Cash RCF Facility
from (and including) the Issue Date to (and including) the last day of the availability period for the Cash RCF Facility cat
a rate of the applicable percentage of the then applicable margin for the Cash RCF Facility. The commitment fee will be
payable quarterly in arrears, on the last day of the availability period of the Cash RCF Facility and on the date the Cash
RCF Facility is cancelled in full or on the date on which a lender cancels its commitment.

A commitment fee will be payable on the aggregate undrawn and uncancelled amount of the L/G RCF Facility
from (and including) the Issue Date to (and including) the last day of the availability period for the L/G RCF Facility
computed at a rate set out in the relevant ancillary facility but in any event not exceeding a rate of the applicable percentage
of the applicable guarantee fee for the L/G RCF Facility. The commitment fee will be payable quarterly in arrears, on the
last day of the availability period of the L/G RCF Facility and on the date the L/G RCF Facility is cancelled in full or on
the date on which a lender cancels its commitment.

The guarantee fee for letters of credit or guarantees issued under the L/G RCF Facility will be agreed with each
ancillary lender under the L/G RCF Facility on a bilateral basis. If letters of credit are cash collateralized and continue to
be provided, the guarantee fee shall be as agreed between the Company and the relevant ancillary lender. The Company or
the relevant Borrower shall also pay (or procure that payment is made) to the relevant ancillary lender under an ancillary
facility related to the L/G RCF Facility an issuance/administration fee in the amount and at the times specified in the
relevant ancillary facility agreement.

In relation to any additional Cash RCF Facility and/or additional L/G RCF Facility (the “Additional **Facility”),**
the Company shall pay (or shall procure that another Obligor shall pay) to the Agent (for the account of each relevant
Additional Facility Lender (as defined in the Super Senior Facilities Agreement)) a commitment fee (if any) in the amounts,
and at the times, specified in any relevant Additional Facility Notice (as defined in the Super Senior Facilities Agreement).

No commitment fee shall be payable unless the Issue Date occurs. The Company is not required to pay any
commitment fees to a lender for so long as such lender is a defaulting lender.

Default interest will, to the fullest extent permitted by law, subject to being in compliance with Article 1154 of
the Luxembourg Civil Code, be calculated as an additional 1% on the overdue amount.

_Other fees_

The Company is also required to pay customary agency fees to the Agent and the Security Agent in connection
with the Super Senior Facilities.

**_Availability_**

The Cash RCF Facility may, subject to satisfaction of customary conditions precedent, be utilized from (and
including) the Issue Date to (and including) the date falling one month prior to its maturity date. The L/G RCF Facility
may, subject to satisfaction of customary conditions precedent, be utilized from (and including) the Issue Date to (and
including) the date falling one day prior to its maturity date.

115


-----

**Maturity and Repayment Requirements**

Each Super Senior Facility matures on the date falling on the earlier of (i) the date falling 4 years and six months
after the date of the Super Senior Facilities Agreement and (ii) the date falling six months prior to the Maturity Date of the
Notes.

Each advance under the Cash RCF Facility will be repaid on the last day of the interest period relating thereto,
subject to a netting mechanism against amounts to be drawn on such date.

All outstanding amounts under a Facility must be repaid in full on or prior to the maturity date for the relevant
Facility.

Amounts repaid by the borrowers on loans made under the Cash RCF Facility may be re-borrowed during the
availability period for that facility, subject to certain conditions.

**_Prepayment_**

The Super Senior Facilities Agreement allows for voluntary prepayments (subject to a minimum amount and
notice requirements).

The Super Senior Facilities Agreement also permits each lender to require the mandatory prepayment of all
amounts due to that lender upon:

  - a “change of control” (which comprises, generally, (i) the Issuer ceasing to directly own 100% of the total issued
share capital or all of the voting rights of the Company and (ii) the scenarios set out under the definition of “Change
of Control” under the caption “Description of the Notes—Certain Definitions”); or

  - if it becomes unlawful for the lender to perform any of its obligations (as applicable) under the Super Senior
Facilities or to fund, issue or maintain its participation in any Utilization (as defined in the Super Senior Facilities
Agreement).

If the Company or a restricted subsidiary has consummated an asset disposition and the net cash proceeds received
in connection therewith which exceed €35.0 million have not been applied for certain purposes specified in the Super
Senior Facilities Agreement within 360 days of the date of the receipt of such net cash proceeds, the Company shall also
mandatorily prepay any outstanding Cash RCF Facility loans in an amount equal to the pro rata share of the Cash RCF
Facility in such net cash proceeds within three business days.

Notwithstanding the foregoing, any ancillary lender may, as between itself and the relevant member of the
Restricted Group, agree to continue to provide such ancillary facility (with such arrangements continuing on a bilateral
basis and not as part of, or under, the finance documents for any Facility and the transaction security for such Facility shall
not, following release by the Security Agent, secure any such ancillary facility in respect of any claims that arise after such
cancellation).

To the extent that the commitments of a lender under the Cash RCF Facility are voluntarily cancelled by the Issuer
in full which the Company is entitled to do by giving five business days’ prior written notice to the Agent of such
cancellation, such lender under the Cash RCF Facility shall have the right to cancel its commitments under the L/G RCF
Facility in full within 30 days of its commitments under the Cash RCF Facility being cancelled in full, by giving not less
than 5 Business Days’ prior notice to the Issuer and the Agent, provided that the Issuer shall have 30 days after the relevant
lender giving notice of such cancellation of the commitments under the L/G RCF Facility to the Issuer and the Agent, to
cash-collateralize, replace or provide counter-guarantees for any guarantees or letters of credit then outstanding under the
relevant ancillary facility provided under the L/G RCF Facility. This shall not apply to the extent that the commitments of
all lenders under the Cash RCF Facility are reduced prior to the Acquisition Closing Date on a pro rata basis.

**_Additional Facilities_**

The Super Senior Facilities Agreement contemplates the incurrence of uncommitted “additional revolving
facilities” and “additional guarantee facilities” in a maximum amount not to exceed the aggregate sum of:

  - in respect of the Cash RCF Facility (i) the greater of (x) €65.0 million and (y) an amount equal to 45% of
consolidated earnings before interest, tax, depreciation and amortization plus certain adjustments, similar to those
in Consolidated EBITDA as set out in “Description of the Notes,” of the Restricted Group, on a pro forma basis
for the most recently ended four full fiscal quarters for which internal consolidated financial statements are
available prior to such incurrence (after giving pro forma effect to the relevant transactions) less (ii) the total Cash

RCF Facility commitment immediately before giving effect to the amount of the additional revolving facility; and

  - in respect of the L/G RCF Facility (i) the greater of (x) €190.0 million and (y) an amount equal to 130% of
consolidated earnings before interest, tax, depreciation and amortization plus certain adjustments, similar to those
in Consolidated EBITDA as set out in “Description of the Notes,” of the Restricted Group, on a pro forma basis
for the most recently ended four full fiscal quarters for which internal consolidated financial statements are
available prior to such incurrence (after giving pro forma effect to the relevant transactions)

_less (ii) the total L/G RCF Facility commitment immediately before giving effect to the amount of the_ additional L/G
RCF Facility,

Such additional revolving facilities and guarantee facilities may be incurred under the Super Senior Facilities
Agreement either as a new Cash RCF Facility, a new L/G RCF Facility and/or as an additional tranche of any existing Cash
RCF facility and/or L/G RCF Facility and/or by increasing the commitments under an existing Cash RCF Facility or an
existing L/G RCF Facility. Such additional revolving facilities and/or guarantee facilities will be secured and shall rank
_pari passu with the Super Senior Facilities and be prepaid on a_ _pro rata basis (including with respect to mandatory_
prepayments). The lenders of any such additional revolving facilities and/or guarantee facilities may not have the benefit
of guarantees from any member of the Restricted Group which is not a borrower or guarantor of the Super Senior Facilities
or security over assets other than the then existing transaction security for the Super Senior Facilities (except where the
same security (to the extent permitted by law) is granted in respect of the other facilities under the Super Senior Facilities).

The availability, maturity, pricing and other terms of any Additional Facility will be those agreed between the
Issuer and the relevant lenders of that Additional Facility, provided that (i) (in relation to an additional revolving facility)
the final maturity date of the additional revolving facility is no earlier than the Termination Date applicable to the Cash
RCF Facility (or, in each case, if at such time the Revolving Facility has been cancelled in full or would be repaid and
cancelled in full after giving effect to the application of the proceeds of the relevant Additional Facility, any final maturity
date under the Super Senior Facilities Agreement); and (in relation to an additional guarantee facility) the final maturity
date of the additional guarantee facility is no earlier than the Termination Date applicable to the L/G RCF Facility (or, in
each case, if at such time the L/G RCF Facility has been cancelled in full or would be repaid and cancelled in full after
giving effect to the application of the proceeds of the relevant Additional Facility, any final maturity date under the Super
Senior Facilities Agreement), (ii) no “material event of default” has occurred and is continuing at the time the relevant
Additional Facility is committed (unless the proceeds of the relevant Additional Facility are used to refinance existing
additional revolving facilities or guarantee facilities) and (iii) no member of the Restricted Group may provide an
Additional Facility.

**_Guarantees_**

The Super Senior Facilities is guaranteed by the Issuer and the Initial Guarantors and will be guaranteed by the
Post-Issue Date Guarantors within 120 days of the Issue Date.

The Super Senior Facilities Agreement requires that, subject to certain “agreed security principles” set out in the
Super Senior Facilities Agreement, each member of the Restricted Group that is, or becomes, a “material company” (which
is generally defined under the Super Senior Facilities Agreement to include, among other things, certain members of the
Restricted Group that have earnings before interest, tax, depreciation and amortization representing 5% or more of the
consolidated earnings before interest, tax, depreciation and amortization of the Restricted Group, and certain members of
the Restricted Group that are a direct or indirect holding company of a “material company”) after the Issue Date by
reference to the annual consolidated financial statements (the “Annual Financial Statements”) most recently delivered to
the Agent, or, at the discretion of the Company, a more recent set of financial statements of the Restricted Group for an
LTM Period; and/or if a Subsidiary has been acquired since the date as at which the latest Annual Financial Statements of
the Restricted Group were prepared, the latest annual financial statements of the relevant Subsidiary for the relevant
financial year (consolidated in the case of a Subsidiary which itself has Subsidiaries), or, if such financial statements are
not available or required by law, such other accounts as are available (commencing with the first complete fiscal year
ending after the Issue Date) will be required to become a guarantor under the Super Senior Facilities Agreement within
120 days of the date of delivery of the relevant annual consolidated or combined, as applicable, financial statements of the
Issuer for the relevant fiscal year.

Furthermore, if on the last day of each financial year of the Company (commencing with the first complete
financial year after the Acquisition Closing Date), the guarantors represent less than 80% of the consolidated earnings
before interest, tax, depreciation and amortization of the members of the Restricted Group (subject to certain exceptions)
(the “Guarantor Coverage Test”), within 120 days of delivery of the annual financial statements for the relevant financial
year (commencing with the first complete financial year after the Issue Date), such other members of the Restricted Group
(subject to the agreed security principles and certain other exceptions) are required to become guarantors until the Guarantor
Coverage Test is satisfied (to be calculated as if such additional guarantors had been guarantors on the last day of the

117


-----

relevant financial year). Members of the Restricted Group may be excluded from such calculation if (i) they are
incorporated in an Excluded Jurisdiction (as defined in the Super Senior Facilities Agreement) or (ii) there is a restriction
applicable to it in relation to becoming a guarantor.

The Company shall also ensure that the Guarantor Coverage Test is satisfied by the date which is 120 days after
(and excluding) the Issue Date (or such later date as the Agent may agree in its reasonable discretion).

**_Security_**

The Super Senior Facilities (subject to the agreed security principles set out in the Super Senior Facilities
Agreement) are secured by the Collateral as further described under “Description of the Notes—Security.”

Each direct and indirect holding company of any “material company” (provided that such holding company is a
wholly-owned member of the Restricted Group in each case with certain members of the Restricted Group being excluded,
which becomes a guarantor under any Facility is required (subject to the “agreed security principles”) to grant security over
the shares it holds in such material company in favor of the Security Agent. In addition, any “material company” or other
member of the Restricted Group which becomes a guarantor of the Super Senior Facilities is required (subject to the agreed
security principles) to grant security over certain of its material assets in favor of the Security Agent.

Under the terms of the Intercreditor Agreement, proceeds from the enforcement of the collateral (whether or not
shared with the holders of the Notes) will be required to be applied to repay indebtedness outstanding under the Super
Senior Facilities, as well as certain hedging obligations and cash management obligations, in priority to the Notes.

**_Representations and Warranties_**

The Super Senior Facilities Agreement contains certain customary representations and warranties (subject to
certain customary materiality, actual knowledge and other qualifications, exceptions and baskets, and with certain
representations and warranties being repeated on the date of each utilization request made after the Issue Date and on the
first day of each interest period), including without limitation: (i) status; (ii) binding obligations; (iii) non-conflict with
other obligations; (iv) power and authority; (v) validity and admissibility in evidence; (vi) consents and filings; (vii)
governing law and enforcement; (viii) no insolvency; (ix) no proceedings pending or threatened; (x) no filing or stamp
taxes; (xi) no events of default; (xii) taxation; (xiii) deduction of tax; (xiv) consents and filing; (xv) no filing and stamp
taxes); (xvi) pari passu ranking; (xvii) legal and beneficial ownership; (xviii) financial model; (xix) group structure; (xx)
centre of main interest; (xxi) compliance with ERISA, (xxii) margin stock; (xxiii) investment company act; (xxiv) anticorruption, anti-terrorism laws and sanctions; (xxv) no breach of laws; (xxvi) good title to assets and (xxvii) financial
statements.

**_Covenants_**

The Super Senior Facilities Agreement contains certain of the same incurrence covenants and related definitions
(with certain adjustments) that will apply to the Notes as included under the caption “Description _of the Notes—Certain_
_Covenants.”_

In addition, the Super Senior Facilities Agreement also contains certain affirmative and negative covenants, and
the Super Senior Facilities Agreement also contains a financial covenant for the benefit of lenders under the Cash RCF
Facility only. Set forth below is a brief description of such covenants, all of which are subject to customary materiality,
actual knowledge or other qualifications, exceptions and baskets.

_Affirmative Covenants_

The affirmative covenants include, among others: (i) providing certain financial information in respect of the
Restricted Group, including annual audited and quarterly financial statements and compliance certificates; (ii)
authorizations; (iii) compliance with laws; (iv) payment of taxes; (v) maintenance of pari passu ranking of the Super Senior
Facilities; (vi) access for the agent; (vii) compliance with environmental permits and laws; (viii) acquisitions; (ix)
maintenance of the guarantor and security coverage; (x) further assurance provisions and (xi) compliance with sanctions
and anti-corruption laws.

_Negative Covenants_

The negative covenants include certain restrictions, among others, with respect to (i) activity by the Issuer other
than a holding company activity; (ii) changing the center of main interest of a borrower or guarantor under any Facility;
and (iii) Notes purchases. Otherwise, the negative covenants in the Super Senior Facilities are substantially the same as the
negative covenants that will be in the Indenture.

118


-----

Certain of the incurrence covenants under the Super Senior Facilities Agreement may be suspended upon (i) the
occurrence of a “Listing” (as defined in the Super Senior Facilities Agreement) (that does not result in a “change of
control”) and the achievement of a “consolidated net leverage ratio” of the Restricted Group is equal to or less than
2.00:1.00 (generally, _pro forma for any prepayment of the Cash RCF Facility from the proceeds of such initial public_
offering) or (ii) a member of the Restricted Group or a holding company of the Issuer having achieved an investment grade
status (Baa3/BBB- or better by Moody’s or S&P, respectively).

The Super Senior Facilities Agreement also contain a “note purchase condition” covenant, which provides, subject
to certain exceptions set out in the Super Senior Facilities Agreement, that the Issuer may not, and shall procure that no
other member of the Restricted Group will, prepay, purchase, redeem, retire or otherwise acquire for value any of the
principal amount of the Notes prior to the scheduled repayment date. The exceptions to such covenant include, inter alia
(and provided that no event of default under any Super Senior Facility is continuing or would result from such note
purchase): (i) notes purchases funded with, _inter alia, certain permitted indebtedness under the Super Senior Facilities_
Agreement (other than the Cash RCF Facility); (ii) note purchases that do not exceed 50% of the aggregate face value of
the Notes in existence at the Issue Date or incurred afterwards (and any permitted refinancing thereof); or (iii) the Super
Senior Facilities (including any additional facilities) are cancelled (and if applicable prepaid) in the same or greater
proportion as the proportion of the note purchase to the aggregate face value of the Notes then outstanding, provided that
(A) the revolving facility commitments shall in no circumstances be required to be reduced below an amount equal to 60%
of the total revolving facility commitments outstanding at that time; and (B) the guarantee facility commitments shall in
no circumstances be required to be reduced below 80% of the total guarantee facility commitments outstanding at that time.

_Financial Covenant_

The Super Senior Facilities Agreement requires the Issuer to comply with a consolidated “senior secured net
leverage” financial covenant for the benefit of the lenders under the Cash RCF Facility and any additional revolving facility
which benefits from the financial covenant. The financial covenant will be tested quarterly on a rolling basis, generally,
subject to (i) the first test date falling on the date that is the end of the second full fiscal quarter date after the Issue Date
and (ii) the “test condition” being met on the relevant test date, such condition being (A) the aggregate of all outstanding
loans under the Cash RCF Facility and any springing covenant revolving facility and all outstanding cash drawings and
any letters of credit or guarantees which have been called and which remain outstanding under Ancillary Facilities (as
defined in the Super Senior Facilities Agreement) under the Cash RCF Facility or any springing covenant revolving facility
less cash and cash equivalents held by members of the Restricted Group as at such test date, which exceeds (B) 40% of the
aggregate of Cash RCF Facility commitments as at the date of the Super Senior Facilities Agreement and additional
revolving facilities established following the date of the Super Senior Facilities Agreement.

The Issuer is permitted to prevent or cure breaches of the financial covenant by applying a “cure” amount
(generally, amounts received by the Issuer in cash pursuant to any new equity or permitted shareholder subordinated debt),
including as if “consolidated earnings before interest, tax, depreciation and amortization” had been reduced by such
amount. There is no requirement to apply any such cure amount in prepayment of the Super Senior Facilities. No more
than five (in aggregate) different cure amounts may be taken into account prior to the original termination date of the Super
Senior Facilities Agreement out of which no more than two may be remedied pursuant to an EBITDA cure and more than
two EBITDA or prepayment cure amounts in any four consecutive financial quarters are not permitted.

**_Events of Default_**

The Super Senior Facilities Agreement provides for some of the same events of default, with certain adjustments,
as those applicable for the Notes as set forth in the section entitled “Description of the Notes—Events of Default.” In
addition, the Super Senior Facilities provides for certain customary events of default, all of which are subject to customary
materiality and other qualifications, exceptions, baskets and/or grace periods, as appropriate, comprising without limitation:
(i) for the benefit of lenders under the Cash RCF Facility only, breach of the financial covenant subject to possibilities to
cure the financial covenant breach; (ii) breach of other obligations subject to a 20 business day grace period; (iii)
representations or warranties found to be untrue or misleading in any material respect when made or deemed repeated
subject to a 20 business day grace period; (iv) material litigation, arbitration or administrative, governmental, regulatory
or other proceedings in relation to the finance documents or against any member of the Restricted Group or its material
assets; (v) cross default subject to thresholds; (vi) unlawfulness and invalidity subject to a 20 business day grace period;
(vii) failure to comply with a material term of the Intercreditor Agreement by a member of the Restricted Group or any
affiliate of the Issuer which is not a member of the Restricted Group subject to a 20 business day grace period; (viii)
repudiation and rescission of the finance documents and (ix) cessation of business.
