Transfers of Rule 144A Book-Entry Interests to persons wishing to take delivery of Rule 144A Book-Entry
Interests will at all times be subject to such transfer restrictions. Transfers of Rule 144A Book-Entry Interests to persons
wishing to take delivery of Rule 144A Book-Entry Interests will at all times be subject to such transfer restrictions.

Rule 144A Book-Entry Interests may be transferred to a person who takes delivery in the form of a Regulation S
Book-Entry Interest only upon delivery by the transferor of a written certification (in the form provided in the Indenture)
to the effect that such transfer is being made in accordance with Regulation S or Rule 144 under the US Securities Act or
any other exemption (if available under the US Securities Act).

Regulation S Book-Entry Interests may be transferred to a person who takes delivery in the form of a Rule 144A
Book-Entry Interest only upon delivery by the transferor of a written certification (in the form provided in the Indenture)
to the effect that such transfer is being made to a person who the transferor reasonably believes is a “qualified institutional
buyer” within the meaning of Rule 144A under the US Securities Act in a transaction meeting the requirements of
Rule 144A under the US Securities Act or otherwise in accordance with the transfer restrictions described under “Transfer
_Restrictions” and in accordance with any applicable securities laws of any other jurisdiction._

In connection with transfers involving an exchange of a Regulation S Book-Entry Interest for a Rule 144A
Book-Entry Interest, appropriate adjustments will be made to reflect a decrease in the principal amount of the relevant
Regulation S Global Note and a corresponding increase in the principal amount of the relevant Rule 144A Global Note.

Definitive Registered Notes may be transferred and exchanged for Book-Entry Interests in a Global Note only as
described under “Description of the Notes” and, if required, only if the transferor first delivers to the Transfer Agent a
written certificate (in the form provided in the Indenture) to the effect that such transfer will comply with the appropriate
transfer restrictions applicable to such Notes. See “Transfer Restrictions.”

Any Book-Entry Interest in one of the Global Notes that is transferred to a person who takes delivery in the form
of a Book-Entry Interest in any other Global Note will, upon transfer, cease to be a Book-Entry Interest in the first
mentioned Global Note and become a Book-Entry Interest in such other Global Note, and accordingly will thereafter be
subject to all transfer restrictions, if any, and other procedures applicable to Book-Entry Interests in such other Global Note
for as long as it remains such a Book-Entry Interest.

**Information Concerning Euroclear and Clearstream**

All Book-Entry Interests will be subject to the operations and procedures of Euroclear and Clearstream, as
applicable. The Issuer provides the following summaries of those operations and procedures solely for the convenience of
investors. The operations and procedures of the settlement system are controlled by the settlement system and may be
changed at any time. Neither the Issuer nor the Initial Purchasers are responsible for those operations or procedures.

The Issuer understands as follows with respect to Euroclear and Clearstream: Euroclear and Clearstream hold
securities for participating organizations. They facilitate the clearance and settlement of securities transactions between
their participants through electronic book-entry changes in the accounts of such participants. Euroclear and Clearstream
provide various services to their participants, including the safekeeping, administration, clearance, settlement, lending and
borrowing of internationally traded securities. Euroclear and Clearstream interface with domestic securities markets.
Euroclear and Clearstream participants are financial institutions such as underwriters, securities brokers and dealers, banks,
trust companies and certain other organizations. Indirect access to Euroclear and Clearstream is also available to others
such as banks, brokers, dealers and trust companies that clear through or maintain a custodial relationship with a Euroclear
and Clearstream participant, either directly or indirectly.

Because Euroclear and Clearstream can only act on behalf of participants, who in turn act on behalf of indirect
participants and certain banks, the ability of an owner of a beneficial interest to pledge such interest to persons or entities
that do not participate in the Euroclear and/or Clearstream system, or otherwise take actions in respect of such interest,
may be limited by the lack of a definitive certificate for that interest. The laws of some jurisdictions require that certain
persons take physical delivery of securities in definitive form. Consequently, the ability to transfer beneficial interests to
such persons may be limited. In addition, owners of beneficial interests through the Euroclear or Clearstream systems will
receive distributions attributable to the Rule 144A Global Notes only through Euroclear or Clearstream participants.

**Global Clearance and Settlement Under the Book-Entry System**

The Notes represented by the Global Notes are expected to be listed on the Official List of the Exchange. The
Issuer expects that secondary trading in any certificated Notes will also be settled in immediately available funds.

264


-----

The following description of the operations and procedures of Euroclear and Clearstream is provided solely as a
matter of convenience. These operations and procedures are solely within the control of the relevant settlement systems
and are subject to changes by them. None of us, the Initial Purchasers, the Trustee, the Calculation Agent, or the Paying
Agent takes any responsibility for these operations and procedures and urge investors to contact the systems or their
participants directly to discuss these matters.

**_Initial Settlement_**

Initial settlement for the Notes will be made in euro. Book-Entry Interests owned through Euroclear or Clearstream
accounts will follow the settlement procedures applicable to conventional Eurobonds in registered form. Book-Entry
Interests will be credited to the securities custody accounts of Euroclear and Clearstream holders on the business day
following the settlement date against payment for value on the settlement date.

**_Secondary Market Trading_**

The Book-Entry Interests will trade through participants of Euroclear or Clearstream and will settle in same-day
funds. Since the purchase determines the place of delivery, it is important to establish at the time of trading of any
Book-Entry Interests where both the purchaser’s and the seller’s accounts are located to ensure that settlement can be made
on the desired value date.

**_Special Timing Considerations_**

You should be aware that investors will only be able to make and receive deliveries, payments and other
communications involving Notes through Euroclear or Clearstream on days when those systems are open for business.

In addition, because of time-zone differences, there may be complications with completing transactions involving
Euroclear and/or Clearstream on the same business day as in the United States. Certain investors who wish to transfer their
interests in the Notes, or to receive or make a payment or delivery of Notes, on a particular day, may find that the
transactions will not be performed until the next business day in Brussels if Euroclear is used, or Luxembourg if
Clearstream is used.

**SERVICE OF PROCESS AND ENFORCEMENT OF CIVIL LIABILITIES**

The Issuer is incorporated under the laws of the Grand Duchy of Luxembourg and the Guarantors are organized
under the laws of Germany, the Netherlands, Poland and the United States. None of the members of board or other
executives of the Issuer and the Non-US Guarantors are residents or citizens of the United States. Therefore, you may be
unable to effect service of process within the United States on such directors, officers or executives. Furthermore, since the
assets of the Issuer and each of the Non-US Guarantors, and their respective directors and officers are located outside the
United States, any judgment obtained in the United States against the Issuer or a Non-US Guarantor or any such other
person, including judgments with respect to the payment of principal, premium (if any) and interest on the Notes or any
judgment of a US court predicated upon civil liabilities under US Federal or state securities laws, may not be collectible in
the United States.

**Luxembourg**

The Issuer is incorporated under the laws of Luxembourg. A substantial portion of the assets of the Issuer is
located outside the United States. As a result, it may not be possible for investors to effect service of process within the
United States upon the Issuer or to enforce against it judgments of U.S. courts predicated upon the civil liability provisions
of U.S. federal or state securities laws. In Luxembourg, it may be possible for investors to effect service of process upon
the Issuer and the Luxembourg Guarantors incorporated and existing under Luxembourg law within Luxembourg in
accordance with the Hague Convention on the Service Abroad of Judicial and Extrajudicial Documents in Civil or
Commercial Matters of November 15, 1965.

The United States and Luxembourg are not currently bound by a treaty providing for reciprocal recognition and
enforcement of judgments, other than arbitral awards rendered in civil and commercial matters. An enforceable judgment
for the payment of monies rendered by any U.S. Federal or state court based on civil liability, whether or not predicated
solely upon the US securities laws, would not directly be enforceable in Luxembourg. However, a party who received such
favorable judgment in a U.S. court may initiate enforcement proceedings in Luxembourg (exequatur) by requesting
enforcement of the U.S. judgment by the District Court (Tribunal d’Arrondissement) pursuant to Section 678 of the New
Luxembourg Code of Civil Procedure. The District Court will authorize the enforcement in Luxembourg of the U.S.
judgment if it is satisfied that all of the following conditions are met:

      - the U.S. judgment is enforceable (exécutoire) in the United States;

      - the U.S. court awarding the judgment must have had jurisdiction to adjudicate the respective matter both
under applicable U.S. Federal or state jurisdictions rules, and under applicable Luxembourg international
private law conflict of jurisdiction rules and local law;

      - the U.S. court has applied the substantive law as designated by Luxembourg conflict of laws rules, or at
least, the order must not contravene the principles underlying those rules (based on case law and legal
doctrine, it is not certain that this condition would still be required for an exequatur to be granted by a
Luxembourg court);

      - the U.S. judgment does not contravene international public policy or order as understood under the laws
of Luxembourg or has not been given in proceedings of a tax, penal or criminal nature (which would
include awards of damages made under civil liabilities provisions of the U.S. federal securities laws, or
other laws, to the extent that the same would be classified by Luxembourg courts as being of a penal or
punitive nature (for example, fines or punitive damages)). Ordinarily an award of monetary damages
would not be considered as a penalty, but if the monetary damages include punitive damages, such
punitive damages may be considered as a penalty;

      - the U.S. court has acted in accordance with its own procedural laws;

      - the principles of fair trial and due process have been complied with and in particular the U.S. judgment
was granted following proceedings where the counterparty had the opportunity to appear, and if it
appeared, to present a defense; and

      - the U.S. judgment was not granted pursuant to an evasion of Luxembourg law (fraude à la loi
_luxembourgeoise)._

Subject to the above conditions, Luxembourg courts tend not to review the merits of a foreign judgment, although
there is no statutory prohibition to do so.

If an original action is brought in Luxembourg, Luxembourg courts may refuse to apply the designated law (i) if
the choice of such law was not made bona fide and (ii) if its application contravenes Luxembourg public policy or is

273


-----

manifestly incompatible with Luxembourg international policy rules. In an action brought in Luxembourg on the basis of
U.S. federal or state securities laws, Luxembourg courts may not have the requisite power to grant the remedies sought.
Also, an exequatur may be refused in respect of punitive damages.

Further, in the event of any proceedings being brought in a Luxembourg court in respect of a monetary obligation
expressed to be payable in a currency other than euro, a Luxembourg court would have power to give judgment expressed
as an order to pay a currency other than euro. However, enforcement of the judgment against any party in Luxembourg
would be available only in euro and for such purposes all claims or debts would be converted into euro.

**Germany**

The Issuer has been advised by its German counsel that there is doubt as to the enforceability in Germany of civil
liabilities based on US federal or state securities laws, either in an original action or in an action to enforce a judgment
obtained in US federal or state courts. The United States and the Federal Republic of Germany currently do not have a
treaty providing for the reciprocal recognition and enforcement of judgments, other than arbitration awards, in civil and
commercial matters. Consequently, a final judgment by any US federal or state court for payment, whether or not predicated
solely upon US federal or state securities laws, would not automatically be enforceable in Germany. A final judgment by
a US federal or state court, however, may be recognized and enforced in Germany in an action before a court of competent
jurisdiction in accordance with the proceedings set forth by the German Code of Civil Procedure (Zivilprozessordnung).
In such an action, a German court generally would not reinvestigate the merits of the original matter decided by a US court,
except as noted below. German courts will, in particular, not recognize and enforce such judgements if any of the reasons
for excluding enforceability set forth in Sections 723(2), 328(1) of the German Code of Civil Procedure
(Zivilprozessordnung) exist:

    - the judgment is final under US federal or state law;

    - if, pursuant to German law, the courts in the country of the court having rendered the foreign judgement did
not have jurisdiction;

    - if process has not been duly served or has not been served in a timely fashion to permit a defense, provided
that the defendant did not actively participate in such process and pleads accordingly;

    - if the judgement is incompatible with a prior judgement rendered by a German court or by a foreign court
which is to be recognized in Germany;

    - if the proceeding resulting in the judgement to be recognized is incompatible with a previously pending
(rechtshängig) proceeding in Germany;

    - if a recognition of the judgement would be obviously incompatible with fundamental principles of German
law (order public), in particular, if the recognition would be incompatible with the civil rights under the
German Constitution (Grundgesetz); and if reciprocity is not ensured (i.e., the courts of the country where the
judgement was issued would not recognize and enforce a comparable judgement by a German court in
equivalent circumstances).

Subject to the foregoing, purchasers of securities may be able to enforce judgments in civil and commercial matters
obtained from US federal or state courts in Germany. The Issuer cannot, however, assure you that attempts to enforce
judgments in Germany will be successful.

In addition, in the past the recognition and enforcement of punitive damages has been denied by German courts
as incompatible with the fundamental principles of German law. Moreover, a German court may reduce the amount of
damages granted by a US court and recognize damages only to the extent that they are necessary to compensate actual
losses or damages. Consequently, judgements awarding monetary damages under civil liabilities provisions of the US
federal securities laws may not be enforceable to the extent they provide for a compensation that would qualify as being of
a penal or punitive nature.

German civil procedure differs substantially from US civil procedure in a number of aspects, including the
possibilities for obtaining evidence. With respect to the production of evidence, for example, US federal and state law and
the laws of several other jurisdictions based on common law provide for pre-trial discovery, a process by which parties to
the proceedings may, prior to trial, compel the production of documents by adverse or third parties and the deposition of
witnesses. Evidence obtained in this manner may be decisive in the outcome of any proceeding. No such pre-trial discovery
process exists under German law.

If the party in whose favor the final US federal or state judgement is rendered brings a new lawsuit in the same
matter in a competent court in Germany, such party may submit to the German courts the final judgement rendered in the

274


-----

United States. Under such circumstances, a judgement by a US federal or state court will be regarded by the German court
only as evidence of the outcome of the dispute to which such judgement relates. A German court may choose to re-hear
the dispute and may render a judgement that is not in line with the judgement rendered by the US federal or state court, but
the latitude to deviate from the foreign judgment is limited. The German court is free to issue a completely new decision if
there are grounds for non-recognition under 328(1) of the German Code of Civil Procedure, but must otherwise take the
foreign decision into account (i.e., the foreign judgement has a certain binding effect).

Enforcement is also subject to the effect of any applicable bankruptcy, insolvency, reorganization, liquidation or
moratorium as well as other similar laws affecting rights of creditors generally.

**Poland**

The recognition and enforcement of judgments of foreign courts in Poland is subject to limitations (i) specified in
the relevant EU laws (including in particular Council Regulation (EC) Regulation (EU) No. 1215/2012 of the European
Parliament and of the Council of December 12, 2012 on jurisdiction and the recognition and enforcement of judgments in
civil and commercial matters if the judgment was issued in a Member State of the European Union); (ii) under international
agreements, if a relevant bilateral/multilateral treaty provides for such enforcement (including in particular the Hague
Convention of June 30, 2005 on Choice of Court Agreements); or (iii) on the basis of the rules of the Polish Code of Civil
Procedure if (i) and (ii) above do not apply. There is currently no treaty between the United States and Poland providing
for the reciprocal recognition and enforcement of judgments (other than arbitration awards) rendered in civil and
commercial matters. Therefore, in such a case, the rules of the Polish Code of Civil Procedure apply. Under that procedure,
any final and conclusive judgment against the Issuer or Guarantor with its registered office in Poland obtained in a court
of the United States and arising out of or in relation to the obligations of the Issuer or Guarantors with its registered office
in Poland, would be recognized ex lege in Poland, unless:

      - the judgment is not final and binding in the US;

      - the judgment was issued on an issue which is within the exclusive jurisdiction of Polish courts (such as
matters relating to real property located in Poland);

      - the defendant who has not entered the dispute as to the essence of the disputed issue has not been served
the complaint in the manner enabling the defendant to defend himself;

      - a party was deprived of the ability to defend itself in the course of the proceeding;

      - proceedings related to the same claim between the same parties had been commenced in Poland before
it was initiated in the US court;

      - the judgment is contrary to a previously issued final and binding judgment of a Polish court or of a
foreign court judgment fulfilling the prerequisites for its recognition in Poland and was issued in
proceedings related to the same claim between the same parties; or

      - the recognition of the judgment would be contrary to the fundamental principles of legal order of Poland
(the public policy clause).

Enforceability of any final and conclusive judgment against the Issuer or a given Guarantor with its registered
office in Poland obtained in a court of the United States and arising out of or in relation to the obligations of the Issuer or
Guarantors, further requires that a Polish court issues a decision confirming that given judgment of the US court is
enforceable in Poland (which will be issued provided that given judgment is enforceable in the US and all the conditions
referred to above are met).

Once the motion to declare enforceability is considered and approved, the court issues a decision to grant an
enforceability clause (klauzula wykonalności). Enforcement pursuant to such a decision may be initiated as soon as the
decision granting the enforceability clause becomes final and binding.

Finally, it should be noted that the enforcement actions conducted by the court executive officer (bailiff) may be
challenged and, therefore, the enforcement of obligations sometimes may not be successful or may be lengthy, even if the
US judgment is recognized and enforceable in Poland.

#### Notes to Condensed consolidated Financial Statements of Mangrove Group

## 1. Fundamental information about the Group

#### 1.1 Company information

Mangrove LuxCo III S.à r.l., Luxembourg, hereinafter also referred to as "Mangrove LuxCo III" or the "company" is a public

limited liability company (Société à responsabilité limitée) incorporated under the laws of the Grand Duchy of Luxembourg,

having its registered office at 2, rue Edward Steichen, L-2540 Luxembourg, and registered with the Luxembourg Trade and

Companies Register (Registre de Commerce et des Sociétés Luxembourg) with registration number B236258. Sole

shareholder of the company is Mangrove LuxCo II S.à r.l., Luxembourg, which itself is a direct subsidiary of Galapagos LuxCo

I S.à r.l., Luxembourg. The Company was incorporated on July 11, 2019. The Beneficial Owner (investor) is Triton Fund IV

L.P which is owner of Mangrove LuxCo III. In the following, Mangrove LuxCo III and its consolidated direct and indirect

subsidiaries is referred to as "Mangrove Group" or “the Group”.

#### 1.2 Description of the business

The Mangrove Group is a leading global manufacturer of heat exchangers and other cooling & heating products. The Group

is active in multiple end markets such as Data Center, HVAC (Heating, Ventilation, Air Conditioning) & Refrigeration, Oil &

Gas, Chemicals, Power & Energy, Transportation, Heavy & Light Equipment, Food & Beverage. In those markets, the Group

services a broad, diversified, and long-standing customer base in more than 130 countries.

#### 1.3 Acquisition of Galapagos BidCo S.à r.l. and its subsidiaries and

 successful Refinancing on October 9, 2019

With an effective date October 9, 2019, Mangrove LuxCo IV S.à r.l., Luxembourg, a 100 percent subsidiary of Mangrove

LuxCo III, bought 100 percent of the shares in Galapagos BidCo S.à r.l., Luxembourg and all its subsidiaries (together

“Galapagos BidCo Group”). Galapagos BidCo S.à r.l., Luxembourg, was 100 percent shareholder of the shares in Kelvion

Finance GmbH, Germany including all of its subsidiaries (together “Kelvion Group”) and in ENEXIO Management GmbH,

Germany including all of its subsidiaries (together “ENEXIO Group”) at the acquisition date. Before the acquisition of

Galapagos BidCo Group, the Company did not have any operational activities.

The Acquisition was consummated in connection with the balance sheet restructuring transaction of the Galapagos Group,

the former shareholder of Galapagos BidCo S.à r.l., which has resulted in a major recapitalization of the operating business

of the Mangrove LuxCo III, Mangrove LuxCo IV and the newly acquired subsidiaries (collectively, the “Mangrove Group”), a

deleveraging of the Mangrove Group’s balance sheet and access to new debt facilities and instruments with longer tenors

(the “Restructuring”). In connection with the Restructuring, the Company issued EUR 356,233,492 in aggregate principal

amount of 7.775 percent senior secured fixed rate notes due on October 9, 2025 (the “New Notes”).

In preparation of the aforesaid acquisition of Galapagos BidCo Group the Company incorporated or acquired the following

direct and indirect subsidiaries: Incorporation of Mangrove LuxCo IV S.à r.l., Luxembourg on July 11, 2019, and indirectly via

the participation in Mangrove LuxCo IV S.à r.l. the following holding entities in Germany were acquired on October 9, 2019:

Mangrove GermanCo I GmbH, Germany and Mangrove GermanCo II GmbH, Germany.

In the following, Mangrove LuxCo III and its consolidated direct and indirect subsidiaries is referred to as "Mangrove Group"
or “the Group”.


-----

## 2. Reporting principles

#### 2.1 Going-concern basis of accounting

###### Preparation of Condensed consolidated financial statements

With effective date December 21, 2022, the Group agreed with the lenders to reset the financial covenants, to which the

Actual 2023 met sufficient headroom. Based on the good start to the year in Q1 2024, management of the Group expects

the financial performance for the full year to exceed budget. With current market conditions and business performance,

the Group does not see any current risk to complying with future covenant requirements and consequently the

management does not see any risk to the going concern of the Group. Based on actual Q1 2024 performance and current

forward planning the Group anticipate they will currently be in the position to meet future financial obligations.

**Refinancing process**

The Group is in the process of refinancing all long-term financing instruments: Revolving Credit Facility, Senior Guarantee

Facility, and bonds – which it started in May 2024. Completion of the refinancing is planned for Q3 2024. The management

of the Group currently expects that the Group will be able to meet its covenants.

Therefore, the Condensed consolidated financial statements of Group, for Q1 2024, have been prepared on a going-concern

basis.

#### 2.2 Basis of preparation

Pursuant to clause 4.03(a)(2) of the Indenture, dated October 09, 2019, between the Company and GLAS Trustees Limited
(as Trustee), Global Loan Agency Services Limited (as Paying Agent), GLAS SAS (as Registrar and Transfer Agent) and GLAS
Trust Corporation Limited (as Security Agent) (the “Mangrove Notes Indenture”), the Company is required to set up
Condensed consolidated Financial Statements.

#### 2.3 Group accounting principles and methods

This Condensed consolidated financial report ending 31 March 2024 has been prepared in accordance with IAS 34 (“Interim
Financial Reporting”), which governs interim financial reporting under International Financial Reporting Standards (IFRS)
issued by the International Accounting Standards Board (IASB), London, which are endorsed by the European Union, and
the Interpretations of the IFRS Interpretations Committee (IFRIC) in effect at the reporting date. As these are Condensed
consolidated financial statements, they do not include all the information required by IFRS for full consolidated financial
statements at the end of a financial year.

The comparable Condensed consolidated Statement of Financial Position refers to the consolidated Statement of Financial
Position as of December 31, 2023. The comparable Condensed consolidated Statement of Profit and Loss Statement as well
as the comparable Condensed consolidated Cash Flow Statement, refer to the three months ended March 31, 2023.

Reference should be made as appropriate to the Notes to the consolidated Financial Statements for the fiscal year 2023,
particularly with regard to the main recognition and measurement principles, except where financial reporting standards
have been applied for the first time in 2024 or accounting principles have changed.

Sales-related and cyclical items are accrued throughout the year, insofar as they are significant.

The interim Financial Statements are prepared in euros (EUR). All amounts, including the comparative figures, are presented
in thousands of euros (EUR thousand). Due to rounding, figures presented may result in differences of EUR 1 thousand in
certain cases.


-----

#### 2.4 Presentation of the condensed consolidated Financial Statements

For information on presentation principles, estimates, assumptions, and significant judgements that have the greatest
impact on the amounts recognised in these condensed consolidated statements for the period January 1 to March 31, 2024,
please refer to corresponding explanations in consolidated Financial Statements of Mangrove Group as of December 31,
2023.

#### 2.5 Accounting regulations applied for the first time in the year 2024

The following standards and amendments to existing standards of possible relevance to the Group, which were adopted

into EU law (endorsement mechanism) which are effective since January 1 2024, have not been applied early, but are

applied by the Group since start of the fiscal year 2024.

   - **Amendments to IAS 1 (Effective January 1, 2024)**

Classification of Liabilities as Current or Non-current: The amendments to IAS 1 only affect the presentation of

liabilities in the statement of financial position. They clarify that a liability is classified as non-current if the entity

has a substantive right at the reporting date to defer settlement of the liability for at least twelve months after

the reporting date. The mere existence of a substantial right is sufficient; the company does not have to intend to

exercise this right. This change did not result in a significant effect on the Condensed consolidated financial

statements.

Non-current Liabilities with Covenants: The supplementary amendment to IAS 1 clarifies that if the right to defer

payment is linked to the fulfilment of conditions that must be met within twelve months of the balance sheet

date, these conditions have no influence on the classification as current or non-current. Extended disclosures on

liabilities classified as non-current with covenants are required for risk assessment. This change did also not result

in a significant change on the Condensed consolidated financial statements.

   - **Amendments to IFRS 16 (Effective January 1, 2024)**

Lease Liability in a Sale and Leaseback: The objective of the Amendments is to specify how a seller-lessee

subsequently measures sale and leaseback transactions that satisfy the requirements in IFRS 15 Revenue from

Contracts with Customers to be accounted for as a sale. The lease liability must be measured in such a way that

no gain or loss arises on subsequent measurement in relation to the retained right-of-use asset. There are no

material effects on the Condensed consolidated financial statements.

   - **Amendments to IAS7 and IFRS7 (Effective January 1, 2024)**

Supplier Finance Arrangements: The amendments introduce two new disclosure objectives – one in IAS 7 and

another in IFRS 7 – for a company to provide information about its supplier finance arrangements that would

enable users (investors) to assess the effects of these arrangements on the company’s liabilities and cash flows,

and the company’s exposure to liquidity risk. There are no material effects on the Condensed consolidated

financial statements.

#### 2.6 International Tax Reform – Pillar Two Model Rules

The Mangrove Group has adopted "International Tax Reform - Pillar Two Model Rules” (Amendments to IAS 12) upon their

release on 23 May 2023. The amendments provide a temporary mandatory exception from deferred tax accounting for the

top-up tax, which is effective immediately, and require new disclosures about the Pillar Two exposure, which are addressed

in section "Income Taxes - Global minimum top-up tax".


-----

The mandatory exception applies retrospectively. However, because no new legislation to implement the top-up tax was

enacted or substantively enacted at the 31 March 2024, in any jurisdiction in which the Mangrove Group operates and no

related deferred tax was recognised at that date, the retrospective application has no impact on the Mangrove Group 's

Condensed consolidated financial statements.

The Mangrove Group has determined that the global minimum top-up tax - which is required to pay under Pillar Two

legislation - is an income tax in the scope of IAS 12. The Group has applied a temporary mandatory relief from deferred tax

accounting for the impacts of the top-up tax and accounts for it as a current tax when it is incurred.

#### 2.7 Interim financial reporting principles

These interim Financial Statements present a true and fair view of the Group's results of operations, financial position, and
net assets in the reporting period.

The preparation of interim Financial Statements requires management to make certain estimates and assumptions that
may affect the Group's assets, liabilities, provisions, and deferred tax assets and liabilities, as well as its income and
expenses. Although management makes such estimates and assumptions carefully and in good faith, actual amounts may
differ from the estimates used in these interim Financial Statements.

Factors that may cause amounts to fall below expectations include deterioration in the global economic situation,
movements in exchange rates and interest rates, as well as material litigation and changes in environmental or other
legislations and errors in internal operating processes. The loss of key customers and rising borrowing costs may also
adversely affect the Group’s future performance.

## 3. Basis of consolidation

As of March 31, 2024, the Mangrove Group comprises 4 companies domiciled in Luxembourg and 50 foreign companies
(totalling 54 as at year-end).

Subsidiaries are entities controlled by the company. Control is assumed, when the following three criteria are fulfilled: (1)
the parent company holds decision-making power over the relevant activities of the investee, (2) the company has rights
to variable returns from the investee and (3) the parent company can use its decision-making power to affect the variable
returns. The fulfilment of these criteria is assessed based on corporate governance and potential supplementary
agreements.

Companies that are dormant or do not have significant impact on the financial position and results of operation of the
Group are not included in the Condensed consolidated financial statements.

A total of two companies are not consolidated. The aggregate assets, equity, revenues, and earnings of these companies
are not material to the Condensed consolidated financial statements. The subsidiaries are recognised at cost as non-current
other financial assets. Management deems the influence to the Group as absolutely insignificant and hence, the disclosure
required under IFRS has not been made due to materiality reason. The disclosure of this information is not suitable to
communicate additional information.

## 4. Financial Covenants

The Group has entered into the following financing agreements in the course of financing the acquisition of Galapagos
BidCo Group:

   - € 65,000,000 Revolving Credit Facility Agreement (“RCF”, “RCF Facility Agreement”)


-----

   - € 260,000,000 Senior Guarantee Facility Agreement (“SGF”, “SGF Facility Agreement”)

   - € 234,921,656.23 Cash Collateral Loan Agreement (“Cash Cover Loan Agreement”)

   - € 84,640,713.21 Multilateral Guarantee Facility Agreement (“MGFA”)

   - €356,233,492 Senior Secured Fixed Rate Notes

The RCF Facility Agreement, the SGF (together, the “Facilities”), the Cash Cover Loan Agreement and the MGFA were
entered into by the Company as parent and certain of its subsidiaries (as borrowers and guarantors). On May 27, 2020, the
process of refinancing the Group’s guarantee and “Letter of Credit” portfolio was completed, and the associated cash cover
loan was fully repaid.

With effective date December 21, 2022, the Group agreed with the lenders to reset the financial covenants set forth in the
facility agreements and make certain additional amendments including, but not limited to, a reduction of the total
commitments under and as defined in the SGF from EUR 260 million to EUR 190 million.

The amended Facilities provide for the following financial covenants:

a) **Minimum EBITDA[1]** – (consolidated EBITDA (normalized Earnings before interest, taxation, depreciation, and
amortization) as defined in the RCF Facility Agreement) - the Group shall be required to meet a minimum amount
of EBITDA in respect of each relevant period. The minimum EBITDA covenant amount is €72,600,000 (the
Minimum EBITDA Amount, as amended) as of March 31, 2024.

b) **Total net leverage – the Group shall be required not to exceed a certain leverage ratio in respect of each relevant**
period (such ratio based on consolidated total net debt (i.e., the aggregate amount of cash and cash
equivalents minus financial indebtedness of the Group as defined in the RCF Facility Agreement) to
consolidated EBITDA). The total required net leverage ratio covenant (as amended) is 5.30 as of March 31, 2024.

c) **Minimum liquidity – the Group shall be required to provide reporting on its liquidity (i.e., freely available cash**
and cash equivalents as defined by the RCF Facility Agreement). If liquidity is less than €25,000,000 (but equal
to, or greater than €20,000,000), a “Soft Minimum Liquidity Breach” shall occur. If liquidity is less than
€20,000,000 a “Hard Minimum Liquidity Breach” shall occur.

The financial covenants set out in paragraphs (a) and (b) above shall be tested on a quarterly basis. The minimum liquidity
set out in paragraph (c) shall be tested on a monthly basis. As of March 31, 2024, the Group complied with all financial
covenants as set out above.

According to the financing agreements the Facilities mature on the date falling four years from the date of acquisition of
Galapagos BidCo Group (i.e., October 8, 2023), subject to an automatic one-year extension (i.e., October 9, 2024). The
extension occurs provided that the annual financial statements delivered by the Issuer for the period ending December 31,
2023, do not contain any qualification as to the ability of the New Group to continue as a going concern (unless that
qualification arises as a result of the RCF maturing on the Original Termination Date). As the annual financial statements for
the period ending December 31, 2023, did not contain such qualification, which was reported to the Agent of the Facilities
on 12 June 2023.

In Q1 2024 the maturity of the facilities had been extended to June 9[th], 2025. The interest rates have been increased by
0,5%.

## 5. Financial risk management

As a global Group, Mangrove Group is in its normal course of business exposed to various financial risks such as liquidity,

currency, interest rate, procurement prices, and credit risks that could affect its net assets, financial position, and results of

operations. It is the company’s policy to use derivative financial instruments to reduce the risks associated with operating

activities and the resulting financing requirements. The Group does not invest in derivatives for trading purposes. The

various risks and the current exposure have not significantly changed compared to the risks described within Note 3 to the

Consolidated Financial Statements of Mangrove Group as of December 31, 2023 (we refer to page 66 of the Consolidated

Financial Statements 2023 of the Group).

## 6. Capital reserve

Based on the shareholder resolution dated March 11, 2020, the sole shareholder Mangrove LuxCo II S.à. r.l. contributed

EUR 140,000,000 to the capital contribution account (account 115 “apport en capitaux propres non rémunéré par des

titres” of the Luxembourg Standard Chart of Accounts) of the Company. Pursuant to a shareholder resolution as of

December 22, 2020, the Company’s sole shareholder Mangrove LuxCo II S.à. r.l. acknowledged to convert an aggregated

amount of EUR 136,528,353 into tracking preferred equity certificates (“TPECs”). The Company issued 13,652,835,300

TPECs, holding a value of EUR 0.01 each, representing a total issue of EUR 136,528,353. The subscription of the TPECs was

dated December 31, 2020. Following the TPECs issuance and as part of the required security package in relation to certain

facilities agreements entered into by the Company (including a EUR 65 million revolving facility, a EUR 190 million facilities

agreement and a senior secured note indenture), the Company granted the TPECs pledge to the benefit of the Security

Agent and entered into the TPECs pledge agreement for the purpose thereof. The capital reserve as of March 31, 2024,

amounts to EUR 3,471,647 (as of December 31, 2023: EUR 3,471,647).

## 7. Tracking preferred equity certificates / Shareholder loan

The company acquired Galapagos BidCo Group on October 9, 2019. Financing of the acquisition was done inter alia by a

bridge loan of EUR 140,000 thousand provided to the Company by the indirect shareholder Mangrove LuxCo I S. à r.l. on

October 9, 2019. The final maturity date for the loan is four years after the date of the transaction, i.e., October 8, 2023.

The loan does not accrue interest for the first six months after the transaction date.

After the transaction date Mangrove LuxCo I S.à r.l. transferred the loan agreement and the EUR 140.000.000 loan

receivable to its subsidiary Mangrove LuxCo II S.à r.l. which is the sole shareholder of the Company. On March 11, 2020,

Mangrove LuxCo II S.à r.l. contributed the loan receivable in the full amount of EUR 140,000 thousand to the capital

contribution account (account 115 “apport en capitaux proprex non rémunéré par des titres” of the Luxembourg Standard

Chart of Accounts) of the Company.

With Shareholder resolution as of December 22, 2020, the sole shareholder Mangrove LuxCo II S.à r.l. to convert an

aggregated amount of EUR 136,528.353 thousand into tracking preferred equity certificates (“TPECS”). The company issued

13,652,835,300 TPECS, having a value of EUR 0.01 each, representing a total issue of EUR 136,528.353 thousand. As of

March 31, 2024, TPECs are recognized at EUR 173,410.429 thousand including an interest of EUR 2,829.929 thousand

(March 31, 2023: EUR 2,798.831 thousand). Following the TPECs issuance and as security package in relation to certain

facilities agreements entered into by the Company (including a EUR 65 million revolving facility, a EUR 190 million facilities

agreement and a senior secured note indenture), the Company granting the TPECs Pledge to the benefit of the Security

Agent and entered into the TPECs Pledge Agreement for the purpose thereof.

These TPECs are junior to all other debt of the Group and cannot be withdrawn by the shareholder under the existing

financing agreements. Therefore, these TPECs are equity like instruments and are being disclosed in the Condensed

consolidated Statement of Financial Position of the Group between equity and liabilities and are summed up together with

the equity to the line item “Equity and tracking preferred equity certificates / shareholder loan”.

Financial assets and liabilities that are measured at fair value, or for which a fair value is disclosed in the Notes to the

Condensed consolidated financial statements, are required to be categorized according to the fair value hierarchy as

described in the following.

Categorization within the levels of the fair value hierarchy is based on the measurement of the underlying inputs:

Level 1 inputs: quoted prices (unadjusted) in active markets for identical financial assets and liabilities.

Level 2 inputs: quoted market prices that are observable as direct (prices) or indirect (derived from prices) inputs used to

measure fair value and that are not quoted prices as defined by Level 1.

Level 3 inputs: inputs that are not based on observable market data.

The following table shows the categorization of financial assets and financial liabilities into the three-level fair value

hierarchy.

## 11.Related party disclosures

Pursuant to IAS 24 persons or entities that (jointly) control or are (jointly) controlled by Mangrove Group shall be disclosed,

unless they are included in the Condensed consolidated financial statements.

The disclosure obligation under IAS 24 furthermore extends to transactions with persons who exercise a significant

influence on the financial and business policies of the Mangrove Group. A significant influence on the financial and business

policies of the Mangrove Group can hereby be based on a shareholding of 20 percent or more of Mangrove, a seat in the

management board of Mangrove Group or another key management position on board either of the parent of Mangrove

Group or on lower level holding company.

Related parties of the Mangrove Group in accordance with IAS 24 primarily comprise the shareholders of the Mangrove

and the subsidiaries of Mangrove Group, which are not consolidated due to materiality reasons.

All transactions with related parties are conducted on an arm's length basis.

As of the reporting date, no transactions between Mangrove Group companies and joint ventures or non-consolidated
companies were occurred.

**Transactions with other related parties**

The Group incurred advisory costs from a Triton related advisory company amounting to EUR 70 thousand (December 31,
2023: EUR 293 thousand).

Additionally, the Group has financial liabilities towards Triton Fund IV amounting to EUR 4,250 thousand (December 31,

2023: EUR 4,172 thousand) as well as EUR 542 thousand (December 31, 2023: EUR 542 thousand) towards Galapagos MidCo

S.à r.l. and EUR 22 thousand (December 31, 2023: EUR 22 thousand) towards Triton MasterluxCo S.à. r.l.

## 13.Bank guarantees

Mangrove Holding Group companies utilised bank guarantees in the amount of EUR 104.0 million (as of December 31, 2023:
EUR 141.4 million). A major part of the lines is granted by a bank consortium (total line EUR 190 million, thereof EUR 88,1
million utilised).

## 14.Litigation

A number of claims have been brought arising out of the financial restructuring of 2019 (the “Restructuring”). These have

now either been irrevocably withdrawn (Luxembourg, NY) or the relevant Mangrove entities prevailed in now final and

unappealable judgments (Germany, England)


-----

The insolvency proceedings in respect of Galapagos SA remain contested as between Kebekus (Germany) and the Official

Receiver (UK), however management (based on legal advice and the judgments in England and Germany) does not perceive

there to be any risk to the efficacy of the restructuring nor of claims against Mangrove entities, as a result of such

proceedings. Neither of the insolvency practitioners has suggested it will seek to assert a claim against any of the Mangrove

entities and the types of claim that would be theoretically possible have already been resolved via the binding judgments

noted above.

## 15.Global economic outlook 2024

As described in the section about the macroeconomic environment in this report, the Mangrove Group as a global

engineering company considers global growth in gross GDP and the corresponding forecasts to be a benchmark for its own

performance.

The Group prepared its financial budget in the fourth quarter of FY 2023 and approved it mid-December 2023 as part of

the update of its H5 Strategy in late 2023 as explained. The 2024 budget is based on the growth expectations according to

the IMF World Economic Outlook (WEO) from October 2023 regarding the development of the global economy as well as

estimates and expectations on the markets for heat exchange provided by a leading strategic consulting firm in 2023 and

further external sources regarding outlook from the second half of 2023 on the development of key markets. For more

details, please refer to chapter 7.3 of the management report in the Annual Financial Statements of the Group (Page 23 ff).

## 16.Events after the end of the reporting period

End of April 2024, the Group announced a restructuring to lower the capacity in two German sites. The program impact
around 150 employees. Following appropriate review and approvals the necessary provisions will be accrued in Q2 2024.

In addition, the Group started the process of refinancing all long-term financing instruments (Revolving Credit Facility,
Senior Guarantee Facility, and bonds) in Q2 2024. Completion of the refinancing is planned for Q3 2024.

### Notes to the Consolidated Financial Statements of Mangrove Group

 1. General information

##### 1.1 Company information

Mangrove LuxCo III S.à r.l., Luxembourg, hereinafter also referred to as "Mangrove LuxCo III" or the

"company" is a public limited liability company (Société à responsabilité limitée) incorporated under the

laws of the Grand Duchy of Luxembourg, having its registered office at 2, rue Edward Steichen, L-2540

Luxembourg, and registered with the Luxembourg Trade and Companies Register (Registre de Commerce

et des Sociétés Luxembourg) with registration number B236258. Sole shareholder of the company is

Mangrove LuxCo II S.à r.l., Luxembourg, which itself is a direct subsidiary of Galapagos LuxCo I S.à r.l.,

Luxembourg. The Company was incorporated on July 11, 2019. The purpose of the Company is the

acquisition, holding and disposal of interests in Luxembourg and/or foreign companies and undertakings as

well as the administration, development and management of such interests.

##### 1.2 Acquisition of Galapagos BidCo S.à r.l. and its subsidiaries and

 successful Refinancing on October 9, 2019

With an effective date October 9, 2019, Mangrove LuxCo IV S.à r.l., Luxembourg, a 100 percent subsidiary

of Mangrove LuxCo III, bought 100 percent of the shares in Galapagos BidCo S.à r.l., Luxembourg and all its

subsidiaries (together “Galapagos BidCo Group”). Galapagos BidCo S.à r.l., Luxembourg, was 100 percent

shareholder of the shares in Kelvion Finance GmbH, Germany including all of its subsidiaries (together

“Kelvion Group”) and in ENEXIO Management GmbH, Germany including all of its subsidiaries (together

“ENEXIO Group”) at the acquisition date. Before the acquisition of Galapagos BidCo Group, the Company

did not have any operational activities.

The Acquisition was consummated in connection with the balance sheet restructuring transaction of the

Galapagos Group, the former shareholder of Galapagos BidCo S.à r.l., which has resulted in a major

recapitalization of the operating business of the Mangrove LuxCo III, Mangrove LuxCo IV and the newly

acquired subsidiaries (collectively, the “Mangrove Group”), a deleveraging of the Mangrove Group’s balance

sheet and access to new debt facilities and instruments with longer tenors (the “Restructuring”). In

connection with the Restructuring, the Company issued EUR 356,233,492 in aggregate principal amount of

7.775 percent senior secured fixed rate notes due on October 9, 2025 (the “New Notes”).

In preparation of the aforesaid acquisition of Galapagos BidCo Group the Company incorporated or acquired

the following direct and indirect subsidiaries: Incorporation of Mangrove LuxCo IV S.à r.l., Luxembourg on

July 11, 2019 and indirectly via the participation in Mangrove LuxCo IV S.à r.l. the following holding entities

in Germany were acquired on October 9, 2019: Mangrove GermanCo I GmbH, Germany and Mangrove

GermanCo II GmbH, Germany.

In the following, Mangrove LuxCo III and its consolidated direct and indirect subsidiaries is referred to as

"Mangrove Group" or “the Group”.

##### 1.3 Description of the business

The Mangrove Group is a leading global manufacturer of heat exchangers and other cooling & heating


-----

products. The Group is active in multiple end markets such as Data Center, HVAC (Heating, Ventilation, Air

Conditioning) & Refrigeration, Oil & Gas, Chemicals, Power & Energy, Transportation, Heavy & Light

Equipment, Food & Beverage. In those markets, the Group services a broad, diversified, and long-standing

customer base in more than 130 countries.

##### 1.4 Segment Reporting

Mangrove Group operates through the four Kelvion segments, “Refrigeration Technologies” (“RT”),

“Machine Cooling Systems” (“MCS”), “Plate Heat Exchangers” (“PHE”) and “Thermal Solutions” (“KTS”).

##### 1.5 The four segments of Mangrove Group

The four segments of Mangrove Group focus on distinct technologies and product portfolios:

- **Refrigeration Technologies (RT) focuses on component business for refrigeration applications with**

significant growth potential in the data center industry. RT supplies a wide range of standard and

customized heat exchangers for cooling and removing heat from different types of data centers

(hyperscale, colocation, modular etc.) using both air and liquid cooling methods. The data center market

consists of cooling solutions such as air conditioning, chilling units, economizer systems, liquid cooling

systems, control systems and includes services such as consulting, installation & deployment and

maintenance and support. The heat exchanger solutions are also used in the refrigeration market in cold

chain warehouses, supermarkets, non-residential buildings, and industrial production. Product offering

includes air cooled condensers which reject heat from refrigeration systems and are often sold as part of

a package of equipment with air coolers. RT’s customized air coolers are design-to-order units for

industrial or OEM solutions for food processing and distribution facilities. Product offering includes also

customized radiators and dry coolers which are mainly used for power and industrial applications.

Improving the energy efficiency of commercial and industrial refrigeration equipment is essential for end

users looking to reduce carbon footprint and operating costs.

- **Machine Cooling Systems (MCS) is a leading player in heat exchangers for power and engine applications**

with substantial growth opportunities by leveraging its global installed base. MCS supplies heat

exchangers for power generation, power transmission, large engine applications (marine and off-highway)

and green applications like biomass, green hydrogen, or renewable energies. The business is mostly with

OEM, e.g., for large engine manufacturers, but MCS also engages in smaller projects, like solar, wind or

solar photovoltaic. Product offering includes charge air coolers, which cool down combustion-air coming

from the turbocharger before entering the engine. MCS’ shell and tube double safety heat exchangers

assure the secure handling of safety-critical media. Product offering also includes box coolers which are

fitted in the sea chest of small and medium-sized vessels.

- **Thermal Solutions (KTS), is Kelvion’s largest segment, focusing on project business for demanding**

applications in the Oil & Gas, Chemicals Industries and, like RT, with significant growth potential in high

tech data center business as well as green tech applications such as hydrogen and Carbon Capture and

Storage (CCS). KTS’ engineering expertise plays a key role in differentiation against competitors. High

degree of geographical diversification with sites in all key region, including Europe, NAFTA, Latin America,

China and MEA. Product offering includes air fin coolers typically used for very large cooling requirements

in different industries, e.g., Oil & Gas and Chemicals, as well as air dryers which are used to remove

humidity from an air stream in various process industries. KTS’ shell & tube heat exchangers are used to

heat, cool, or condense water and other media in different process industries. The focus of the BU has

shifted in the recent years from Oil & Gas and Petrochemicals to high and green tech business.


-----

- **Plate Heat Exchangers (PHE) provides a broad range of plate heat exchangers for a wide variety of**

applications in terms of pressure and temperature demands for a wide range of customer industries,

ranging from HVAC and Refrigeration to Food & Beverages, Chemicals, Power, and Industrials. Product

offering includes fully welded plate heat exchangers which are used to save energy in demanding high

pressure and temperature applications, as well as brazed plate heat exchangers, often used for

environmentally friendly heat pump applications. PHE’s gasketed heat exchangers have the highest

efficiency and flexibility and are used in a variety of industries as well as for heat recovery applications.

In contrast to the project driven segment KTS, the three segments RT, MCS and PHE represent the

component type business of the Group and form together “Kelvion Products” (“KP”). All four segments hold

strong favorable market positions in their respective markets. MCS and PHE are among the TOP 3, RT

amongst the Top 5 and KTS is niche-market leader.

In addition to the above segments there is the fifth Service segment, which is a virtual segment, i.e.,
Service is not separated from the four segments but managed globally and centrally across segments.


-----

### 2. Reporting and Accounting principles

##### 2.1 Going-concern basis of accounting

**Preparation of consolidated financial statements**

With effective date December 21, 2022, the Group agreed with the lenders to reset the financial covenants,

to which the Actual 2023 met sufficient headroom. Based on the good start to the year, management of the

Group expects the financial performance for the full year to exceed budget. With current market conditions

and business performance, the Group does not see any current risk to complying with future covenant

requirements and consequently the management does not see any risk to the going concern of the Group.

Based on actual planning the Group will be at every time and in the upcoming year in the position to meet

all financial obligations.

Therefore, the consolidated financial statements of Mangrove Group have been prepared on a going
concern basis.

##### 2.2 Basis of presentation

The presented consolidated financial statements cover the period from January 1, 2023 to December 31,

2023 with the prior period from January 1, 2022 to December 31, 2022.

The consolidated financial statements of Mangrove Group - which comprise the consolidated statement of

financial position, consolidated statement of profit or loss, consolidated statement of comprehensive

income, consolidated statement of cash flows, consolidated statement of changes in equity and the notes

to the consolidated financial statements - include Mangrove LuxCo III and its direct and indirect subsidiaries

(hereinafter referred to as “Mangrove Group” or the “Group”). The consolidated financial statements have

been prepared in accordance with the IFRS Accounting standards as adopted by the EU. All IFRS Accounting

standards and interpretations in effect for fiscal years beginning on or after January 1, 2023, have been

applied.

The consolidated financial statements are prepared in euro (EUR), the functional currency of the group, and

presented in thousand of euros (EUR thousand) or in millions of euros (EUR million). Due to rounding, figures

presented may result in differences of EUR 1 thousand in certain cases.

To improve the clarity of presentation, various items in the consolidated balance sheet and consolidated

income statement have been aggregated and are explained accordingly in the Notes. Assets and liabilities

are classified into current and non-current items. Current assets are expected to be realised within 12

months after the reporting period and current liabilities are due to be settled within 12 months after the

reporting period. The consolidated income statement is prepared using the cost of sales method.

The consolidated statement of cash flows is prepared using the indirect method for cash flows from

operating activities and the direct method for cash flows from investing and financing activities.

The accounting and measurement principles are presented and explained in detail in note 2.8. The

consolidated financial statements were authorised for issue by the Board of Managers on April 15, 2024.

##### 2.3 First-time adoption of new accounting pronouncements

The Group applied for the first time all standards and amendments, which are effective for annual periods

beginning on January 1, 2023. The impact on the consolidated financial statements of the Group is not

significant. The Group has not early adopted any other standard, interpretation or amendments that were


-----

issued but are not yet effective.

##### 2.3.1 Accounting regulations applied for the first time in the year

 2023

   - **Amendments to IFRS 17 (Effective January 1, 2023)**

IFRS 17 Insurance Contracts replaces IFRS 4 and for the first time sets out standard requirements

for the recognition, measurement, presentation and disclosure of insurance contracts,

reinsurance contracts and investment contracts with discretionary participation features. Under

the IFRS 17 measurement model, groups of insurance contracts are measured based on the

expected value of discounted cash flows with an explicit risk adjustment for non-financial risks as

well as a contractual service margin that results in the recognition of profit in line with the

provision of services.

The amendments add a transition option aimed to improve the usefulness of comparative

information presented on initial application of both IFRS 17 and IFRS 9 and introduce the option

of applying a "classification overlay approach". This option can be applied when IFRS 17 and IFRS

9 are applied simultaneously for the first time and no "restatement" of a financial asset with regard

to the comparative information of IFRS 9 in 2022 is made.

   - **Amendments to IAS 1 and IFRS Practice Statement 2 (Effective January 1, 2023)**

Disclosure of Accounting Policies: The amendment to IAS 1 requires that only "material"

accounting policies are presented in the notes instead of significant accounting policies.

It clarifyies that accounting policies related to immaterial transactions, other events or conditions

are themselves immaterial and do not need to be disclosed; and that not all accounting policies

relating to material transactions, other events or conditions are themselves material.

The amendments to Practice Statement 2 accordingly indicate how the concept of materiality is

applied to the disclosure of accounting policies.

   - **Amendments to IAS 8 (Effective January 1, 2023)**

Definition of Accounting Estimates: The amendments clarify how companies should distinguish

changes in accounting policies from changes in accounting estimates, taking into account that

changes in accounting policies are applied retrospectively, whereas changes in accounting

estimates are applied prospectively.

The changes to IAS 8 focus entirely on accounting estimates and clarify the definition of a change

in accounting estimates by introducing a new definition of accounting estimates. Under the new

definition, acounting estimates are “monetary amounts in financial statements that are subject to

measurement uncertainty”.

   - **Amendments to IAS 12 (Effective January 1, 2023)**

Deferred Tax related to Assets and Liabilities arising from a Single Transaction: The amendment

restricts the exemption from (initial) recognition of deferred taxes to the extent that it no longer

applies to transactions in which companies recognise both an asset and a liability (for example,

leases and asset retirement obligations). Deferred tax assets and liabilities must be recognised for

such transactions in future, insofar as deductible and taxable temporary differences of the same

amount arise.

   - **Amendments to IAS 12 (International Tax Reform – Pillar Two Model Rules)**

The KELVION group has adopted "International Tax Reform - Pillar Two Model Rules”


-----

(Amendments to IAS 12) upon their release on 23 May 2023. The amendments provide a

temporary mandatory exception from deferred tax accounting for the top-up tax, which is

effective immediately, and require new disclosures about the Pillar Two exposure, which are

addressed in section "Income Taxes - Global minimum top-up tax".

The mandatory exception applies retrospectively. However, because no new legislation to

implement the top-up tax was enacted or substantively enacted at 31 December 2022, in any

jurisdiction in which the KELVION group operates and no related deferred tax was recognised at

that date, the retrospective application has no impact on the KELVION group 's consolidated

financial statements.

##### 2.3.2 Accounting regulations not applied in advance of their

 effective date

The following standards and amendments to existing standards of possible relevance to the Group, which

were adopted into EU law (endorsement mechanism) but are not yet mandatory, have not been applied

early:

   - **Amendments to IAS 1 (Effective January 1, 2024)**

Classification of Liabilities as Current or Non-current: The amendments to IAS 1 only affect the

presentation of liabilities in the statement of financial position. They clarify that a liability is

classified as non-current if the entity has a substantive right at the reporting date to defer

settlement of the liability for at least twelve months after the reporting date. The mere existence

of a substantial right is sufficient; the company does not have to intend to exercise this right.

Significant effects on the consolidated financial statements are not expected. Due to the COVID
19 pandemic, the date of initial application was postponed to 1 January 2024.

Non-current Liabilities with Covenants: The supplementary amendment to IAS 1 clarifies that if the

right to defer payment is linked to the fulfilment of conditions that must be met within twelve

months of the balance sheet date, these conditions have no influence on the classification as

current or non-current. Extended disclosures on liabilities classified as non-current with covenants

are required for risk assessment. No material effects on the consolidated financial statements are

expected.

   - **Ammendments to IFRS 16 (Effective January 1, 2024)**

Lease Liability in a Sale and Leaseback: The objective of the Amendments is to specify how a seller
lessee subsequently measures sale and leaseback transactions that satisfy the requirements in

IFRS 15 Revenue from Contracts with Customers to be accounted for as a sale. The lease liability

must be measured in such a way that no gain or loss arises on subsequent measurement in relation

to the retained right-of-use asset. The Amendments become effective for annual periods

beginning on or after 1 January 2024, with earlier application permitted. No material effects on

the consolidated financial statements are expected.

These new standards and amendments to existing standards will be applied by the Group starting in fiscal

2024 or later.

##### 2.4 Accounting pronouncements not yet endorsed by the EU

The IASB issued the following standards and amendments to existing standards of relevance to the Group,

which still have to be adopted into EU law (endorsement mechanism) before they become applicable:


-----

   - **Amendments to IAS 21 (Effective January 1, 2025)**

Lack of Exchangeability: The amendment clarifies how to specify when a currency is exchangeable

into another currency and how a company estimates a spot rate when a currency lacks

exchangeability (e.g. due to government directives). A currency is exchangeable when an entity is

able to exchange that currency for the other currency through markets or exchange mechanisms

that create enforceable rights and obligations without undue delay at the measurement date and

for a specified purpose. A currency is not exchangeable into the other currency if an entity can

only obtain an insignificant amount of the other currency. When a currency is not exchangeable,

a company needs to estimate a spot rate. The amendments apply for annual reporting periods

beginning on or after 1 January 2025. Earlier application is permitted. Significant effects on the

consolidated financial statements are not expected.

   - **Amendments to IAS 7 and IFRS 7 (Effective January 1, 2024)**

Supplier Finance Arrangements: The amendments introduce additional disclosure requirements

for companies that enter into these arrangements. They do not change the classification and

presentation of the related liabilities and cash flows.

The amendments relate to disclosure requirements in connection with supplier financing

arrangements (supply chain financing, trade payables financing or reverse factoring

arrangements) and include

          - disclosures on terms and conditions of those financing arrangements,

          - the amounts of the liabilities that are the subject of such agreements,

          - for which part of these arrangements the suppliers have already received payments

from the financiers,

          - under which item these liabilities are recognised in the balance sheet,

          - maturity date ranges and

          - information on liquidity risk.

The amendments are to be applied for financial years beginning on or after 1 January 2024, but

for the Group only after corresponding EU endorsement. Significant effects on the consolidated

financial statements are not expected.

##### 2.5 Basis of consolidation

**Consolidated entities**

The consolidated financial statements comprise the financial statements of Mangrove LuxCo III and its direct

prepared for the same reporting period as the parent company, except of the Indian subsidiary and the

Galapagos BidCo S.à r.l., Luxembourg, consistently applying group IFRS accounting policies. The financial

control is lost.

**Subsidiaries**

Subsidiaries are entities controlled by the company. Control is assumed, when the following three criteria

are fulfilled:

(1) the parent company holds decision-making power over the relevant activities of the investee,

(2) the company has rights to variable returns from the investee and

(3) the parent company can use its decision-making power to affect the variable returns.

The fulfillment of these criteria is assessed based on corporate governance and potential supplementary

agreements.

Companies that are dormant or do not have significant impact on the financial position and results of

operation of the Group are not included in the consolidated financial statements.

A total of two (2022: three) companies are not consolidated.

In April 2023, the Bloksam Asia Ltd, Hong Kong was dissolved.

The aggregate assets, equity, revenues and earnings of these companies are not material to the

consolidated financial statements. The subsidiaries are recognised at cost as non-current other financial

assets. Management deems the influence to the Group as absolutely insignificant and hence, the disclosure

required under IFRS has not been made due to materiality reason. The disclosure of this information is not

suitable to communicate additional information.

**Interests in associated companies and joint ventures**

Associated are those entities in which the Group has significant influence, but no control or joint control,

over the financial and operating policies. A joint venture is an arrangement in which the Group has joined

control, whereby the Group has rights to the net assets of the arrangement, rather than rights to its assets

and obligations for its liabilities. Interests in associated companies and joint ventures are accounted for using

the equity method and at cost in case the company is not material. They are initially recognised at cost,

which includes transaction costs. Subsequent to initial recognition, the consolidated financial statements

include the Group's share of profit or loss and OCI of equity accounted investees, until the date on which

significant influence or joint control ceases for those that are accounted at equity.

One associated company is accounted at cost since it is not material.

Management deems the influence of the associated company to the financial position of the Group as


-----

insignificant.

##### 2.6 Currency translation

The Mangrove Group companies prepare their annual financial statements on the basis of their respective

functional currencies.

Foreign currency transactions entered into by companies included in the consolidated financial statements

are translated into the functional currency at the exchange rate prevailing at the transaction date. Monetary

assets and liabilities are translated at the applicable exchange rate at each reporting date. Exchange rate

gains and losses resulting from these items are generally reported in the income statement under other

income or expenses. Non-monetary items measured in terms of historical acquisition or production cost in

a foreign currency are translated using the exchange rates at the dates of the transaction. Non-monetary

items measured at fair value in a foreign currency are translated using the exchange rates as of the date

when the fair value was determined.

All financial statements of companies whose functional currencies differ from the reporting currency are

translated into the reporting currency used in the consolidated financial statements. The assets and

liabilities of the companies included in the consolidated financial statements are translated at the middle

rates prevailing at the reporting date. The income statements of these companies are translated at the

average rates for the period under review. If these average rates are not a reasonable approximation of the

actual transaction rates, the income statements are translated at the relevant transaction rates. Any

translation differences are recognised and subsequently adjusted in other comprehensive income.
