**General remarks**

On October 9, 2019, the Company has issued EUR 356.233,492 thousand in aggregate principal amount of

New Notes (“SSNs”) in connection with the acquisition of Galapagos BidCo Group as described elsewhere in

these notes (e.g. in Sections 1. and 4.). The notes are due on the October 8, 2025, at which date the principal

shall be payable in full. The notes were issued under an indenture among, inter alia, the issuer, Mangrove

LuxCo III S.à r.l. as well as the issuer’s subsidiaries that guarantee the notes. Galapagos BidCo S.à r.l. and

Kelvion Finance GmbH, and GLAS Trustee Limited act as trustee.

**Interest on the notes and right to defer interest payments in cash in 2022 and 2023**

The Notes bear interest at a rate of 7.775% per annum and will be payable in cash, semi-annually in arrears

on June 15 and December 15 of each year; provided that with respect to the interest periods ending June

15, 2022, December 15, 2022, June 15, 2023 and/or December 15, 2023, the Company, in its sole discretion,

elect (if such election is necessary to ensure compliance with the minimum liquidity covenant and clean

-----

down provision as per the terms of the New RCF on the relevant interest payment date and the twelve

months following thereafter) to capitalize part of its interest payments for those periods, with the remainder

payable in cash (an “Interest Election”).

Following an Interest Election, interest due for the relevant interest period will be equal to an aggregate

amount of 9.00% and shall comprise the following elements: (i) 0.25% per annum cash-pay interest; and (ii)

8.75% per annum payment-in-kind interest (increasing the principal amount of the outstanding Notes or by

issuing additional New Notes, in each case, in a principal amount equal to an amount corresponding to an

interest rate of 8.75% per annum on 100% of the then outstanding principal amount of the Notes).

**Right to redeem the notes**

Since October 09, 2023, the second anniversary of the Restructuring Effective Time, the Company is entitled,

at its option, to redeem all or a portion of the Notes at a redemption price as described in the Notes

Indenture and accrued and unpaid interest to (but not including) the date of redemption. In the event of

certain developments affecting taxation, the Issuer may redeem all, but not less than all, of the Notes.

**Mandatory repayment upon request in case of change of control**

Upon certain events defined as constituting a change of control, each holder of the Notes will have the right

to require the Company to repurchase such holders’ Notes at a price in cash equal to 101% of the aggregate

principal amount thereof plus accrued and unpaid interest to (but not including) the date of redemption.

Following certain public equity offerings by the Parent or any Parent Entity (as defined in the Notes

Indenture), the Company will be required to use the net cash proceeds of the relevant public equity offering

to make an offer to redeem the Notes at the redemption prices described in the Notes Indenture.

**Pledge agreements – securitization of the Notes**

In accordance with the notes indenture, various pledge agreements between the banks and selected Group

companies have been entered into under which all or a significant portion of the group’s assets and shares

of consolidated subsidiaries were granted as security for the payment of the Bonds. The assets that serve as

Financial assets and liabilities that are measured at fair value, or for which a fair value is disclosed in the

notes to the consolidated financial statements, are required to be categorized according to the fair value

hierarchy described in the following.

Categorization within the levels of the fair value hierarchy is based on the measurement of the underlying

inputs:

Level 1 inputs: quoted prices (unadjusted) in active markets for identical financial assets and liabilities.

Level 2 inputs: quoted market prices that are observable as direct (prices) or indirect (derived from prices)

inputs used to measure fair value and that are not quoted prices as defined by Level 1.

Level 3 inputs: inputs that are not based on observable market data.

Trade receivables, cash and cash equivalents, other financial assets and liabilities have short remaining

maturities in general. As a result, their fair values correspond to the carrying amounts.

Regarding Tracking preferred equity certificates / shareholder loan we refer to note “5.2 Tracking preferred

equity certificates / shareholder loan”.

The carrying amount of the trade payables and other current liabilities that are subject to the measurement

rules of IFRS 9 corresponds to their fair value. The fair value of fixed-interest liabilities is the present value

of their expected future cash flows. They are discounted at the rates prevailing at the reporting date. The

carrying amount of variable-rate liabilities corresponds to their fair value.

The fair value of derivatives and embedded derivatives are calculated using quoted exchange rates and yield

curves observable in the market. Accordingly, they are categorized within Level 2 of the fair value hierarchy.

The fair value of senior secured notes is categorized within Level 1. Fair Value is calculated according to its

quoted (unadjusted) price in active market.

The fair value of other financial assets of shares in non-consolidated subsidiaries and other equity

investments is measured on the basis of available financial information, such as transaction prices for

financing rounds or business plans to the extent that this information is reliable, or, as an approximation, as

cost, which is considered an appropriate estimate of fair value as no more suitable information is available.

A review is carried out on a quarterly basis using all information available on the equity investments to

establish whether cost is still representative of fair value. This would not be the case, for example, in the

event of a significant change in the market in which the equity investments are active. As cost is the sole

input factor for fair value, a percentage change in cost results in an equal change in fair value. The estimated

fair value would increase (decrease) with any increase (decrease) in cost. A 1% increase (decrease) would

not materially affect fair value. Accordingly, they are categorized within Level 3 of the fair value hierarchy.

**Derivative financial instruments**

The fair value of currency forwards at the reporting date is calculated on the basis of the spot exchange rate,

taking into account forward premiums and discounts corresponding to the relevant remaining maturities.

Forward premiums and discounts are derived from yield curves observable at the reporting date. The fair

value of currency options is calculated on the basis of recognized measurement models. Fair value is affected

by the remaining term of the option, the current exchange rate, the volatility of the exchange rate, and the

underlying yield curves.

Mangrove Group uses currency forwards as derivative financial instruments to hedge economically foreign

currency risk for existing or planned underlying transactions.

The carrying amounts for the derivatives presented in the balance sheet are gross amounts.

Mangrove Group enters into derivative transactions under netting agreements with banks under the

German Master Agreement for Financial Derivatives Transactions. In general, under such agreements, the

amounts owed by each counterparty on a single day in respect of all transactions outstanding in the same

currency are aggregated into a single net amount that is payable by one party to the other, in certain

circumstances – e.g. when a credit event such as a default occurs - all outstanding transactions under the

agreement are terminated, the termination value is assessed and only a single net amount is payable in

settlement of all transactions. The potential offsetting volume is insignificant.

**Global minimum top-up tax**

The group is in the process of enacting new legislation to implementation the global minimum top-up tax,

expectedly from fiscal year 2024 onwards and is in the process of adopting the necessary internal measures

to fully comply with upcoming legislation.

To measure the impact, if the global minimum tax legislation had applied in 2023 already, the group tested

the Transitional CbCR Safe Harbour rules provided by said upcoming legislation, based on financial and tax

data for the year 2022. Based on this, all jurisdictions where the group operates, would have been covered

and deemed to have a zero top-up tax and thus no subsidiary in these jurisdictions would have been subject

to the full global minimum tax legislation.

Since the newly enacted legislation in Luxembourg is only effective from 1 January 2024, there is no current

tax impact for the year ended 31 December 2023. The group has applied a temporary mandatory relief from

deferred tax accounting for the impacts of the top-up tax and accounts for it as a current tax when it is

incurred.

**Contingent liability for income taxes**

A transfer pricing audit was carried out at an Indian subsidiary for the 2019/2020 and 2020/2021
financial years by the Indian tax authorities and results in a contingent liability.

The uncertain tax treatment relates to the interpretation of how the tax legislation is to be applied to
the transfer prices for the company. The company has already started an appeal process against the
assessment notes for transfer pricing which is still pending.

No tax amounts were accrued for this topic since the company is convinced to get a relief for most of
the findings in the appeal processes and because of the huge amount of loss carry-forwards of this
entity (no deferred taxes were recognized on the tax loss-carry-forward amounts). The impact of the
transfer pricing adjustment in the amount of EUR 2,750 thousand would reduce the tax-loss-carryforward correspondingly.

### 7. Lease

A lease is an agreement that conveys the right to control the use of an identified asset for a defined period

of time in return for a number of payments. The Group is a lessee mainly of land and buildings, machinery,

transportation and technical equipment.

**Lease accounting since October 9, 2019**

With the adoption of IFRS 16, the lessee is no longer required to differentiate between operating and finance

leases. As lessee, Mangrove now accounts for nearly all leases, recognising right-of-use assets for leased

assets and liabilities for lease agreements. The following principles are considered:

    - Mangrove exercises the exemption for lease agreements with a maximum term of 12 months

from the date of provision and low-value assets. Low-value assets are generally defined as leased

with aggregated payments of EUR 20,000 or less.

    - Mangrove separates non-lease components, such as services, from lease payments.

    - Lease liabilities are measured at the present value of the remaining lease payments. Lease

payments are discounted at the rate implicit in the lease if that rate can readily be determined.

Otherwise, discounting is at the incremental borrowing rate. The incremental borrowing rate,

which is mainly applied, is based on risk-adjusted interest rates, and determined for the

respective lease terms and currencies.

    - A right-of-use asset is initially recognised at the same amount as the lease liability. Differences

may arise from lease payments before commencement date and initial direct costs.

    - After capitalisation at commencement date, the right-of use asset is measured at cost and

depreciated over the lease term using the straight-line method.

    - Extension and termination options are part of a number of leases particularly of real estate.

Extension and termination options are taken into account on recognition of the lease liability only

if it is reasonably certain that these options will be exercised in the future. When contract terms

are being determined, consideration is given to all facts and circumstances that offer an

economic incentive for exercising extension options or not exercising termination options.

Changes in lease terms arising from the exercise of an extension option or non-exercise of a

termination option are only considered when determining lease terms if sufficient certainty

exists. Estimates and expectations which are asserted at the commencement date of the lease

liability and the right-of-use asset and pertain to future payments not yet determined on the date

of provision are assessed continuously during the lease term. If subsequently improved or

changed knowledge influences the expected payment profile over time, the lease liability is

remeasured.

### 8. Contingent liabilities, other financial obligations and litigation

##### 8.1 Contingent liabilities

A Contingent liability is according to IAS 37.10 a “possible obligation that arises from past events and

whose existence will be confirmed only by the occurrence or non-occurrence of one or more uncertain

future events not wholly within the control of the entity; or a present obligation that arises from past

events but is not recognized because:

(i) it is not probable that an outflow of resources embodying economic benefits will be required to settle

the obligation; or

(ii) the amount of the obligation cannot be measured with sufficient reliability.”, i.e., uncertainties for

which the outcome has not been determined. If the occurrence is probable and the outcome can be

estimated reliable, a liability is recorded in the balance sheet. As of December 31, 2023, Mangrove

Group has a recognized contingent liability relating to the SSNs which amounts to EUR 17,787 thousand

(2022: EUR 26,412 thousand) as of December 31, 2023. This contingent liability was recognized via

purchase price allocation.

Several companies of Mangrove Group have issued or instructed the issuance of bank guarantees in favor

of customers or lenders. These bank guarantees are not considered to be contingent liabilities because these

guarantees are linked to a performance obligation to be rendered by Mangrove Group.

##### 8.3 Litigation

A number of claims have been brought arising out of the financial restructuring as described below (the

“Restructuring”).

On October 9, 2019, Mangrove LuxCo IV S.à r.l. acquired the shares in Galapagos BidCo S.à r.l. as described

elsewhere in these notes (e.g. chapter “1.2 Acquisition of Galapagos BidCo S.à r.l. and its subsidiaries and

successful Refinancing on October 9, 2019”), associated preferred equity certificates and any intercompany

payables owed by Galapagos BidCo S.à r.l. to its former parent company Galapagos S.A. The acquisition was

made in connection with the Restructuring, which was completed on October 9, 2019.

A number of sets of internationally recognized advisors were involved in the Restructuring and latest

decisions show that the Restructuring was fully legally effective and complied with all obligations, including

under the applicable finance documents.

The following claims have been brought which arise out of the Restructuring:

   - Galapagos BidCo S.à r.l. had commenced proceedings in England against inter alios the Security

Trustee under the Intercreditor Agreement which effected the Restructuring, the trustee which

held rights on behalf of the Galapagos Senior Notes and each of the plaintiffs in the New York,

German and Luxembourg proceedings described below, requesting that the English Court makes

a series of declarations inter alia that the Restructuring complied with the terms of the

Intercreditor Agreement. The English proceedings do not contain any claim for damages. On 28

July 2023 the English Court issued its judgment, ruling in favour of Galapagos BidCo S.à r.l., by

confirming that the Restructuring complied with the Intercreditor Agreement. The decision is

legally binding. This is closed now.

   - A claim in the Supreme Court of the State of New York by a beneficial holder of the Galapagos
Senior Notes (“NY Claimant”) against inter alios Galapagos Holding (former indirect parent of
Galapagos BidCo S.à r.l.) and certain of its subsidiaries (now being subsidiaries of Mangrove
Group) relating to the Restructuring. The plaintiff alleged that the Restructuring wrongly deprived
it of value by diverting assets away from the Group and releasing certain guarantees. The plaintiff
ssought: (i) damages; and (ii) a reversal of the steps taken to affect the Restructuring. In addition,
the plaintiff sought a declaration that the release of liabilities under the Galapagos Senior Notes
Indenture pursuant to the provisions of the former Intercreditor Agreement applying to certain
liabilities of the Group was invalid (in other words, that this part of the Restructuring also be
reversed). The Supreme Court of the State of New York decided on 22 July 2020 to stay this action
pending a decision from the English Court as to its jurisdiction in these matters (as referred to
above). Following the decision of the English Court on 28 July 2023, the NY Claimant agreed to a
joint stipulation regarding the dismissal of its claim with prejudice, i.e., the dismissal is legally
binding on all parties. This is closed now.

   - On October 31, 2019 main insolvency proceedings were opened over the assets of Galapagos
S.A. in Düsseldorf, Germany. Two appeals were lodged at the German Federal Supreme Court on


-----

the jurisdiction of the Düsseldorf insolvency court. Following such appeals, on December 17,
2020, the German Federal Court of Justice referred certain legal questions concerning matters of
European insolvency law (and, consequently, the jurisdiction of the Düsseldorf court in such
insolvency proceedings) to the Court of Justice of the European Union for determination. The
Court of Justice of the European Union rendered its decision on 24 March 2022, which confirmed
that the German courts did not have authority to appoint the administrator on 23 August 2019,
given that the European regime applied to the UK at this time. Following this decision, on 30 June
2022 the English insolvency court made a winding-up order with regard to Galapagos S.A. and
has therefore asserted its jurisdiction over the insolvency proceedings (after it had stayed the
insolvency proceedings in England in August 2019 due to the court in Düsseldorf, Germany,
claiming its jurisdiction). The German Federal Court of Justice rendered its decision (based on the
Court of Justice of the European Union decision) on 8 December 2022, declaring that since the
English courts did not make their winding-up order prior to the Brexit transition period, i.e. 31
December 2020 such that the German courts are no longer bound by the EU Insolvency
regulation when considering proceedings opened in England, the German courts had
retrospective authority to appoint the administrator on 23 August 2019. Thus, the German
insolvency proceedings remain in place, alongside the competing equivalent English proceedings.

   - The purported administrator of Galapagos S.A., Luxembourg (former 100 percent shareholder of
Galapagos BidCo S.à r.l.) has brought a claim against Mangrove LuxCo IV S.à r.l. and Galapagos
BidCo S.à r.l. in Luxembourg detailing his allegations that the Restructuring (i.e. the refinancing
of Galapagos Group and the sale of Galapagos BidCo S.à r.l. to Mangrove Group) involved a
fraudulent exercise of a Luxembourg share pledge and that it should, therefore, be unwound.
However, no steps have been taken by the administrator to progress this claw back action. In
addition, the administrator has brought a separate action challenging the 2021 restructuring of
the assets of Galapagos BidCo S.à r.l. This action raises similar allegations to those made in the
claw back action. The Luxembourg Court has yet to order a timetable for Mangrove LuxCo IV S.à
r.l. and Galapagos BidCo S.à r.l’ to file their defence.
The purported administrator of Galapagos S.A., had initiated a claw back action against inter
alios Mangrove LuxCo IV S.à r.l.  This proceeding was dismissed by the District Court of Düsseldorf
on 15 June 2023. The dismissal is legally binding. This is closed now.

Based on legal advice of leading international law firms based in the UK, Luxembourg, Germany and the US

(privilege in respect of which is not waived) and based on the final decisions of the courts in England, New

York and Germany, Management assesses the risk from the above-mentioned ongoing litigation as well as

future litigation as follows: 1) The risk that the Restructuring would be unwound is considered remote; and

2) The risk of having to pay damages to former holders of the Galapagos Senior Notes or any other third

party is considered unlikely. Please also refer to the chapter “11. Events after the end of the reporting

period”.

##### 9.5 Share based payments

In 2020 certain management personnel (“co-investors”) were invited to participate in the Mangrove Group’s
Management Incentive Plan (“Mangrove MIP”). This investment takes the form of part-ownership of
Mangrove Management Invest S.C.A; an entity which has a part-ownership of Mangrove LuxCo II S.à r.l., the
parent company of Mangrove LuxCo III S.à r.l.. In order to participate in the MIP, an initial cash investment
was required from the co-investors, which was at not less than the fair value of the investments.

During the year 2022 an additional Management Incentive Plan was launched. Again, certain management
personnel were invited to participate in the new Kelvion Thermal Solutions Group’s Management Incentive
Plan (“KTS MIP”). This investment takes the form of part-ownership of TESCO Management S.C.A; an entity
which has a minority of TES LuxCo S.à r.l.. TES LuxCo S.à r.l. is the parent company of the Mangrove´s business
unit Kelvion Thermal Solutions Group. Similar to the first MIP (“Mangrove MIP”) launched in 2020, the
investment is structured in a way that the co-investors are taking a part ownership of a holding company via
an investment vehicle. In order to participate in the KTS MIP, in a first step the co-investors sold their
contribution in the Mangrove MIP at fair value to Mangrove LuxCo I S.à r.l.. In the amount of this receivable
from Mangrove LuxCo I S.à r.l., the co-investors received an investment in the new KTS MIP. The initial cash
related investment of the co-investors (receivable from Mangrove LuxCo I S.à r.l.) in KTS MIP was not less
than to the fair value of the investment in any case.

The nature of both schemes is such that co-investors’ investments will only be realised upon “exit” of the
Group’s current shareholders, with exception of specific events (for example co-investors leaving the
employment of the Group). It is anticipated that co-investors will participate in the MIPs until such exit is
achieved. The lead investor is permitted to issue further equity, and each co-investor has the explicit right
to participate further in the MIPs, such that their investment is not diluted.

In the context of IFRS 2, both MIPs are considered to be equity-settled share-based payment arrangements.

##### 9.10 Correction of errors[1]

During 2023 Mangrove Group discovered that Deferred tax liability related to Agio from SSNs was
underestimated at December 31, 2021, and at December 31, 2022, with amount EUR 11,574 thousand.

On October 9, 2019, Mangrove LuxCo III raised the SSN in the amount of EUR 356,294 thousand on the
capital market, considering a premium of EUR 46,372 thousand. The premium was passed to Mangrove
LuxCo IV via an Intercompany loan, and respected expenses were fully deducted in tax returns. Deferred
taxes on premium were not recognized in the IFRS consolidated financial statements either on the
temporary difference from the SSNs or on the tax loss carryforward.

This error has been corrected by restating each of the affected financial statement line items for prior

### 11.Events after the end of the reporting period

The German insolvency administrator of Galapagos S.A., Luxembourg (former 100 percent shareholder of

Galapagos BidCo S.à r.l.) brought a claim against Mangrove LuxCo IV S.à r.l. and Galapagos BidCo S.à r.l. in

Luxembourg alleging that the Restructuring (i.e. the refinancing of Galapagos Group and the sale of

Galapagos BidCo S.à r.l. to Mangrove Group) involved a fraudulent exercise of a Luxembourg share pledge

and that it should, therefore, be unwound. In addition, the administrator brought a separate action in

Luxembourg challenging the 2021 restructuring of the assets of Galapagos BidCo S.à r.l. This action raised

similar allegations to those made in the separate claw back action in Germany. The German insolvency

administrator of Galapagos S.A. on January 19, 2024 filed withdrawals (Désistement d’action) in respect of

all Luxembourg proceedings previously initiated.

During Q1 2024, the group extended the Senior Guarantee Facility (SGF) as well as the Revolving Credit

Facility (RCF) to 2025, June 9[th].

###### REPORT OF THE REVISEUR D’ENTREPRISES AGREE

 Report on the audit of the consolidated financial statements

 Opinion

 We have audited the consolidated financial statements of Mangrove LuxCo III S.à r.l. and its subsidiaries (the "Group"), which comprise the consolidated statement of financial position as at 31 December 2023, and the consolidated statement of profit or loss, consolidated statement of comprehensive income, consolidated statement of changes in equity and consolidated statement of cash flows for the year then ended, and notes to the consolidated financial statements, including material accounting policy information and other explanatory information.

 In our opinion, the accompanying consolidated financial statements give a true and fair view of the consolidated financial position of the Group as at 31 December 2023, and its consolidated financial performance and its consolidated cash flows for the year then ended in accordance with IFRS Accounting Standards as adopted by the European Union.

 Basis for opinion

 We conducted our audit in accordance with the Law of 23 July 2016 on the audit profession (the “Law of 23 July 2016”) and with International Standards on Auditing (“ISAs”) as adopted for Luxembourg by the Commission de Surveillance du Secteur Financier (“CSSF”). Our responsibilities under the Law of 23 July 2016 and ISAs as adopted for Luxembourg by the CSSF are further described in the « Responsibilities of “réviseur d'entreprises agréé” for the audit of the consolidated financial statements » section of our report. We are also independent of the Group in accordance with the International Code of Ethics for Professional Accountants, including International Independence Standards, issued by the International Ethics Standards Board for Accountants (“IESBA Code”) as adopted for Luxembourg by the CSSF together with the ethical requirements that are relevant to our audit of the consolidated financial statements, and have fulfilled our other ethical responsibilities under those ethical requirements. We believe that the audit evidence we have obtained is sufficient and appropriate to provide a basis for our opinion.

 Other information

 The Board of Managers is responsible for the other information. The other information comprises the information stated in the consolidated report including the consolidated management report but does not include the consolidated financial statements and our report of the “réviseur d'entreprises agréé” thereon.


-----

###### Our opinion on the consolidated financial statements does not cover the other information and we do not express any form of assurance conclusion thereon.

 In connection with our audit of the consolidated financial statements, our responsibility is to read the other information and, in doing so, consider whether the other information is materially inconsistent with the consolidated financial statements or our knowledge obtained in the audit or otherwise appears to be materially misstated. If, based on the work we have performed, we conclude that there is a material misstatement of this other information, we are required to report this fact. We have nothing to report in this regard.

 Responsibilities of the Board of Managers for the consolidated financial statements

 The Board of Managers is responsible for the preparation and fair presentation of the consolidated financial statements in accordance with IFRS Accounting Standards as adopted by the European Union, and for such internal control as the Board of Managers determines is necessary to enable the preparation of consolidated financial statements that are free from material misstatement, whether due to fraud or error.

 In preparing the consolidated financial statements, the Board of Managers is responsible for assessing the Group’s ability to continue as a going concern, disclosing, as applicable, matters related to going concern and using the going concern basis of accounting unless the Board of Managers either intends to liquidate the Group or to cease operations, or has no realistic alternative but to do so.

 Responsibilities of the réviseur d’entreprises agréé for the audit of the consolidated financial statements

 The objectives of our audit are to obtain reasonable assurance about whether the consolidated financial statements as a whole are free from material misstatement, whether due to fraud or error, and to issue a report of the “réviseur d’entreprises agréé” that includes our opinion. Reasonable assurance is a high level of assurance, but is not a guarantee that an audit conducted in accordance with the Law of 23 July 2016 and with ISAs as adopted for Luxembourg by the CSSF will always detect a material misstatement when it exists. Misstatements can arise from fraud or error and are considered material if, individually or in the aggregate, they could reasonably be expected to influence the economic decisions of users taken on the basis of these consolidated financial statements.

 As part of an audit in accordance with the Law of 23 July 2016 and with ISAs as adopted for Luxembourg by the CSSF, we exercise professional judgment and maintain professional skepticism throughout the audit. We also:

 — Identify and assess the risks of material misstatement of the consolidated financial
 statements, whether due to fraud or error, design and perform audit procedures responsive to those risks, and obtain audit evidence that is sufficient and appropriate to provide a basis for our opinion. The risk of not detecting a material misstatement resulting from fraud is higher than for one resulting from error, as fraud may involve collusion, forgery, intentional omissions, misrepresentations, or the override of internal control.

 — Obtain an understanding of internal control relevant to the audit in order to design audit
 procedures that are appropriate in the circumstances, but not for the purpose of expressing an opinion on the effectiveness of the Group’s internal control.

 — Evaluate the appropriateness of accounting policies used and the reasonableness of
 accounting estimates and related disclosures made by the Board of Managers.


-----

###### — Conclude on the appropriateness of the Board of Managers' use of the going concern basis
 of accounting and, based on the audit evidence obtained, whether a material uncertainty exists related to events or conditions that may cast significant doubt on the Group’s ability to continue as a going concern. If we conclude that a material uncertainty exists, we are required to draw attention in our report of the “réviseur d’entreprises agréé” to the related disclosures in the consolidated financial statements or, if such disclosures are inadequate, to modify our opinion. Our conclusions are based on the audit evidence obtained up to the date of our report of the “réviseur d’entreprises agréé”. However, future events or conditions may cause the Group to cease to continue as a going concern.

 — Evaluate the overall presentation, structure and content of the consolidated financial
 statements, including the disclosures, and whether the consolidated financial statements represent the underlying transactions and events in a manner that achieves fair presentation.

 — Obtain sufficient appropriate audit evidence regarding the financial information of the
 entities and business activities within the Group to express an opinion on the consolidated financial statements. We are responsible for the direction, supervision and performance of the Group audit. We remain solely responsible for our audit opinion.

 We communicate with those charged with governance regarding, among other matters, the planned scope and timing of the audit and significant audit findings, including any significant deficiencies in internal control that we identify during our audit.

 We also provide those charged with governance with a statement that we have complied with relevant ethical requirements regarding independence, and to communicate with them all relationships and other matters that may reasonably be thought to bear on our independence, and where applicable, actions taken to eliminate threats or safeguards applied.

 Report on other legal and regulatory requirements

 The consolidated management report is consistent with the consolidated financial statements and has been prepared in accordance with applicable legal requirements.

# Notes to the Consolidated Financial Statements of

 Mangrove Group, Luxembourg

## 1. General information

#### 1.1 Company information

Mangrove LuxCo III S.à r.l., Luxembourg, hereinafter also referred to as " Mangrove LuxCo III " or the

"company" is a public limited liability company (Société à responsabilité limitée) incorporated under the

laws of the Grand Duchy of Luxembourg, having its registered office at 2, rue Edward Steichen, L-2540

Luxembourg, and registered with the Luxembourg Trade and Companies Register (Registre de Commerce

et des Sociétés Luxembourg) with registration number B236258. Sole shareholder of the company is

Mangrove LuxCo II S.à r.l., Luxembourg, which itself is a direct subsidiary of Galapagos LuxCo I S.à r.l.,

Luxembourg. The Company was incorporated on July 11, 2019. The purpose of the Company is the

acquisition, holding and disposal of interests in Luxembourg and/or foreign companies and undertakings as

well as the administration, development and management of such interests.

#### 1.2 Acquisition of Galapagos BidCo S.à r.l. and its subsidiaries and

 successful Refinancing on October 9, 2019

With an effective date October 9, 2019, Mangrove LuxCo IV S.à r.l., Luxembourg, a 100 percent subsidiary

of Mangrove LuxCo III, bought 100 percent of the shares in Galapagos BidCo S.à r.l., Luxembourg and all its

subsidiaries (together “Galapagos BidCo Group”). Galapagos BidCo S.à r.l., Luxembourg, was 100 percent

shareholder of the shares in Kelvion Finance GmbH, Germany including all of its subsidiaries (together

“Kelvion Group”) and in ENEXIO Management GmbH, Germany including all of its subsidiaries (together

“ENEXIO Group”) at the acquisition date. Before the acquisition of Galapagos BidCo Group, the Company

did not have any operational activities.

The Acquisition was consummated in connection with the balance sheet restructuring transaction of the

Galapagos Group, the former shareholder of Galapagos BidCo S.à r.l., which has resulted in a major

recapitalization of the operating business of the Mangrove LuxCo III, Mangrove LuxCo IV and the newly

acquired subsidiaries (collectively, the “Mangrove Group”), a deleveraging of the Mangrove Group’s balance

sheet and access to new debt facilities and instruments with longer tenors (the “Restructuring”). In

connection with the Restructuring, the Company issued EUR 356,233,492 in aggregate principal amount of

7.775 percent senior secured fixed rate notes due 2025 (the “New Notes”).

In preparation of the aforesaid acquisition of Galapagos BidCo Group the Company incorporated or acquired

the following direct and indirect subsidiaries: Incorporation of Mangrove LuxCo IV S.à r.l., Luxembourg on

July 11, 2019 and indirectly via the participation in Mangrove LuxCo IV S.à r.l. the following holding entities

in Germany were acquired on October 9, 2019: Mangrove GermanCo I GmbH, Germany and Mangrove

GermanCo II GmbH, Germany.

In the following, Mangrove LuxCo III and its consolidated direct and indirect subsidiaries is referred to as

"Mangrove Group" or “the Group”.


-----

#### 1.3 Description of the business

The Mangrove Group is a leading global manufacturer of heat exchangers and other cooling & heating

products. The Group is active in multiple end markets such as Refrigeration, HVAC (Heating, Ventilation, Air

Conditioning), Data Center, Power, Heavy & Light Industry, Chemicals, Oil & Gas, Food & Beverage and

Marine. In those markets, the “new Group” services a broad, diversified and long-standing customer base

in more than 130 countries.

###### 1.3.1 Segment Reporting

Mangrove Group operates through the four Kelvion segments, “Kelvion Refrigeration Technologies” (“RT”),

“Kelvion Machine Cooling Systems” (“MCS”), “Kelvion Plate Heat Exchangers” (“PHE”) and “Kelvion Thermal

Solutions” (“KTS”). The former segment “ENEXIO” continues to be in the process of being wound down.

ENEXIO, manufacturer of power plant and industry cooling systems as well as wastewater treatment

solutions, consisted of three business units: Dry Cooling Systems (DCS), Service Solutions and Water

Technologies (WT). After the strategic decision was taken to exit the DCS business and to either sell or

integrate the Service and Water business into Kelvion Group, one part of the DCS business (DCS Heller) was

successfully sold at the end of 2020 and on October 20, 2021 closing in connection with the share purchase

and transfer agreement for the shares of ENEXIO companies comprising the Service business took place.

Furthermore, on January 3, 2022 the same was executed in connection with the shares of ENEXIO

companies comprising the Water business. On March 23, 2022 the Group signed an asset-/share purchase

agreement for certain parts of the DCS business (DCS Air Cooled Condenser) comprising the stake in an

Indian Joint Venture as well as certain assets (intellectual property in Germany and one production line in

China). After these transactions, only parts of the Dry Cooling business remain with the Group, until the

continuing wind-down of this activity has been completed. The declining importance of the ENEXIO Business

is also reflected in its decreasing volume, which represented in FY 2021 already less than 10 Percent and in

FY 2022 less than 1 Percent in terms of Mangrove Group. Overall, the contribution of the segment ENEXIO

to revenue and normalized EBITDA of the Group is no longer significant for the Group’s earnings position.

###### 1.3.2 The four segments of Mangrove Group

The four segments of Mangrove Group focus on distinct technologies and product portfolios:

- **Kelvion Refrigeration Technologies (RT) focuses on component business for refrigeration applications**

with significant growth potential in the data center industry. RT supplies a wide range of standard and

customized heat exchangers for cooling and removing heat from different types of data centers

(hyperscale, colocation, modular etc.) using both air and liquid cooling methods. The data center market

consists of cooling solutions such as air conditioning, chilling units, economizer systems, liquid cooling

systems, control systems and includes services such as consulting, installation & deployment and

maintenance and support. The heat exchanger solutions are also used in the refrigeration market in cold

chain warehouses, supermarkets, non-residential buildings, and industrial production. Product offering

includes air cooled condensers which reject heat from refrigeration systems and are often sold as part of

a package of equipment with air coolers. RT’s customized air coolers are design-to-order units for

industrial or OEM solutions for food processing and distribution facilities. Product offering includes also

customized radiators and dry coolers which are mainly used for power and industrial applications.

Improving the energy efficiency of commercial and industrial refrigeration equipment is essential for end

users looking to reduce carbon footprint and operating costs.


-----

- **Kelvion Machine Cooling Systems (MCS) is a leading player in heat exchangers for power and engine**

applications with substantial growth opportunities by leveraging its global installed base. MCS supplies

heat exchangers for power generation, power transmission, large engine applications (marine and off
highway) and green applications like biomass, green hydrogen, or renewable energies. The business is

mostly with OEM, e.g., for large engine manufacturers, but MCS also engages in smaller projects, like solar,

wind or solar photovoltaic. Product offering includes charge air coolers, which cool down combustion-air

coming from the turbocharger before entering the engine. MCS’ shell and tube double safety heat

exchangers assure the secure handling of safety-critical media. Product offering also includes box coolers

which are fitted in the sea chest of small and medium-sized vessels.

- **Kelvion Thermal Solutions (KTS), is Kelvion’s largest segment, focusing on project business for demanding**

applications in the Oil & Gas, Chemicals Industries and, like RT, with significant growth potential in high

tech data center business as well as green tech applications such as hydrogen and Carbon Capture and

Storage (CCS). KTS’ engineering expertise plays a key role in differentiation against competitors. High

degree of geographical diversification with sites in all key region, including Europe, NAFTA, Latin America,

China and MEA. Product offering includes air fin coolers typically used for very large cooling requirements

in different industries, e.g., Oil & Gas and Chemicals, as well as air dryers which are used to remove

humidity from an air stream in various process industries. KTS’ shell & tube heat exchangers are used to

heat, cool, or condense water and other media in different process industries. The focus of the BU has

shifted in the recent years from Oil & Gas and Petrochemicals to high and green tech business. KTS

represents mainly the former segment “Kelvion Thermal Engineered Solutions” (“TES”).

- **Kelvion Plate Heat Exchangers (PHE) provides a broad range of plate heat exchangers for a wide variety**

of applications in terms of pressure and temperature demands for a wide range of customer industries,

ranging from HVAC and Refrigeration to Food & Beverages, Chemicals, Power, and Industrials. Product

offering includes fully welded plate heat exchangers which are used to save energy in demanding high

pressure and temperature applications, as well as brazed plate heat exchangers, often used for

environmentally friendly heat pump applications. PHE’s gasketed heat exchangers have the highest

efficiency and flexibility and are used in a variety of industries as well as for heat recovery applications.

In contrast to the project driven segment KTS, the three segments RT, MCS and PHE represent the

component type business of the Group and form together “Kelvion Products” (“KP”). All four segments hold

strong favorable market positions in their respective markets. MCS and PHE are among the TOP 3, RT

amongst the Top 5 and KTS is niche-market leader.

In addition to the above segments there is the fifth Service segment, which is a virtual segment, i.e., Service

is not separated from the four segments but managed globally and centrally across segments.

## 2. Reporting and Accounting principles

#### 2.1 Going-concern basis of accounting

###### Preparation of consolidated financial statements

With effective date December 21, 2022, the Group agreed with the lenders to reset the financial covenants,

to which the budget 2023 offers sufficient headroom. In the first three months of the year 2023 the Group

can report an order intake and a financial performance that exceeds previous year and budget 2023. Based

on the good start to the year, management of the Group expects the financial performance for the full year

to exceed budget. With current market conditions and business performance, the Group does not see any

current risk to complying with future covenant requirements and consequently the management does not

see any risk to the going concern of the Group. Based on actual planning the Group will be at every time and

in the upcoming year in the position to meet all its financial obligations.

Therefore, the consolidated financial statements of Mangrove Group have been prepared on a going
concern basis.

#### 2.2 Basis of presentation

The presented consolidated financial statements cover the period from January 1, 2022 to December 31,

2022 with the prior period from January 1, 2021 to December 31, 2021.

The consolidated financial statements of Mangrove Group - which comprise the consolidated statement of

financial position, consolidated statement of profit or loss, consolidated statement of comprehensive

income, consolidated statement of cash flows, consolidated statement of changes in equity and the notes

to the consolidated financial statements - include Mangrove LuxCo III and its direct and indirect subsidiaries

(hereinafter referred to as “Mangrove Group” or the “Group”). The consolidated financial statements have

been prepared in accordance with the International Financial Reporting Standards (IFRS) as adopted by the

EU. All IFRS standards and interpretations in effect for fiscal years beginning on or after January 1, 2022,

have been applied.

The consolidated financial statements are prepared in euro (EUR), the functional currency of the group, and

presented in thousand of euros (EUR thousand) or in millions of euros (EUR million). Due to rounding, figures

presented may result in differences of EUR 1 thousand in certain cases.

To improve the clarity of presentation, various items in the consolidated balance sheet and consolidated

income statement have been aggregated and are explained accordingly in the Notes. Assets and liabilities

are classified into current and non-current items. Current assets are expected to be realized within 12

months after the reporting period and current liabilities are due to be settled within 12 months after the

reporting period. The consolidated income statement is prepared using the cost of sales method.

The consolidated statement of cash flows is prepared using the indirect method for cash flows from

operating activities and the direct method for cash flows from investing and financing activities.

The accounting and measurement principles are presented and explained in detail in Note 2.8. The

consolidated financial statements were authorized for issue by the Board of Managers on April 28, 2023.

#### 2.3 First-time adoption of new accounting pronouncements

The Group applied for the first time all standards and amendments, which are effective for annual periods


-----

beginning on January 1, 2022. The impact on the consolidated financial statements of the Group is not

significant. The Group has not early adopted any other standard, interpretation or amendments that were

issued but are not yet effective.

###### 2.3.1 Accounting regulations applied for the first time in the year 2022

   - **Amendments to IFRS 16 (Effective April 1, 2021)**

IFRS 16 contains regulations regarding the recognition of changes in lease payments (including

rental concessions) by the lessee. In general, the lessee must assess for each lease whether the

lease concessions granted constitute changes to the lease and must remeasure the lease liability

as a result.

In response to the ongoing impact of the COVID-19 pandemic, IFRS 16 Leases was amended on

March 31, 2021 to provide a one-year extension of the practical expedient to assist lessees in

accounting for COVID-19-related lease concessions. The amendments extend the practical

expedient to lease concessions that reduce lease payments originally due on or before June 30,

2022. Previously, only lease concessions that reduce lease payments that are or were due on or

before June 30, 2021, were within the scope of the relief.

   - **Amendments to IAS 37 (Effective January 1, 2022)**

Clarification that the cost of fulfilling a contract includes all directly attributable costs. The cost of

fulfilling the contract includes both the incremental costs of fulfilling that contract (such as direct

wage and material costs) and an allocation of other costs that relate directly to fulfilling contracts.

In addition, it is clarified that before a provision for an onerous contract is established, an entity

should recognize any impairment loss that has occurred on assets used in (previously: dedicated

to) fulfilling the contract.

   - **Amendments to IFRS 3 (Effective January 1, 2022)**

In accordance to the amended framework, references to the framework in various standards,

including IFRS 3, have been adjusted. The rules for accounting for business combinations are not

changed in substance. The amendments are to be applied to business combinations for which the

acquisition date is on or after January 1, 2022. Earlier application is permitted.

   - **Improvements to IFRS 2018 – 2020 (Effective January 1, 2022)**

The Annual Improvements to IFRS amended the following standards:

`o` In IFRS 1, the option was opened for first-time adopters of IFRS 1.D16 (a) to measure

cumulative translation differences at the amounts recognized by the parent.
`o` The amendment to IFRS 9 clarifies which fees are to be included in the 10 percent test

(IFRS 9.B3.3.6) with regard to the assessment of whether a financial liability is

derecognized. Only fees paid or received between the entity as borrower and the lender

are included.
`o` In IFRS 16, the presentation of the reimbursement of leasehold improvements has been

removed in explanatory example 13 to IFRS 16.
`o` In IAS 41, the prohibition on including tax payments in the fair value measurement is

removed.

   - **Amendments to IAS 16 (Effective January 1, 2022)**

The amendment prohibits entities from deducting the cost of an item of property, plant and


-----

equipment any proceeds from selling items produced while bringing that asset to the location and

condition necessary for it to be capable of operating in the manner intended by management.

Clarification of the definition of the costs of testing. Revenue and cost that relate to items

produced that are not an output of the entity’s ordinary activities must be presented separately.

Disclosure of the line item in the statement of comprehensive item that includes such revenue.

###### 2.3.2 Accounting regulations not applied in advance of their effective date

The following standards and amendments to existing standards of possible relevance to the Group, which

were adopted into EU law (endorsement mechanism) but are not yet mandatory, have not been applied

early:

   - **IFRS 17 Insurance Contracts (including Amendments) (Effective January 1, 2023)**

IFRS 17 replaces IFRS 4 and for the first time sets out standard requirements for the recognition,

measurement, presentation and disclosure of insurance contracts, reinsurance contracts and

investment contracts with discretionary participation features. Under the IFRS 17 measurement

model, groups of insurance contracts are measured based on the expected value of discounted

cash flows with an explicit risk adjustment for non-financial risks as well as a contractual service

margin that results in the recognition of profit in line with the provision of services.

The amendments add a transition option aimed to improve the usefulness of comparative

information presented on initial application of both IFRS 17 and IFRS 9 and introduce the option

of applying a "classification overlay approach". This option can be applied when IFRS 17 and IFRS

9 are applied simultaneously for the first time and no "restatement" of a financial asset with

regard to the comparative information of IFRS 9 in 2022 is made.

   - **Amendments to IAS 1 and IFRS Practice Statement 2 (Effective January 1, 2023)**

The amendment to IAS 1 requires that only "significant" accounting policies are presented in the

notes. To be material, the accounting policy must be related to significant transactions or other

events and there must be a reason for its presentation. A reason may be, for example, that the

method has been changed, it is an option, the method is complex or highly judgmental, or it has

been developed in accordance with IAS 8.10-11. The amendments to Practice Statement 2

accordingly indicate how the concept of materiality is applied to the disclosure of accounting

policies. Thus, in the future, company-specific disclosures are to be given priority over

standardized disclosures.

   - **Amendments to IAS 8 (Effective January 1, 2023)**

The amendment to IAS 8 clarifies how entities can better distinguish changes in accounting

policies from changes in estimates. For this purpose, it is defined that an accounting estimate

always relates to a measurement uncertainty of a financial figure in the financial statements. In

addition to input parameters, an entity also uses valuation techniques to determine an estimate.

Valuation techniques can be estimation techniques or valuation techniques.


-----

   - **Amendments to IAS 12 (Effective January 1, 2023)**

The amendments address previously existing uncertainties in the accounting for deferred taxes

in connection with leases and disposal or restoration obligations.

The amendments clarify the application of the already existing “initial recognition exemption”

(IAS 12.15) and result in the recognition of deferred taxes, e.g. on leases accounted for by the

lessee and on disposal or restoration obligations. This is therefore an exemption to the "initial

recognition exemption" for narrowly defined cases.

These new standards and amendments to existing standards will be applied by the Group starting in fiscal

2022 or later. No material impacts are expected.

#### 2.4 Accounting pronouncements not yet endorsed by the EU

In previous years, and in fiscal year 2022, the IASB issued the following standards and amendments to

existing standards of relevance to the Group, which still have to be adopted into EU law (endorsement

mechanism) before they become applicable:

   - **Amendments to IAS 1 (Effective January 1, 2023)**

The amendments to IAS 1 concern a limited adjustment to the assessment criteria for classifying

liabilities as current or non-current.

It is clarified that the classification of liabilities as current depends on the entity's rights at the

reporting date to defer settlement of the liability for at least twelve months after the end of the

reporting period: If such rights exist, the liability is classified as non-current. The right to defer

settlement of the liability must be substantial. If the entity has to meet certain conditions in order

to exercise such a right, these conditions must be met at the reporting date; otherwise, the

liability is classified as current.

For the classification of a liability, it is irrelevant whether management intends or expects that

the liability will actually be settled within twelve months after the balance sheet date. The only

decisive factor for classification is the right existing at the balance sheet date to defer settlement

of the liability for at least 12 months. This also applies in the event of settlement within the value

recovery period.

   - **Amendments to IFRS 16 (Effective January 1, 2024)**

The Amendments to IFRS 16 shall clarify how a seller-lessee subsequently measures sale and

leaseback transactions that satisfy the requirements in IFRS 15 to be accounted for as a sale. It

requires a seller-lessee to subsequently measure lease liabilities arising from a leaseback in a

way that it does not recognise any amount of the gain or loss that relates to the right of use it

retains. The new requirements do not prevent a seller-lessee from recognising in profit or loss

any gain or loss relating to the partial or full termination of a lease.

   - **Amendments to IFRS 10 and IAS 28**

The amendments address a known inconsistency between the requirements of IFRS 10 and IAS

28 (2011) in the case of the disposal of assets to an associate or joint venture or the contribution

of assets to an associate or joint venture.


-----

IFRS 10 requires a parent to recognize the full amount of the gain or loss on disposal of a

subsidiary in profit or loss when control is lost. In contrast, the currently applicable IAS 28.28

requires that the gain or loss on disposal of a disposal transaction between an investor and an

investment accounted for using the equity method - whether an associate or a joint venture - be

recognized only to the extent of the other's interest in the entity.

In the future, the entire gain or loss on a transaction is to be recognized only if the assets sold or

contributed constitute a business as defined by IFRS 3. This applies regardless of whether the

transaction is structured as a share or asset deal. If, on the other hand, the assets do not

constitute a business, only pro rata income recognition is permitted.

The IASB has postponed the date of first-time application of the amendments indefinitely.

#### 2.5 Impact of the introduction of a global minimum tax rate by

 the OECD (Pillar Two)

To address concerns about the unequal distribution of profits and unequal tax levies of large multinational

corporations, various agreements have been reached at the global level, including an agreement by over

135 countries to introduce a global minimum tax rate of 15 percent. In December 2021, the OECD published

a draft legal framework, followed by detailed guidance in March 2022, to be used by individual countries

that are signatories to the agreement to amend their local tax laws. Once the changes in tax laws are in place

or will soon be in place in the countries where the Group operates, the Group may be subject to the

minimum tax.

At the date of authorization of the consolidated financial statements for issue, the tax legislation related to

the minimum tax is not applicable or soon to be applicable in any of the countries in which the Group

operates. The Board closely monitors the progress of the legislative process in each country in which the

Group operates. As of December 31, 2022, the Group did not have sufficient information to determine the

potential quantitative impact.

#### 2.6 Basis of consolidation

###### Consolidated entities

The consolidated financial statements comprise the financial statements of Mangrove LuxCo III and its direct

and indirect subsidiaries as of December 31, 2022. The financial statements of the subsidiaries are generally

prepared for the same reporting period as the parent company, except of the Indian subsidiary, consistently

applying group IFRS accounting policies. The financial year ends due to local Indian commercial law on March

31, each year. This company was incorporated in the consolidated financial statements of Mangrove Group

on the basis of interim financial statements.

All intra-group balances and transactions, and any unrealized income and expenses arising from intra-group

transactions, are eliminated.

The consolidated financial statements of Mangrove Group include Mangrove LuxCo III and all material

companies which Mangrove LuxCo III controls directly or indirectly. Companies are consolidated as of the

date on which control is obtained by Mangrove LuxCo III. They are deconsolidated as of the date on which

control is lost.

In addition to the ultimate parent company, 55 companies were consolidated.

**Subsidiaries**

Subsidiaries are entities controlled by the company. Control is assumed, when the following three criteria

are fulfilled: (1) the parent company holds decision-making power over the relevant activities of the

investee, (2) the company has rights to variable returns from the investee and (3) the parent company can

use its decision-making power to affect the variable returns. The fulfillment of these criteria is assessed

based on corporate governance and potential supplementary agreements.

Acquisitions include the following companies: ENEXIO ACC GmbH, Kelvion Management GmbH, Thermal

Solutions Germany GmbH and TESCO Management SCA .

The ongoing optimazition of the group structure reduced the number of subsiduaries to a minimum. In 2022,

one consolidated company (Mangrove HoldCo S.à r.l.) was **_liquidated. In addition one consolidated_**

company was merged. The Kelvion Thermal S.A.S. was merged into Kelvion Thermal Soutions S.A.S.

In 2022 the two consolidated companies ENEXIO Water Technologies GmbH and ENEXIO UK Ltd. were sold

and **_deconsolidated. For further details see Note 4. “Non-current assets held for sale and discontinued_**

operations”.

Companies that are dormant or do not have significant impact on the financial position and results of

operation of the Group are not included in the consolidated financial statements.

A total of three (prior year: three) companies are not consolidated. The aggregate assets, equity, revenues

and earnings of these companies are not material to the consolidated financial statements. The subsidiaries

are recognised at cost as non-current other financial assets. Management deems the influence to the Group

as absolutely insignificant and hence, the disclosure required under IFRS has not been made due to

materiality reason. The disclosure of this information is not suitable to communicate additional information.

###### Control over subsidiary Galapagos BidCo S.à r.l.

As described in more detail in section “9.3 Litigations”, the purported administrator of Galapagos S.A.

(“GSA”), Luxembourg (former 100 percent shareholder of Galapagos BidCo S.à r.l., “GBG") brought a claim

in Luxembourg against Mangrove LuxCo IV S.à r.l. (Mangrove) and GBG. An _ex parte order of the_

Luxembourg Court was granted on November 27, 2019 at the request of the purported administrator of

GSA placing the shares of GBG in escrow and appointing a Luxembourg based law firm as escrow trustee

(the Trustee). The Escrow Order has as its primary purpose the preservation of the GBG shares as an asset,

primarily by preventing an actual or de facto liquidation of GBG, pending separate determination of the

main proceedings brought by GSA (which contest the transfer of the shares in GBG under a Luxembourg


-----

pledge enforcement). This escrow order was successfully appealed and set aside by the Luxembourg Court.

This decision was then appealed by the purported administrator, but this appeal was rejected by the Court.

A further appeal has been lodged by the purported administrator to the Luxembourg Cour de cassation

which overturned the Court of Appeal’s decision. The matter was referred back to the Luxembourg Court of

Appeal to consider the position on the merits but was dismissed. The consequence of these various actions

is that there is no escrow order in place. Finally, the administrator has brought a separate action challenging

the 2021 restructuring of the assets of Galapagos BidCo S.à r.l. This action raises similar allegations to those

made in the claw back action. The Luxembourg Court has yet to order a timetable for Mangrove LuxCo IV

S.à r.l. and Galapagos BidCo S.à r.l’ to file their defence.

Following an application of the purported administrator of Galapagos S.A., the District Court of Düsseldorf,

Germany, has issued an injunction (einstweilige Verfügung) against Mangrove LuxCo IV S.à r.l., ordering an

escrow agent to hold the shares in Galapagos BidCo S.à r.l. This order was successfully appealed and,

consequently, the injunction was lifted in June 2021. Further, by the same plaintiff, a main proceeding

(Hauptsacheverfahren) has been initiated against inter alios Mangrove LuxCo IV S.à r.l. A first hearing took

place in February 2023 with a decision announced for May 2023 (reference is made to section “9.3

Litigations”).

The intention of the Escrow Order is not to interfere with the ordinary course of business of GBG or of the

Group and as such where matters are in the ordinary course of business and the Trustee is requested to

vote the GBG Shares to approve such actions. Therefore, the Company as the parent company holds (1)

decision-making power over the relevant activities of GBG, (2) has rights to variable returns from the

investee and (3) can use its decision-making power to affect the variable returns. Furthermore, the

imposition of the Escrow Order has been contested by Mangrove.

###### Interests in associated companies and joint ventures

Associated are those entities in which the Group has significant influence, but no control or joint control,

over the financial and operating policies. A joint venture is an arrangement in which the Group has joined

control, whereby the Group has rights to the net assets of the arrangement, rather than rights to its assets

and obligations for its liabilities. Interests in associated companies and joint ventures are accounted for using

the equity method and at cost in case the company is not material. They are initially recognised at cost,

which includes transaction costs. Subsequent to initial recognition, the consolidated financial statements

include the Group's share of profit or loss and OCI of equity accounted investees, until the date on which

significant influence or joint control ceases for those that are accounted at equity.

Two associated companies are accounted at cost since they are not material.

Management deems the influence of the associated companies to the financial position of the Group as

insignificant.


-----

#### 2.7 Currency translation

The Mangrove Group companies prepare their annual financial statements on the basis of their respective

functional currencies.

Foreign currency transactions entered into by companies included in the consolidated financial statements

are translated into the functional currency at the exchange rate prevailing at the transaction date. Monetary

assets and liabilities are translated at the applicable exchange rate at each reporting date. Exchange rate

gains and losses resulting from these items are generally reported in the income statement under other

income or expenses. Non-monetary items measured in terms of historical acquisition or production cost in

a foreign currency are translated using the exchange rates at the dates of the transaction. Non-monetary

items measured at fair value in a foreign currency are translated using the exchange rates as of the date

when the fair value was determined.

All financial statements of companies whose functional currencies differ from the reporting currency are

translated into the reporting currency used in the consolidated financial statements. The assets and

liabilities of the companies included in the consolidated financial statements are translated at the middle

rates prevailing at the reporting date. The income statements of these companies are translated at the

average rates for the period under review. If these average rates are not a reasonable approximation of the

actual transaction rates, the income statements are translated at the relevant transaction rates. Any

translation differences are recognised and subsequently adjusted in other comprehensive income.
